thence north along the range line between ranges eighty-five (85) and eighty-six (86) west to the northeast corner of section one (1), township forty-eight (48), north range eighty-six (86) west; thence west along the twelfth standard parallel to the northwest corner of section six (6), township forty-eight (48), north range ninety-seven (97) west; thence south along the range lines between ranges ninety-seven (97) and ninety-eight (98) west to the southwest corner of section thirty-one (31), township forty-eight (48), north range ninety-seven (97) west; thence east along the township line between townships forty-seven (47) and forty-eight (48) north, to the northeast corner of section four (4), township forty-seven (47), north range ninety-seven (97) west; thence south along section lines to the southwest corner of section thirty-four (34), township forty-seven (47), north range ninety-seven (97) west; thence east along the township line between townships forty-six (46) and forty-seven (47) north to the northwest corner of section six (6), township forty-six (46) north, range ninety-six (96) west; thence south along the range line between ranges ninety-six (96) and ninety-seven (97) west to the southwest corner section thirty-one (31), township forty-six (46), north range ninety-six (96) west; thence east along the township line between townships forty-five (45) and forty-six (46) north, to the northwest corner of section six (6), township forty-five (45), north range ninety-five (95) west; thence south along the range line between ranges ninety-five (95) and ninety-six (96) west, to the southwest corner of section nineteen (19), township forty-five (45), north range ninety-five (95) west; thence east along the section lines to the intersection of said line with the center line of the main channel of the Big Horn River; thence southerly along the center line of the main channel of the Big Horn River to the township line between townships forty-four (44) and forty-five (45); thence east along said township line between townships forty-four (44) and forty-five (45) north, to the northwest corner of section six (6), township forty-four (44), north range ninety-two (92) west; thence south along the range line between ranges ninety-two (92) and ninety-three (93) west, to the southwest corner of section thirty-one (31), township forty-four (44), north range ninety-two (92) west; thence east along the township line between townships forty-three (43) and forty-four (44) north, to the northwest corner of section six (6), township forty-three (43), north range ninety (90) west; thence south along the range line between ranges ninety (90) and ninety-one (91) west, to the southwest corner of section thirty-one (31), township forty-three (43), north range ninety (90) west; thence east along the township line between townships forty-two (42) and forty-three (43), north to the northwest corner of section six (6), township forty-two (42), north range eighty-nine (89) west; thence south along the range line between ranges eighty-nine (89) and ninety (90) west, to the southwest corner of section nineteen (19), township forty-one (41), north range eighty-nine (89) west; thence east along section lines to the point of beginning.
  23. Weston county is that portion of the state of Wyoming within the following boundaries: commencing at a point on the eastern boundary of the state of Wyoming where the same is intersected by a line projected east from the west one-quarter corner of section thirty (30), township forty-one (41) north, range sixty (60) west; thence north along said eastern boundary of the state of Wyoming, to the point on said boundary where the same is intersected by the township line between townships forty-eight (48) and forty-nine (49) north; thence west along said township line to the northwest corner of section six (6), township forty-eight (48) north, range sixty-eight (68) west; thence south along the range line between ranges sixty-eight (68) and sixty-nine (69) west to the southwest corner of section thirty-one (31), township forty-five (45) north, range sixty-eight (68) west; thence along the eleventh (11th) standard parallel to the northwest corner of section six (6), township forty-four (44) north, range sixty-eight (68) west; thence south along the range line between ranges sixty-eight (68) and sixty-nine (69) west to the west one-quarter corner of section thirty (30), township forty-one (41) north, range sixty-eight (68) west; thence east through centers of sections and through one-quarter corners to the point of beginning.

The eastern boundary of Natrona county, Wyoming, and the western boundary of Converse county, Wyoming, is hereby fixed, established and determined to be as follows, to-wit: beginning at the center of section twenty-six (26), township forty-one (41) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence south to the south one-quarter corner of section thirty-five (35), township forty-one (41) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence along the tenth (10th) standard parallel to the northeast corner of section three (3), township forty (40) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence south along section lines to the southeast corner of section thirty-four (34), township thirty-seven (37) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence along the ninth (9th) standard parallel to the north one-quarter corner of section three (3), township thirty-six (36) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence south through the centers of sections and through one-quarter corners to the north one-quarter corner of section thirty-four (34), township thirty-three (33) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence south on centerline of section thirty-four (34) to the southwest corner of lot one (1), section thirty-four (34), thence west on the north line of tract forty-four (44), section thirty-four (34) to the northwest corner thereof, thence south on the west line of tract forty-four (44), section thirty-four (34), township thirty-three (33) north, range seventy-seven (77) west, to the southwest corner thereof; thence south along the east line of lots eleven (11), thirteen (13), fourteen (14), eighteen (18) and tract fifty-two (52), section four (4), township thirty-two (32) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence south along the east line of tract fifty-two (52), lots three (3), four (4), six (6), and tract fifty-nine (59), section nine (9); thence south along the east line of tract fifty-nine (59) and lot three (3) to the southwest corner of tract fifty-eight (58), thence east on south line of tract fifty-eight (58) to the northwest corner of lot four (4), thence south on the east line of lot three (3), section sixteen (16); thence south along the east line of lots one (1), two (2), three (3), four (4), section twenty-one (21); thence south along the east line of lot four (4) to the point of intersection on the north boundary of lot “A”, tract seventy-eight (78), thence east along the north boundary of lot “A” to the northeast corner thereof, thence south along the east line of lot “A” to the southeast corner thereof, thence west along the south line of lot “A” to the southwest corner of lot “A,” tract seventy-eight (78); thence south along the west line of lots three (3), four (4), five (5), section twenty-eight (28); thence south on the west line of lot one (1), section thirty-three (33) to the northeast corner of tract ninety-seven (97) “B”, thence east along the north line of lot “A”, tract ninety-seven (97) to the northeast corner thereof, thence south on the east line of tract ninety-seven (97) to the southeast corner thereof, thence west on the south line of tract ninety-seven (97) to the east line of lot six (6), thence south on the east line of lot six (6) to the township line, all being in township thirty-two (32) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence west on the township line to the north one-quarter of section four (4), township thirty-one (31) north, range seventy-seven (77) west; thence south through the centers of sections and through one-quarter corners to the south one-quarter corner of section thirty-three (33), township twenty-nine (29) north, range seventy-seven (77) west, in accordance with the original survey and resurvey plats on file in the public survey office of the United States general land office, Cheyenne, Wyoming.

History.

Laws 1911, ch. 7, § 1; ch. 8, § 1; ch. 9, § 1; ch. 10, § 1; ch. 14, § 1; ch. 20, § 1; ch. 67, § 1; ch. 77, §§ 1 to 14; C.S. 1920, §§ 1249 to 1269; Laws 1921, ch. 52, § 1; ch. 53, § 1; 1923, ch. 21, § 1; 1929, ch. 18, § 1; ch. 22, § 1; ch. 42, § 1; 1931, ch. 96, § 1; ch. 124, § 1; R.S. 1931, §§ 29-102 to 29-124; C.S. 1945, §§ 26-102 to 26-124; Laws 1950, Sp. Sess., ch. 8, § 1; 1951, ch. 61, §§ 1, 2; 1953, ch. 137, §§ 1, 2; 1954, ch. 74, § 1; 1955, ch. 74, § 2; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-2 to 18-6, 18-8 to 18-25; Laws 1961, ch. 38, § 1; ch. 43, § 1; 1963, ch. 106, §§ 1, 2; 1965, ch. 149, §§ 1, 2; 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

Chapter 77, Laws 1911, redescribed the boundaries of Albany, Big Horn, Carbon, Converse, Crook, Fremont, Johnson, Laramie, Natrona, Park, Sheridan, Sweetwater, Uinta and Weston counties.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Albany county were § 1, ch. 27, C.L. 1876; § 1, ch. 5, Laws 1886; § 657, R.S. 1887; § 981, R.S. 1899; § 1023, C.S. 1910.

The prior laws defining the boundaries of Big Horn county were § 1, ch. 48, Laws 1890; § 982, R.S. 1899; § 1024, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws fixing boundaries of Carbon county were §§ 1, 2, ch. 27, C.L. 1876; § 1, ch. 19, Laws 1879; §§ 1, 5, ch. 5, Laws 1886; § 659, R.S. 1887; § 983, R.S. 1899; § 1, ch. 129, Laws 1909; § 1024, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Converse county were § 60, ch. 90, Laws 1888; § 984, R.S. 1899; § 1026, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws fixing boundaries of Crook county were § 1, ch. 27, C.L. 1876; § 661, R.S. 1887; § 985, R.S. 1899; § 1027, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Fremont county were § 1, ch. 46, Laws 1884; § 663, R.S. 1887; § 986, R.S. 1899; § 2, ch. 129, Laws 1909; § 1028, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Johnson county were § 2, ch. 27, C.L. 1876; § 1, ch. 31, Laws 1879; § 664, R.S. 1887; § 987, R.S. 1899; § 1029, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Laramie county were § 1, ch. 105, Laws 1886; § 665, R.S. 1887; § 988, R.S. 1899; § 1030, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Natrona county were § 61, ch. 90, Laws 1888; § 989, R.S. 1899; § 3, ch. 129, Laws 1909; § 1035, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Park county were § 1, ch. 19, Laws 1909; § 1031, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Sheridan county were § 62, ch. 90, Laws 1888; § 990, R.S. 1899; § 1036, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Sweetwater county were § 1, ch. 27, C.L. 1876; § 1, ch. 46, Laws 1884; § 5, ch. 5, Laws 1886; § 667, R.S. 1887; § 991, R.S. 1899; § 4, ch. 129, Laws 1909; § 1037, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Uinta county were § 1, ch. 27, C.L. 1876; § 669, R.S. 1887; § 992, R.S. 1899; § 1038, C.S. 1910.

Prior laws defining boundaries of Weston county were § 1, ch. 47, Laws 1890; § 993, R.S. 1899; § 1039, C.S. 1910.

Section 4, ch. 74, Laws 1955, amending § 4, ch. 137, Laws 1953, provides as follows:

“The changes as hereinabove made of the boundaries of Albany and Converse counties shall not become effective and such boundaries be so established until a majority of the qualified electors of the territory proposed to be cut off from Albany county voting on the proposition shall vote in favor of such change.

“An election for such purpose shall be held at a time, not later than August 1, 1955, to be fixed by resolution of the board of county commissioners of Albany county and shall be held and conducted in the same manner as is provided for the conduct of other special elections, and the board of county commissioners shall certify the results to the secretary of state and to the board of county commissioners of Converse county.”

At a special election held on July 12, 1955, a majority of the qualified voters voted in favor of the change.

There is no subsection (i) or (l) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Repealing clauses. —

Section 6, ch. 7, Laws 1911, repealed all laws and parts of laws in conflict therewith.

Section 5, ch. 20, Laws 1911, repealed all laws and parts of laws in conflict therewith.

Section 2, ch. 18, Laws 1929, repealed all laws and parts of laws in conflict therewith.

Section 2, ch. 124, Laws 1931, repealed all laws and parts of laws in conflict therewith.

Assessment in disputed territory. —

Where territory is claimed by two counties, taxpayer's application by bill of complaint to court of chancery for order requiring parties interested to interplead and for perpetual injunction against those in error is proper course. Union Pac. R.R. v. Carr, 1 Wyo. 96, 1872 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1872).

Contribution toward indebtedness. —

Where Wyoming legislature organized two new counties including within their limits parts of an existing county, old county had no claim upon new counties for contribution on its outstanding indebtedness in absence of provision for an apportionment. Commissioners of Laramie County v. Commissioners of Albany County, 92 U.S. 307, 23 L. Ed. 552, 1875 U.S. LEXIS 1759 (U.S. 1876).

Sufficiency of name. —

The name used in this section is sufficient to create the corporate name of Sweetwater county. Board Comm'rs Sweetwater County v. Young, 3 Wyo. 684, 29 P. 1002, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1892).

Population requirement. —

Since Big Horn county was not organized before adoption of the state constitution, proceedings for its organization could not be taken until it had a population of 1,500. Board of Comm'rs v. Perkins, 5 Wyo. 166, 38 P. 915, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1895).

In general. —

When Campbell county was carved out of Crook and Weston counties it was provided that, until it should have organized and elected county officers, all portions of Campbell county should belong to and be a part of Crook and Weston counties for revenue and other purposes, that portion of Campbell county lying within Crook county must, until the board of supervisors was duly elected and qualified, be considered as a part of Crook county in determining the status of that county, according to the assessed valuation of the property therein. Board of Comm'rs v. Mulholland, 22 Wyo. 130, 136 P. 112, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1913).

Status. —

Campbell county remained a part of the counties from which it was created until the organization was perfected and the supervisors were elected and qualified. Board of Comm'rs v. Mulholland, 22 Wyo. 130, 136 P. 112, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1913).

Constitutionality of 1921 act. —

Chapter 53, Laws 1921, insofar as it undertook to form Teton county, it was constitutional, using the word “form” in the sense employed by the constitution. Budge v. Board of Comm'rs, 29 Wyo. 35, 208 P. 874, 1922 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1922).

The organization of Teton county without regard to provisions of § 18-1-303 as to population and assessed valuation of property, having been validated by curative act and recognized by other enactments, was not invalid. State ex rel. Budge v. Snyder, 31 Wyo. 333, 225 P. 1102, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1924).

Curative statute. —

Curative statute legalizing defective organization of Teton county, was not invalid as special act organizing county or regulating its affairs or interfering with uniform operation of general laws. State ex rel. Budge v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 287, 219 P. 735, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1923).

Courts powerless to correct inaccurate description of countyset forth in statute. —

Where there was a failure to describe accurately in this section the boundaries of Converse county so as to leave part thereof not properly closed and a portion of the county not united with any portion of the state, the supreme court held that it was beyond the power of the courts to correct and remedy the situation and that the matter should be resubmitted to the incoming legislature so that proper boundaries could be established in accord with the certain and definite intentions of the lawmaking body. State ex rel. Fawcett v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 69, 273 P.2d 188, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1954).

Applied in

State ex rel. Fawcett v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 69, 273 P.2d 188, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (1954).

Cited in

Baldwin v. Nickerson, 3 Wyo. 208, 19 P. 439, 1888 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (1888); Torrey v. Baldwin, 3 Wyo. 430, 26 P. 908, 1891 Wyo. LEXIS 2 (1891); In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (1898); State ex rel. Sullivan v. Schnitger, 16 Wyo. 479, 95 P. 698, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 35 (1908); Board of County Comm'rs v. Board of County Comm'rs, 17 Wyo. 424, 100 P. 659, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1909); Board of Comm'rs v. Woods, 18 Wyo. 316, 106 P. 923, 1910 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (1910); Dillman v. State ex rel. Merrill, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (1912); Board of Comm'rs v. Mulholland, 22 Wyo. 130, 136 P. 112, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (1913).

§ 18-1-102. Range line explanation.

The range lines between ranges eighty-nine (89) and ninety (90), west of the sixth principal meridian referred to in W.S. 18-1-101(d), (g), (o) and (u) relate to the public surveys and embrace such offsets and correction lines east or west as such surveys have established.

History.

Laws 1909, ch. 129, § 5; C.S. 1910, § 1040; C.S. 1920, § 1270; R.S. 1931, § 29-125; C.S. 1945, § 26-125; W.S. 1957, § 18-26; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Law reviews. —

See comment, “Settlement of County Boundary Disputes,” V Land & Water L. Rev. 467 (1970).

Article 2. County Seats

  • § 18-1-201.  County seats enumerated.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

56 Am. Jur. 2d Municipal Corporations, Counties, etc. §§ 44 to 49.

Withdrawal of name from petition for change of county seat, or revocation of withdrawal, and time therefor, 27 ALR2d 604.

20 C.J.S. Counties §§ 53 to 73.

§ 18-1-201. County seats enumerated.

  1. The county seats in the state of Wyoming are as follows:
    1. Albany county, at Laramie;
    2. Big Horn county, at Basin;
    3. Campbell county, at Gillette;
    4. Carbon county, at Rawlins;
    5. Converse county, at Douglas;
    6. Crook county, at Sundance;
    7. Fremont county, at Lander;
    8. Goshen county, at Torrington;
    9. Hot Springs county, at Thermopolis;
    10. Johnson county, at Buffalo;
    11. Laramie county, at Cheyenne;
    12. Lincoln county, at Kemmerer;
    13. Natrona county, at Casper;
    14. Niobrara county, at Lusk;
    15. Park county, at Cody;
    16. Platte county, at Wheatland;
    17. Sheridan county, at Sheridan;
    18. Sublette county, at Pinedale;
    19. Sweetwater county, at Green River;
    20. Teton county, at Jackson;
    21. Uinta county, at Evanston;
    22. Washakie county, at Worland;
    23. Weston county, at Newcastle.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 27, §§ 2, 3; ch. 107, § 1; Laws 1884, ch. 46, § 1; R.S. 1887, §§ 658, 660, 663, 666, 668; 1899, § 980; C.S. 1910, § 1022; C.S. 1920, § 1248; Laws 1931, ch. 73, § 14; R.S. 1931, § 29-101; C.S. 1945, § 26-101; W.S. 1957, § 18-1; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

For constitutional provision as to changing county seats, see art. 12, § 3, Wyo. Const.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Article 3. Organization of New Counties

  • § 18-1-301.  Organization of new counties.
  • § 18-1-302.  Petition for organization.
  • § 18-1-303.  Assessed valuation and population requirements of proposed and residual counties.
  • § 18-1-304.  Appointment of commissioners.
  • § 18-1-305.  Meeting of commissioners; oath.
  • § 18-1-306.  Commissioners to appoint clerk; oath of clerk; calling election.
  • § 18-1-307.  Expenses of special election borne by new county; salary of clerk and commissioners.
  • § 18-1-308.  Election of officers.
  • § 18-1-309.  Duties of commissioners and clerk.
  • § 18-1-310.  When officers to qualify; when county organized.
  • § 18-1-311.  Approval of bonds of commissioners.
  • § 18-1-312.  Payment of expenses in organization of new county.
  • § 18-1-313.  Assessment of property in new counties.
  • § 18-1-314.  Taxes for new counties.
  • § 18-1-315.  Indebtedness to be apportioned upon division of county.
  • § 18-1-316.  Method of ascertaining indebtedness; rule of apportionment.
  • § 18-1-317.  Commissioners to report indebtedness to district court.
  • § 18-1-318.  Notice of hearing on report.
  • § 18-1-319.  Apportionment by court; order for payment by new county; lien upon property of new county.
  • § 18-1-320.  New county to issue warrants in payment; tax levy.

Cross references. —

As to effect of county division in connection with payment of bonds, see § 18-4-310.

As to effect of county division on payment and redemption of county funding bonds, see § 18-4-505.

For constitutional provision relative to organization of new counties, see art. 12, § 2, Wyo. Const.

As to changing county seats, see art. 12, § 3, Wyo. Const.

As to selection of jurors in new counties, see § 1-11-128.

As to notaries public receiving new commission upon application to governor on formation of new counties, see § 32-1-101.

§ 18-1-301. Organization of new counties.

New counties may be organized as provided by W.S. 18-1-302 through 18-1-320.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1002; C.S. 1910, § 1049; C.S. 1920, § 1279; R.S. 1931, § 29-201; C.S. 1945, § 26-201; W.S. 1957, § 18-27; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Population requirement. —

Big Horn county not being organized before adoption of the constitution, it was necessary to meet the statutory requirement as to population before organizing. Board of Comm'rs v. Perkins, 5 Wyo. 166, 38 P. 915, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1895).

Commissioners' powers and duties. —

Commissioners and their clerks appointed to organize a county, and perform all the duties preparatory to, respecting, or incident to election of the first county officers, though public officers, and required to take the oaths of commissioners and clerk, do not hold such offices, and are not entitled to the compensation provided for county officers but have authority to purchase election supplies at the expense of the county. Taylor v. Board of Comm'rs, 11 Wyo. 106, 70 P. 835, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1902).

Constitutional. —

This article is in the nature of an enabling act and, though inappropriate as to the organization of a new county for failing to provide, as required by art. 12, § 2, Wyo. Const., for the submission of the question to the electors, is not repugnant to the constitution, but is constitutional as far as it goes. Board of Comm'rs v. Woods, 18 Wyo. 316, 106 P. 923, 1910 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 18 Wyo. 316, 107 P. 753, 1910 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1910).

Application of general laws before organization. —

The provision of Laws 1911 creating the county of Platte (§ 18-1-101) and similar acts creating other new counties, to the effect that until the new county shall have selected officers as provided by law, and the same shall have duly qualified as such, all such portions of said county, as at the time of the passage of the act constituted a part of another county for judicial, revenue and elective purposes, shall be attached to said parent county, except as otherwise in the act provided, did not prevent the operation of the general law for organizing new counties as to the duties imposed thereby upon the organization commissioners and their clerk, with reference to conducting the next general election after the appointment of said commissioners. The effect of said provision in the act creating the new county was merely to continue the new county as a part of the original county or counties until its organization for election purposes, as to such elections only conducted by the old county that would necessarily be participated in by the electors within the territory of the new county if no provision had been made for the creation of such new county, and, hence, the provisions of the general law for the organization of new counties applies to any election pertaining to the pending or proposed organization of the new county, occurring after the appointment of the commissioners to organize the same. Dillman v. State, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1912).

Commissioners to act until county organized. —

The powers and duties imposed upon commissioners appointed to organize an unorganized county, with reference to the holding of elections in such county, by the general law for organizing new counties, do not cease until the county is organized, where a special election has been held in the territory proposed to be cut off on the question of division and the vote has been in favor of division. Dillman v. State, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1912).

Valid legislative power. —

Sections 18-1-301 to 18-1-303 are a valid exercise of legislative power to provide by general law for the organization of new counties, under art. 12, § 2, Wyo. Const.Budge v. Board of Comm'rs, 29 Wyo. 35, 208 P. 874, 1922 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1922).

Legislative, administrative functions. —

The formation of a county is a legislative function, and may be done by special act; but the organization of a county is an administrative function effected with the consent of the people of the formed county by administrative or executive officers acting under a general law. State ex rel. Budge v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 287, 219 P. 735, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1923).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

56 Am. Jur. 2d Municipal Corporations, Counties, etc. §§ 28 to 49.

20 C.J.S. Counties § 5.

§ 18-1-302. Petition for organization.

Whenever at least three hundred (300) qualified electors who are property owners desire to organize a new county for the purpose of establishing a county government, they may petition the governor to appoint three (3) electors residing within the boundaries of the proposed new county to act as commissioners in organizing the new county. Attached to the petition shall be affidavits of at least two (2) qualified electors residing within the boundaries of the proposed new county stating that the petitioners are qualified electors and property owners residing within the boundaries of the proposed new county and that the requirements of W.S. 18-1-303(a) and (b) have been met.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 1003; C.S. 1910, § 1050; C.S. 1920, § 1280; R.S. 1931, § 29-202; C.S. 1945, § 26-202; W.S. 1957, § 18-28; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Specific counties. —

When Campbell county was carved out of Crook and Weston counties it was provided that, until it should have organized and elected county officers, all portions of Campbell county should belong to and be a part of Crook and Weston counties for revenue and other purposes, that portion of Campbell county lying within Crook county must, until the board of supervisors was duly elected and qualified, be considered as a part of Crook county in determining the status of that county, according to the assessed valuation of the property therein. Board of Comm'rs v. Mulholland, 22 Wyo. 130, 136 P. 112, 1913 Wyo. LEXIS 41 (Wyo. 1913).

Curative statute. —

Curative statute legalizing defective organization of Teton county was not invalid as special act organizing county or regulating its affairs or interfering with uniform operation of general laws. State ex rel. Budge v. Snyder, 30 Wyo. 287, 219 P. 735, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 45 (Wyo. 1923).

Cited in

Taylor v. Board of Comm'rs, 11 Wyo. 106, 70 P. 835, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (1902); Dillman v. State ex rel. Merrill, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (1912); Budge v. Board of Comm'rs, 29 Wyo. 35, 208 P. 874, 1922 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (1922).

§ 18-1-303. Assessed valuation and population requirements of proposed and residual counties.

  1. No new county shall be organized unless it:
    1. Contains a population of at least three thousand (3,000) persons; and
    2. Contains taxable property of at least seven million dollars ($7,000,000.00) as shown in the last assessment.
  2. In addition to the requirements of subsection (a) of this section the county or counties from which the proposed new county is to be formed shall each contain, after the new county is organized:
    1. A population of at least five thousand (5,000) persons; and
    2. Taxable property of at least nine million dollars ($9,000,000.00) as shown in the last assessment.
  3. The governor may require further evidence of population and assessed value of the proposed new county and the county or counties from which the proposed new county is to be formed.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 3; 1895, ch. 81, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1004; C.S. 1910, § 1051; Laws 1917, ch. 58, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 1281; Laws 1929, ch. 69, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 29-203; C.S. 1945, § 26-203; W.S. 1957, § 18-29; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Curative statute. —

Organization of Teton county without regard to provisions of this section as to population and assessed valuation of property, having been validated by curative act and recognized by other enactments, was not invalid. State ex rel. Budge v. Snyder, 31 Wyo. 333, 225 P. 1102, 1924 Wyo. LEXIS 28 (Wyo. 1924).

§ 18-1-304. Appointment of commissioners.

After the governor has received the petition specified in W.S. 18-1-302 and is satisfied the requirements provided for in W.S. 18-1-303 have been met he shall appoint the persons named in the petition as commissioners to organize the county and shall notify them of their appointment. If any of the commissioners die, resign or refuse to act the governor may appoint another.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 4; R.S. 1899, § 1005; C.S. 1910, § 1052; Laws 1917, ch. 58, § 2; C.S. 1920, § 1282; Laws 1929, ch. 69, § 2; R.S. 1931, § 29-204; C.S. 1945, § 26-204; W.S. 1957, § 18-30; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-305. Meeting of commissioners; oath.

The commissioners shall as soon as practicable after receiving notice of their appointment meet at a suitable place within the proposed new county and each commissioner shall take and subscribe before any officer authorized to administer oaths an oath that he will faithfully and impartially discharge the duties of his office as prescribed by law and also the oath required of county commissioners.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 5; R.S. 1899, § 1006; C.S. 1910, § 1053; C.S. 1920, § 1283; R.S. 1931, § 29-205; C.S. 1945, § 26-205; W.S. 1957, § 18-31; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to oath of office generally, see art. 6, § 20, Wyo. Const.

As to officers authorized to administer oaths, see § 1-2-102.

§ 18-1-306. Commissioners to appoint clerk; oath of clerk; calling election.

  1. The appointed commissioners shall:
    1. Appoint a clerk who shall take an oath that he will faithfully and impartially discharge the duties of his office as prescribed by law and shall also take the oath required of a county clerk;
    2. Designate a place for the transaction of their official duties;
    3. Call for an election for the purpose of having the qualified electors of the proposed new county decide:
      1. If the proposed new county should be organized; and
      2. The location of the county seat of the proposed new county.
  2. The election may be held on an election date authorized under W.S. 22-21-103 or another date specified by the appointed commissioners.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 5; R.S. 1899, § 1007; Laws 1909, ch. 75, § 1; C.S. 1910, § 1054; C.S. 1920, § 1284; R.S. 1931, § 29-206; C.S. 1945, § 26-206; W.S. 1957, § 18-32; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1996, ch. 97, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to elections generally, see title 22.

Duties of commissioners. —

It is the duty of the commissioners appointed to organize a county and their clerk to perform all the duties imposed by law upon county commissioners and county clerks, respectively, preparatory to, respecting, or incident to the next general election occurring after the appointment of said commissioners, where a special election has been called and held prior to said general election for the purpose of submitting to the qualified electors of the proposed new county the question of division, and the vote has been in favor of division. Dillman v. State, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1912).

§ 18-1-307. Expenses of special election borne by new county; salary of clerk and commissioners.

The expenses for the special election provided by W.S. 18-1-306(a)(iii) shall be borne by the proposed new county and the county commissioners of the county or counties from which the new county is to be formed may impose a special levy upon the taxable property within the boundaries of the proposed new county to pay for the expenses of the election and to pay the salaries of the appointed commissioners and clerk. The appointed commissioners and clerk in the proposed new county shall each receive a salary of fifty dollars ($50.00).

History.

Laws 1909, ch. 75, § 2; C.S. 1910, § 1055; C.S. 1920, § 1285; R.S. 1931, § 29-207; C.S. 1945, § 26-207; W.S. 1957, § 18-33; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-308. Election of officers.

If a majority of the qualified electors residing in the proposed new county vote for the organization, the new county is organized. At the next general election, or if the special election is held in conjunction with a general election, the qualified electors residing in the proposed new county shall vote for county and precinct officers as provided by law.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 6; R.S. 1899, § 1008; Laws 1909, ch. 75, § 3; C.S. 1910, § 1056; C.S. 1920, § 1286; R.S. 1931, § 29-208; C.S. 1945, § 26-208; W.S. 1957, § 18-34; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Completion of organization. —

A county will not be fully organized until its officers, at least its county commissioners, are elected. Dillman v. State, 20 Wyo. 404, 125 P. 367, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 46 (Wyo. 1912).

§ 18-1-309. Duties of commissioners and clerk.

The appointed commissioners and clerk shall perform the duties incident to such election as are imposed by law upon county commissioners and county clerks in organized counties except that the returns shall be canvassed and the result declared by the appointed commissioners.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 7; R.S. 1899, § 1009; C.S. 1910, § 1057; C.S. 1920, § 1287; R.S. 1931, § 29-209; C.S. 1945, § 26-209; W.S. 1957, § 18-35; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

For general powers of board of county commissioners, see § 18-3-504.

For general duties of county clerks, see § 18-3-402.

As to elections generally and as to duties of officers with reference thereto, see title 22.

§ 18-1-310. When officers to qualify; when county organized.

On the first Monday of January following the election or as soon thereafter as possible, the county and precinct officers elected in the new county shall qualify and enter upon their respective duties. When at least two (2) county commissioners elected have qualified and entered upon their duties the county is organized and is vested with all the powers of an organized county.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 8; R.S. 1899, § 1010; C.S. 1910, § 1058; C.S. 1920, § 1288; R.S. 1931, § 29-210; C.S. 1945, § 26-210; W.S. 1957, § 18-36; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-311. Approval of bonds of commissioners.

The commissioners appointed by the governor shall approve the bonds of the first county commissioners elected.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 59, § 9; R.S. 1899, § 1011; C.S. 1920, § 1289; R.S. 1931, § 29-211; C.S. 1945, § 26-211; W.S. 1957, § 18-37; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Repealing clauses. —

Section 11, ch. 59, Laws 1895, reads: “Sections two and three of an act, entitled, ‘An act to provide for the creation of Big Horn county, in Wyoming Territory, and to amend and re-enact sections forty-eight (48) and forty-nine (49) of chapter ninety (90), of the Session Laws of Wyoming Territory, of eighteen hundred and eighty-eight (1888) and for other purposes,’ approved March 12, 1890; and sections forty-seven (47) to and including section fifty-eight (58), of an act entitled ‘An act making divers appropriations and for other purpose,’ passed by the tenth legislative assembly of the Territory of Wyoming, notwithstanding the objections of the governor, are hereby repealed.” Approved February 16, 1895.

§ 18-1-312. Payment of expenses in organization of new county.

Expenses incurred in the organization of the new county and expenses incurred on behalf of the new county before the elected county commissioners assume office shall be audited and paid by the board of commissioners of the new county in the same manner as expenses incurred after organization.

History.

Laws 1911, ch. 39, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 1291; R.S. 1931, § 29-213; C.S. 1945, § 26-213; W.S. 1957, § 18-39; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-313. Assessment of property in new counties.

If a new county is organized after the first Monday in January and before the following fourth Monday in May, the deputy county assessors appointed in the original county or counties for districts included in the new county shall be ex officio deputy assessors for the new county and, with the county assessor of the new county, shall assess and return the value of the taxable property to the new county. The department of revenue shall assess all property within the new county authorized by law to be assessed by the department, and shall return and certify the same to the new county.

History.

Laws 1911, ch. 81, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 1292; R.S. 1931, § 29-214; C.S. 1945, § 26-214; W.S. 1957, § 18-40; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1991, ch. 174, § 2.

§ 18-1-314. Taxes for new counties.

If a new county is organized after the fourth Monday in May and before the following first Monday in January the taxes levied and collected from property within the new county for that year shall be paid by the county treasurer of the original county to the county treasurer of the new county.

History.

Laws 1911, ch. 81, § 2; C.S. 1920, § 1293; R.S. 1931, § 29-215; C.S. 1945, § 26-215; W.S. 1957, § 18-41; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-315. Indebtedness to be apportioned upon division of county.

Any newly organized county is liable for the payment of an equitable proportion of the indebtedness existing at the time of organization of any counties from which the newly organized county is formed.

History.

Laws 1877, p. 54, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 678; R.S. 1899, § 1013; C.S. 1910, § 1061; C.S. 1920, § 1294; R.S. 1931, § 29-601; C.S. 1945, § 26-216; W.S. 1957, § 18-42; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

In general. —

Taxes due from the parent county to the state are debts; assets include delinquent taxes levied for state purposes. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Adoption of constitution. —

Adoption of constitution did not by implication repeal this and other sections in this article. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Claims against original county. —

Claims which existed as valid debts of the original county on the date of the organization of the new county, although not reduced to judgment until after that date, were properly included as part of the indebtedness of the original county for apportionment. Board of Comm'rs v. Board of Comm'rs, 25 Wyo. 172, 166 P. 674, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1917).

Delayed court order. —

In view of provision requiring commissioners of original county to state in their report the date when outstanding indebtedness became due, and that court upon finding amount to be charged the new county shall order its commissioners to issue warrants payable to the original county at a time not later than the time when the indebtedness shall become due, the action of the court in ordering a warrant payable to the new county at a time later than that when such indebtedness would become due is not prejudicial to the new county. Board of Comm'rs v. Board of Comm'rs, 25 Wyo. 172, 166 P. 674, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1917).

Delinquent taxes. —

In apportioning debts and assets between a parent county and one formed out of it, delinquent taxes should be computed as assets at their value only, and not at the aggregate amount on the rolls. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Where a new county is formed out of parts of other counties, delinquent general taxes due from persons and property therein continue enforceable by the parent county; hence, in apportioning the debts and assets between the old and the new counties, such taxes are to be treated as assets. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Determination of amount. —

The report of the commissioners of the parent county as to assets and debts is not conclusive, but the court may determine their amount. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Judgments. —

Judgments against the parent county must be considered as debts in making apportionment. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Jurisdiction of courts. —

The jurisdiction of courts in apportionment proceedings being derived from the provisions of this article only, they have no power to determine the validity of the indebtedness to be apportioned. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

New county, commissioners' duties. —

The provisions of this article do not require the commissioners of a new county to issue warrants against any particular taxes, or against the tax of any particular year. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Value of taxes due. —

Where court found value of taxes due to original county to be much in excess of that reported by the old county and estimated by witnesses, the finding will not be disturbed because the witnesses improperly based their estimated value upon the probable cost of collection. Board of Comm'rs v. Board of Comm'rs, 25 Wyo. 172, 166 P. 674, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1917).

§ 18-1-316. Method of ascertaining indebtedness; rule of apportionment.

  1. When any new county is organized the county commissioners of the counties from which the new county is formed shall:
    1. Determine the amount of county indebtedness existing at the time of the division;
    2. Determine the total assessed value of the property of both the original and newly organized counties.
  2. The proportion of indebtedness for which the new county is liable shall be determined by dividing the assessed value of the new county by the assessed value of the original county before the division. The assessed value figures will be taken from the assessment made before the division.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 32, § 1; 1886, ch. 36, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 679; Laws 1888, ch. 7, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1014; C.S. 1910, § 1062; C.S. 1920, § 1295; R.S. 1931, § 29-602; C.S. 1945, § 26-217; W.S. 1957, § 18-43; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-317. Commissioners to report indebtedness to district court.

  1. The county commissioners shall immediately report to the district court within which the new county is located:
    1. The amount, type, interest rate and date payable of the indebtedness of each county from which the new county is formed;
    2. The assessed value of the property of both the new and original counties;
    3. The kind, value and location of all public property of the original county;
    4. All monies and credits of the original county.
  2. The report shall be verified by the affidavit of the chairman of the respective boards of county commissioners, and shall be accompanied with proof of the organization and description of the new county’s boundaries.
  3. If the new county has no district court, the report specified in subsection (a) of this section shall be filed in a district court adjoining the new county.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 32, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 680; R.S. 1899, § 1015; C.S. 1910, § 1063; C.S. 1920, § 1296; R.S. 1931, § 29-603; C.S. 1945, § 26-218; W.S. 1957, § 18-44; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Construction. —

“Immediately” as used in this section means “as soon as practicable.” Board of Comm'rs v. Board of Comm'rs, 25 Wyo. 172, 166 P. 674, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1917).

§ 18-1-318. Notice of hearing on report.

  1. The court to which the report is made shall immediately notify the chairman of the board of county commissioners of the new county of the time and place when the report will be heard and considered by the court.
  2. All counties interested in the report shall have an opportunity to be heard and the hearing may be adjourned from time to time at the discretion of the court.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 32, § 3; R.S. 1887, § 681; R.S. 1899, § 1016; C.S. 1910, § 1064; C.S. 1920, § 1297; R.S. 1931, § 29-604; C.S. 1945, § 26-219; W.S. 1957, § 18-45; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-319. Apportionment by court; order for payment by new county; lien upon property of new county.

The court to which the report is made shall determine the proportion of the existing indebtedness which the new county shall bear under the provisions of W.S. 18-1-316 after deducting the new county’s proportionate share of the value of the public property, money and credits of the original county. The court, if any of the public property is located within the limits of the new county, may apportion its value to the new county, and shall order the board of county commissioners of the new county to issue warrants in the amount of their proportionate share payable to the original county when the new county’s proportionate share of the indebtedness and interest is due. The proportion of indebtedness of the new county is a lien upon the taxable property of the new county.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 32, § 4; R.S. 1887, § 682; R.S. 1899, § 1017; C.S. 1910, § 1065; C.S. 1920, § 1298; R.S. 1931, § 26-605; C.S. 1945, § 26-220; W.S. 1957, § 18-46; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-320. New county to issue warrants in payment; tax levy.

  1. Upon receiving the order of the court pursuant to W.S. 18-1-319 the board of county commissioners of the new county shall issue and deliver warrants to the commissioners of the original county or counties.
  2. Each year the board of county commissioners of the new county shall levy a sufficient tax upon all the taxable property in the county to pay its proportionate share of the indebtedness.

History.

Laws 1882, ch. 32, § 5; R.S. 1887, § 683; R.S. 1899, § 1018; C.S. 1910, § 1066; C.S. 1920, § 1299; R.S. 1931, § 29-606; C.S. 1945, § 26-221; W.S. 1957, § 18-47; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Article 4. Proceedings in Boundary Disputes

  • § 18-1-401.  Commissioners to order surveyor of their respective counties to make survey.
  • § 18-1-402.  Duty of surveyors in making survey; joint report; findings conclusive if in agreement.
  • § 18-1-403.  Reports of county surveyors to be separate when they disagree.
  • § 18-1-404.  Application to court for settlement when surveyors disagree; filing and notice of filing; court jurisdiction.
  • § 18-1-405.  Court to appoint surveyor; filing of surveyor's report; action upon report; appeal.
  • § 18-1-406.  Application to court upon refusal to survey; action taken by court.
  • § 18-1-407.  Expenses and costs to be paid jointly.

Cross references. —

As to county boundaries generally, see § 18-1-101.

Law reviews. —

See comment, “Settlement of County Boundary Disputes,” V Land & Water L. Rev. 467 (1970).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

56 Am. Jur. 2d Municipal Corporations, Counties, etc. §§ 39 to 43; 12 Am. Jur. 2d Boundaries § 1 et seq.

20 C.J.S. Counties §§ 13 to 18.

§ 18-1-401. Commissioners to order surveyor of their respective counties to make survey.

Whenever a dispute arises between two (2) adjoining counties as to the location of the boundary line between them each board of county commissioners shall order their county surveyor to survey the disputed boundary line with the county surveyor of the other county at a time agreed upon by each board of county commissioners.

History.

Laws 1886, ch. 87, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 670; 1899 § 994; C.S. 1910, § 1041; C.S. 1920, § 1271; R.S. 1931, § 29-501; C.S. 1945, § 26-501; W.S. 1957, § 18-331; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

Section 1, ch. 87, Laws 1886, contained a proviso clause relative to the boundary line between Crook and Johnson counties. It has not been carried since 1899.

Boundary to be established by survey. —

A proceeding, under this article, by one county to determine the boundary line between it and the adjoining county, is a proceeding to locate the line as designated by the law creating the counties, and that line must be established by the survey to be made in the proceeding. Board of Comm'rs v. Board of Comm'rs, 17 Wyo. 424, 100 P. 659, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1909).

§ 18-1-402. Duty of surveyors in making survey; joint report; findings conclusive if in agreement.

  1. The county surveyors shall:
    1. Mark the boundary line as located by them by placing or erecting at the end of each mile an easily discernible and durable monument upon which will be designated the point which it represents or locates;
    2. Make a joint report of the boundary line agreed upon, attaching maps which show the location of the boundary line and all monuments placed or erected on the line.
  2. The report shall be signed and sworn to by each surveyor and one (1) copy shall be filed with the county clerk of each county. The line agreed on by the county surveyors is located and binding upon both counties.

History.

Laws 1886, ch. 87, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 671; 1899, § 995; C.S. 1910, § 1042; 1920, § 1272; R.S. 1931, § 29-502; C.S. 1945, § 26-502; W.S. 1957, § 18-332; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-403. Reports of county surveyors to be separate when they disagree.

If the county surveyors do not agree in the location of the boundary line after making the survey provided by W.S. 18-1-402 they shall each make separate reports on the portion of the line upon which they do not agree, attaching maps showing the location of all monuments placed or erected on the line. One (1) report shall be filed with each county clerk.

History.

Laws 1886, ch. 87, § 3; R.S. 1887, § 672; 1899, § 996; C.S. 1910, § 1043; C.S. 1920, § 1273; R.S. 1931, § 29-503; C.S. 1945, § 26-503; W.S. 1957, § 18-333; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Board of County Comm'rs, 17 Wyo. 424, 100 P. 659, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1909).

§ 18-1-404. Application to court for settlement when surveyors disagree; filing and notice of filing; court jurisdiction.

  1. After the reports provided by W.S. 18-1-403 have been filed the county commissioners of either county may apply to the district court within their county for a hearing, describing the previous proceedings and attaching a certified copy of all records and reports which have been filed with the county clerk.
  2. The application for a hearing shall be entitled “in the matter of disputed boundary line between  . . . . .  and  . . . . .  counties.” Upon receiving the application the clerk of court shall file and docket it and immediately notify the county clerk of the other county by registered mail of the filing and docketing and shall include a copy of the application. This notice is sufficient to establish the pendency of the matter.
  3. When the requirements of this section have been met the district court has acquired jurisdiction and shall exclude the jurisdiction of any other court.

History.

Laws 1886, ch. 87, §§ 4, 5; R.S. 1887, §§ 673, 674; 1899, §§ 997, 998; C.S. 1910, §§ 1044, 1045; C.S. 1920, §§ 1274, 1275; R.S. 1931, §§ 29-504, 29-505; C.S. 1945, §§ 26-504, 26-505; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-334, 18-335; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-1-405. Court to appoint surveyor; filing of surveyor's report; action upon report; appeal.

  1. Upon hearing the matter as provided by W.S. 18-1-404 and if the court is satisfied that all proceedings have been made pursuant to the provisions of W.S. 18-1-401 through 18-1-404 the court shall appoint a licensed surveyor who is not a resident of either interested county to survey the disputed boundary line. The court shall specify the time in which the survey is to be made.
  2. The surveyor shall take and subscribe an oath to faithfully and impartially make a survey, and after making the survey shall make a report in triplicate, one (1) copy to be filed with the court and the others to be filed with the county clerks of each county. The report will be signed and sworn to by the surveyor and will contain maps showing the location of the boundary line in the same manner as provided by W.S. 18-1-402.
  3. When the report has been filed with the court, the boundary line is fixed and designated as shown in the report, unless the court sets aside the survey and report for being insufficient or indefinite upon the application of either county if made within sixty (60) days after the report has been filed in the court.
  4. Any order of the court concerning the boundary line may be appealed to the supreme court, but the boundary line is conclusive until set aside. In the event the order is set aside, another surveyor may be appointed as provided by this section.

History.

Laws 1886, ch. 87, § 6; R.S. 1887, § 675; 1899, § 999; C.S. 1910, § 1046; C.S. 1920, § 1276; R.S. 1931, § 29-506; C.S. 1945, § 26-506; W.S. 1957, § 18-336; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Board of County Comm'rs, 17 Wyo. 424, 100 P. 659, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1909).

§ 18-1-406. Application to court upon refusal to survey; action taken by court.

  1. If a county involved in a boundary dispute fails to act as provided by W.S. 18-1-401 or if the boards of county commissioners cannot agree on a time for making a survey, the commissioners of the county wanting the dispute settled may apply to the district court in their county as provided by W.S. 18-1-404, stating the circumstances of the dispute and the reasons why the dispute has not been settled.
  2. The district court shall decide the dispute as provided by W.S. 18-1-404 and 18-1-405.

History.

Laws 1886, § 7; R.S. 1887, § 676; 1899, § 1000; C.S. 1910, § 1047; C.S. 1920, § 1277; R.S. 1931, § 29-507; C.S. 1945, § 26-507; W.S. 1957, § 18-337; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Board of County Comm'rs, 17 Wyo. 424, 100 P. 659, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1909).

§ 18-1-407. Expenses and costs to be paid jointly.

The expenses of the costs of the surveys and court proceedings provided by W.S. 18-1-401 through 18-1-406 shall be paid equally by the counties involved in the dispute.

History.

Laws 1886, ch. 87, § 8; R.S. 1887, § 677; 1899, § 1001; C.S. 1910, § 1048; C.S. 1920, § 1278; R.S. 1931, § 29-508; C.S. 1945, § 26-508; W.S. 1957, § 18-338; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Chapter 2 Corporate Powers and Duties

  • § 18-2-101.  General powers.
  • § 18-2-102.  Property.
  • § 18-2-103.  Buildings generally; infrastructure for court information technology.
  • § 18-2-104.  Joint city and county buildings.
  • § 18-2-105.  County, city or local housing authority; authority to establish senior citizen center; receiving state and federal monies; contracting for services.
  • § 18-2-106.  Senior citizen advisory commission.
  • § 18-2-107.  Cooperation with other agencies for funding and operation of senior citizen centers.
  • § 18-2-108.  Joint establishment, operation, contracts and agreements of facilities by local governments; sharing of costs; issuance of bonds; limitation on expenditures.
  • § 18-2-109.  Name in which county shall sue or be sued.
  • § 18-2-110.  Commissioners to receive service of process and employ attorney in behalf of counties.
  • § 18-2-111.  Judgment against county to be paid by tax levy; when execution to issue.
  • § 18-2-112.  Contracts for human services.
  • § 18-2-113.  Prohibition of towing by a county.
  • § 18-2-114.  Prohibitions; amateur radio antenna regulation.
  • § 18-2-115.  Nuisance abatement; procedures.
  • § 18-2-116.  County prohibitions on utility connections.

Cross references. —

As to powers of county officers generally, see chapter 3 of this title.

As to authority of state, counties and municipal corporations to acquire by condemnation proceedings, see §§ 1-26-501 through 1-26-817.

As to actions by or against state agency or political subdivision, see §§ 1-35-101 through 1-35-108.

As to county tax levies and limitation on amount, see § 21-13-102.

As to general county school tax, see § 21-13-201.

As to establishment, vacation or alteration of county highways, see §§ 24-3-101 to 24-3-127.

As to powers and limitations upon local authorities with reference to regulation of motor vehicles, see title 31.

Law reviews. —

See article, “Governmental Immunity from Damage Actions in Wyoming — Part II,” VII Land & Water L. Rev. 617 (1972).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

56 Am. Jur. 2d Municipal Corporations, Counties, etc. §§ 193 to 230.

Power of governing body of county to dispose of county real estate in absence of specific statutory authority, 21 ALR2d 722.

Operation of garage for maintenance and repair of municipal vehicles as governmental function, 26 ALR2d 944.

Power of county to sell, lease or mortgage public utility plant or interest therein, 61 ALR2d 595.

Recovery of exemplary or punitive damages from municipal corporation, 1 ALR4th 448.

20 C.J.S. Counties §§ 45 to 62.

§ 18-2-101. General powers.

  1. Each organized county in the state is a body corporate and politic. The powers of the county shall be exercised by a board of county commissioners which may:
    1. Sue and be sued;
    2. Purchase property for the use of the county and acquire real property at tax sales, as provided by law;
    3. Sell or convey property owned by the county, when it is in the best interests of the county;
    4. Make contracts and perform other acts relating to the property and concerns of the county in the exercise of its corporate or administrative powers;
    5. Exercise other powers as provided by law;
    6. Establish a surface water drainage system, utilities and drainage management; and
    7. Repealed by Laws 1999, ch. 22, § 2.
    8. Declare and abate nuisances which the commission determines to be a threat to health or safety as provided in W.S. 18-2-115. No person shall create, continue or permit nuisances to exist in violation of a final order issued pursuant to W.S. 18-2-115. Any resolution passed by a board of county commissioners pursuant to this paragraph is enforceable, in addition to other remedies provided by law, by injunction, mandamus or abatement. Whoever fails to comply with a final order shall be assessed a civil penalty of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day for each day the violation continues. No resolution issued pursuant to this paragraph shall regulate any permitted industrial facility or oil and gas or mining operations necessary to the extraction, production or exploration of the mineral resources. Nothing in this paragraph shall be construed to impair or modify any rights afforded to farm or ranch operations pursuant to the Wyoming Right to Farm and Ranch Act.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 1791; R.S. 1899, § 1073; C.S. 1910, § 1067; C.S. 1920, § 1300; R.S. 1931, § 29-301; C.S. 1945, § 26-301; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-48, 18-50; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1995, ch. 118, § 2; 1998, ch. 84, § 1; 1999, ch. 22, § 2; 2008, ch. 81, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to county cooperation in extension work in agriculture and home economics, see § 21-17-305.

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, inserted (a)(viii) and made a related stylistic change.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

In general. —

County has authority to make contracts, and do all other acts in relation to the property and concerns of the county necessary to the exercise of its corporate or administrative powers. Appel v. State, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1900).

Governmental functions defined. —

Governmental functions are those conferred or imposed on the county as a local agency of limited and prescribed jurisdiction, to be employed in administering the affairs of the state, and promoting the public welfare generally. Bondurant v. Board of Trustees, 354 P.2d 219, 1960 Wyo. LEXIS 63 (Wyo. 1960), citing War Memorial Hosp. of Dist. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 371, 279 P.2d 472, 1955 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1955).

The provisions of this section would seem to apply to property acquired by tax sale. Probasco v. Sikes, 77 Wyo. 108, 307 P.2d 817, 1957 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1957).

Conveyance of land. —

It is for the board of commissioners in the exercise of its discretion, in good faith, to determine whether it shall convey for a site for a federal building, as unnecessary for the purposes of the county, part of a tract of land owned by the county, on another part of which the county buildings are located. Collins v. Board of Comm'rs, 20 Wyo. 517, 126 P. 465, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (Wyo. 1912).

Implied contract, nonapplicability. —

County is not liable on theory of implied contract for benefits received, to contractor who constructed road upon oral authorization from individual members of board of county commissioners when same was not a county road. George W. Condon Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 56 Wyo. 38, 103 P.2d 401, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1940).

County road, implied establishment. —

County road cannot be established by implication through construction thereof under invalid agreement with members of board of county commissioners, individually, when road was not of statutory width and on completion was not taken over by commissioners. George W. Condon Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 56 Wyo. 38, 103 P.2d 401, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1940).

Private roads. —

The board of county commissioners has no authority to take charge and control of a private road on behalf of the county since its powers are limited to duly established county roads. George W. Condon Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 56 Wyo. 38, 103 P.2d 401, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1940).

Notices of tax sales. —

Treasurer may publish notice of sale of real property for delinquent taxes in any newspaper he may select and the county is liable for the expense thereof. Albany County v. Chaplin, 5 Wyo. 74, 37 P. 370, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1894).

Applied in

Haddenham v. Board of County Comm'rs, 679 P.2d 429, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 276 (1984); Martens v. Johnson County Bd. of Comm'rs, 954 P.2d 375, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1998).

Cited in

Collins v. Board of County Comm'rs, 20 Wyo. 517, 126 P. 465, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (1912); Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Geringer, 297 F.3d 1108, 2002 U.S. App. LEXIS 15353 (10th Cir. 2002); Western Wyo. Constr. Co. v. Bd. of County Comm'rs of Sublette, 2015 WY 77, 2015 Wyo. LEXIS 86 (May 27, 2015).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Wyoming's Local Governments and the Quality of Growth — A Preliminary Discussion,” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 491 (1979).

§ 18-2-102. Property.

Any property conveyed to a county, is the property of the county.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 1792; R.S. 1899, § 1074; C.S. 1910, § 1069; C.S. 1920, § 1302; R.S. 1931, § 29-303; C.S. 1945, § 26-302; W.S. 1957, § 18-49; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Disallowance of claims. —

Where county commissioners contracted with attorneys to defend county in court actions and issued certificates of indebtedness, which were registered and assigned by payees for value, but later passed resolution that attorneys had not rendered service, cancelled certificates and ordered treasurer not to pay them, allowance of claim and issuance of certificates did not preclude county contesting claim, as certificates are merely orders on the treasurer to pay when funds available, and may be revoked and payment stopped if later a defense develops which justifies recision of contract, whereupon treasurer in mandamus action may plead the resolution and order of commissioners as his defense. State ex rel. Robertson Inv. Co. v. Patterson, 47 Wyo. 416, 38 P.2d 617, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 1934).

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Chaplin, 5 Wyo. 74, 37 P. 370, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (1894); Collins v. Board of County Comm'rs, 20 Wyo. 517, 126 P. 465, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 51 (1912).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Power of governing body of county to dispose of county real estate in absence of specific statutory authority, 21 ALR2d 722.

Power of county as to lease or sublease of property owned or leased by it, 47 ALR3d 19.

§ 18-2-103. Buildings generally; infrastructure for court information technology.

  1. Each county shall provide and maintain a suitable courthouse, jail and other necessary county buildings.
  2. Each county shall provide and maintain infrastructure to ensure the proper function of court information technology equipment including, but not limited to, requisite power outlets, network drops, audio and visual drops and associated wiring for connectivity of all endpoints and peripherals associated with court information technology equipment.
  3. For purposes of this section, “court information technology equipment” means as defined in W.S. 5-2-120 (d) (i).

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 4; R.S. 1887, §§ 1366, 1794; R.S. 1899, § 1025; C.S. 1910, § 1078; C.S. 1920, § 1311; R.S. 1931, § 29-401; C.S. 1945, § 26-304; W.S. 1957, § 18-51; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2018 ch. 18, § 1, effective March 9, 2018.

The 2018 amendment, added (b) and (c).

Laws 2018, ch. 18, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2018.

Cross references. —

As to county courthouses and jails generally, see chapter 6 of this title.

As to duty of sheriff as custodian of jail, see § 18-3-603.

As to county libraries generally, see ch. 7 of this title.

As to memorial hospitals, see ch. 8 of this title.

As to fairgrounds, airports, parks, pleasure grounds and recreational systems, see ch. 9 of this title.

§ 18-2-104. Joint city and county buildings.

  1. Any county and its county seat, acting through the board of county commissioners and the city or town council respectively may agree for the joint purchase or construction and use of:
    1. A building to be used as a county courthouse and city hall, to be known as a city and county building;
    2. A public auditorium, athletic fields, civic center or other community buildings, which may be designated as a memorial to the veterans of the United States of America as the board and council may determine.
  2. The county and its county seat shall each contribute to the cost of purchase or construction of any facility specified in subsection (a) of this section in such amounts as they agree.
  3. The county commissioners and the city or town council shall fix all details and control of construction, maintenance and management and the division of the expense of maintenance and management of facilities specified in subsection (a) of this section by agreement, and the agreement shall bind both parties until modified or rescinded by mutual agreement.
  4. All laws relative to raising funds and issuing bonds by counties, cities or towns for purchasing or constructing county courthouses and jails and city and town halls, respectively, are applicable for the facilities specified in subsection (a) of this section.

History.

Laws 1917, ch. 24, §§ 1 to 3; C.S. 1920, § 1332; R.S. 1931, § 29-420; C.S. 1945, § 26-419; Laws 1947, ch. 135, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 18-52; Laws 1963, ch. 148, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity of governmental borrowing or expenditure for purposes of acquiring, maintaining or improving stadium for use of professional athletic team, 67 ALR3d 1186.

§ 18-2-105. County, city or local housing authority; authority to establish senior citizen center; receiving state and federal monies; contracting for services.

A board of county commissioners, cities or local housing authorities designated by said counties or cities may establish and maintain senior citizen centers to provide transportation, information, recreation facilities and other services which will enable senior citizens to maintain their independence and to avoid institutionalization as long as possible. A board of county commissioners, cities or local housing authorities designated by said counties or cities may receive both state and federal monies for the establishment and maintenance of these facilities. A board of county commissioners, the mayor and council or the board of commissioners of a local housing authority may provide these services or contract with public or private organizations or individuals for the services.

History.

Laws 1977, ch. 90, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

Sections 18-48.3 to 18-48.5, W.S. 1957, which were enacted by § 1, ch. 90, Laws 1977, have been renumbered as §§ 18-2-105 to 18-2-107 and §§ 18-2-105 to 18-2-108, which were enacted by § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, have been redesignated as §§ 18-2-108 to 18-2-111, accordingly.

§ 18-2-106. Senior citizen advisory commission.

A board of county commissioners, the mayor and council or the board of commissioners of a local housing authority may appoint an advisory commission for senior citizens. The composition of the advisory commission, the appointment and terms of its members and provisions for its organization and procedures shall be determined by the board of county commissioners. A member may be removed for cause by the board of county commissioners or other appointing body. The board shall fill any vacancy by appointment for the unexpired term.

History.

Laws 1977, ch. 90, § 1.

§ 18-2-107. Cooperation with other agencies for funding and operation of senior citizen centers.

The county, city or local housing authority may cooperate with other agencies as provided in W.S. 16-1-101, for the operation and funding of senior citizen centers.

History.

Laws 1977, ch. 90, § 1; 2006, ch. 114, § 1.

The 2006 amendment, substituted “16-1-101” for “9-18.7.”

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 5, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 24, 2006.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2006, ch. 114, § 3, provides: “[A]ny other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

§ 18-2-108. Joint establishment, operation, contracts and agreements of facilities by local governments; sharing of costs; issuance of bonds; limitation on expenditures.

  1. Each county, municipality, school, hospital or other special district, or any two (2) or more of them may enter into contracts or agreements to jointly establish and operate recreation facilities, water, liquid or solid waste facilities, police protection agency facilities, fire protection agency facilities, transportation system facilities, public school facilities, airports, public health facilities, community college facilities, hospital and related medical facilities, courthouse, jail and administrative office facilities or any combination thereof, and public access roads to school, hospital or other special districts where not otherwise provided by law.
  2. Each county, municipality, school, hospital or other special district, or any two (2) or more of them may enter into contracts or agreements to jointly purchase, lease, construct and operate facilities and equipment used in joint operations permitted under this section and may issue their bonds for such purpose as provided by law.
  3. The costs of the joint operations and joint use of machinery and facilities specified in this section shall be shared among the contracting parties as determined by their governing boards but no cost shall be incurred nor monies expended by any contracting party which will be in excess of limits prescribed by law for expenditures by it.

History.

Laws 1967, ch. 101, §§ 1 to 4; 1975, ch. 172, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to memorial hospitals generally, see chapter 8 of this title.

As to fairgrounds, airports, parks, pleasure grounds and recreational systems, see chapter 9 of this title.

As to solid waste disposal districts, see chapter 11 of this title.

Editor's notes. —

See Editor's note to § 18-2-105.

§ 18-2-109. Name in which county shall sue or be sued.

In all suits or proceedings the county shall sue or be sued as the “board of county commissioners of the county of . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ,” but this shall not prevent county officers when authorized by law from suing in their name of office for the benefit of the county.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 5; R.S. 1887, § 1795; R.S. 1899, § 1076; C.S. 1910, § 1071; C.S. 1920, § 1304; R.S. 1931, § 29-305; C.S. 1945, § 26-305; W.S. 1957, § 18-53; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to actions by or against state, state agencies and political subdivisions generally, see §§ 1-35-101 through 1-35-108.

Corporate name. —

Notwithstanding the statutory provisions that counties may sue in their corporate name, actions must be brought by and against the board of commissioners of the county. Board Comm'rs Sweetwater County v. Young, 3 Wyo. 684, 29 P. 1002, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1892).

Disallowance of claims. —

Where county commissioners contracted with attorneys to defend county in court actions, allowed claim for retainer and issued certificates of indebtedness, but later passed resolution that attorneys had not rendered service, cancelled certificates and ordered treasurer not to pay them, allowance of claim and issuance of certificates did not preclude county from contesting the claim, as certificates are merely orders on the treasurer to pay when funds available and may be revoked and payment stopped if later a defense develops which justifies recision of contract. Treasurer in a mandamus action may plead the resolution and order of commissioners as his defense. State ex rel. Robertson Inv. Co. v. Patterson, 47 Wyo. 416, 38 P.2d 617, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 1934).

Variance. —

Where title of board was given incorrectly as “the board of commissioners of Natrona county,” instead of “the board of the county commissioners of the county of Natrona,” variance is too trivial to be noticed by court. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

Cited in

North Laramie Land Co. v. Hoffman, 28 Wyo. 183, 201 P. 1022, 1921 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (1921).

§ 18-2-110. Commissioners to receive service of process and employ attorney in behalf of counties.

In all legal proceedings against the county process shall be served on the board of county commissioners or any member thereof and they may in the absence of the county attorney employ an attorney to defend them, for which they may make an appropriation from the general county fund.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 6; R.S. 1887, § 1796; R.S. 1899, § 1078; C.S. 1910, § 1072; C.S. 1920, § 1305; R.S. 1931, § 29-306; C.S. 1945, § 26-306; W.S. 1957, § 18-54; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

See also § 18-3-302 as to employment of other attorneys by county. As to restrictions on employment of attorneys, see § 18-3-520.

Change in personnel. —

Where injunction was sought against board of county commissioners and members thereof, individually and as commissioners, and judgment was for defendants, and plaintiff brought error, it was no ground for dismissal of the proceedings in error that the membership of county commissioners had changed. North Laramie Land Co. v. Hoffman, 28 Wyo. 183, 201 P. 1022, 1921 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1921).

Facts govern. —

Where county commissioners had no personal interest in suits and action was not against them individually, commissioners had power as board representing county to employ private attorneys to defend actions and to pay them, assertion in pleadings that county was not sued being a mere conclusion. The facts govern. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

Individual interest, effect. —

Where county commissioners were charged with fraudulently conspiring to extort money from county treasury, being individually interested in action, they were unable to exercise proper discretion in employing private attorneys and could not impose liability on county for paying them. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

Private counsel. —

The board of county commissioners may engage private counsel, in absence of county attorney, or in case of his refusal to act. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

Risk of accusation. —

When one accepts public office, he assumes risk of defending himself even against unfounded accusations at own expense. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

Cited in

Appel v. State ex rel. Shutter-Cottrell, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (1900); Bd. of Prof'l Responsibility v. Argeris, 2014 WY 150, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Nov. 19, 2014).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Persons upon whom notice of injury or claim against county may or must be served, 23 ALR2d 969.

§ 18-2-111. Judgment against county to be paid by tax levy; when execution to issue.

Except as provided in W.S. 1-39-101 through 1-39-120 when a judgment is rendered against the board of county commissioners or any county officer the judgment shall be paid by a tax levied for that purpose and when collected shall be paid by the county treasurer to the judgment creditor upon the delivery of a proper voucher. Execution may issue on the judgment if payment is not made within sixty (60) days after the time required for the payment of county taxes to the county treasurer.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 7; R.S. 1887, § 1798; R.S. 1899, § 1077; C.S. 1910, § 1074; C.S. 1920, § 1307; R.S. 1931, § 29-308; C.S. 1945, § 26-307; W.S. 1957, § 18-55; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1979, ch. 157, § 2; 2010, ch. 82, § 1; 2017 ch. 41, § 1, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2010 amendment, substituted “1-39-121” for “1-39-119.”

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo.Const. Approved March 9, 2010

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, substituted “1-39-120” for “1-39-121.”

Limitation. —

This section does not authorize the levy of a tax in excess of the rate limited by the constitution, but judgments must be paid out of the amount realized by the levy for ordinary county purposes. Grand I. & N. W. R.R. v. Baker, 6 Wyo. 369, 45 P. 494, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1896).

Stated in

Bd. of Prof'l Responsibility v. Argeris, 2014 WY 150, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Nov. 19, 2014).

§ 18-2-112. Contracts for human services.

A county may contract for treatment and preventive services for the mentally ill, substance abuser and developmentally disabled as provided in W.S. 35-1-611 through 35-1-627.

History.
