Laws 1979, ch. 155, § 1; 2010, ch. 82, § 1.

The 2010 amendment, substituted “35-1-627” for “35-1-626.”

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo.Const. Approved March 9, 2010

§ 18-2-113. Prohibition of towing by a county.

  1. As used in this section, “towing service” means the transportation or recovery of privately owned vehicles or the disposal of abandoned, privately owned vehicles by use of a motor vehicle altered, designed or equipped to tow or render assistance for vehicles by means of a crane, hoist, tow bar, tow line or dolly.
  2. Except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, a county shall not purchase or use equipment purchased by the county to engage in a towing service.
  3. Notwithstanding subsection (b) of this section, a county may purchase or use equipment to engage in a towing service if there is no privately owned commercial towing service operating in the county that is able and willing to perform a towing service at a reasonable cost.
  4. Nothing in this section prohibits the use of a county vehicle which is otherwise engaged in authorized activities, from providing assistance to stranded motorists.

History.

Laws 1990, ch. 51, § 1.

§ 18-2-114. Prohibitions; amateur radio antenna regulation.

No county shall enact or enforce an ordinance or regulation that fails to conform to the limited preemption entitled “Amateur Radio Preemption, 101 FCC 2d 952 (1985)” issued by the federal communications commission. An ordinance or regulation adopted by a county with respect to amateur radio antennas shall conform to the limited federal preemption which states local regulations that involve placement, screening or height of antennas based on health, safety or aesthetic considerations shall be crafted to reasonably accommodate amateur communications. No ordinance or regulation adopted by a county under this section shall establish a maximum height for an amateur radio antenna of less than seventy (70) feet above ground.

History.

Laws 1997, ch. 76, § 1; 1998, ch. 34, § 1.

§ 18-2-115. Nuisance abatement; procedures.

  1. A board of county commissioners shall, by resolution, establish standards for determining when a site may be declared a nuisance under W.S. 18-2-101(a)(viii).
  2. A board of county commissioners may issue an order declaring a property to be a nuisance under W.S. 18-2-101(a)(viii) and shall provide written notice to the owner or occupant of the property describing with specificity the nature of the nuisance and the steps required for abatement. The order shall be in writing, shall state the grounds for the order and shall be filed in the office of the clerk of the district court of the county in which the property is situated. A copy of the order shall be served in accordance with the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure upon the owner or occupant with a written notice that the order has been filed and shall remain in force, unless the owner or occupant files his objections or answer with the clerk of the district court within twenty (20) days. A copy of the order shall be posted in a conspicuous place upon the property.
  3. Within twenty (20) days of service of an order issued under subsection (b) of this section, the owner or occupant may file with the clerk of the district court and serve upon the board of county commissioners issuing the order, an answer denying the existence of any of the allegations in the order. If no answer is filed and served, the order shall become a final order declaring the site a nuisance and fix a time when the order shall be enforced. If an answer is filed and served, the court shall hear and determine the issues raised as set forth in subsection (d) of this section.
  4. The court shall hold a hearing within twenty (20) days from the date of the filing of the answer. If the court sustains all or any part of the order, the court shall issue a final order and fix a time within which all or any part of the final order shall be enforced.
  5. An appeal from the judgment or final order of the district court may be taken by any party to the proceeding in accordance with the Wyoming Rules of Appellate Procedure.

History.

Laws 2008, ch. 81, § 1.

Effective date.—

Laws 2008, ch. 81, § 1, makes the act effective July 1, 2008.

§ 18-2-116. County prohibitions on utility connections.

No county shall enact or implement any resolution or policy that prohibits, or has the effect of prohibiting, the connection or reconnection of an electric, natural gas, propane or other energy utility service provided by a public utility, municipality or cooperative utility.

History.

2021 ch. 153, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

Effective date. —

Laws 2021, ch. 153, § 2, makes the act effective July 1, 2021.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Oath of allegiance or loyalty, validity of governmental requirement of, 18 ALR2d 268.

Union organization and activities of public employees, 31 ALR2d 1142, 37 ALR3d 1147, 95 ALR3d 1102.

Legislative power to prescribe qualifications for or conditions of eligibility to constitutional office, 34 ALR2d 155.

Immunity from service of process of public officer while attending court in official capacity, 45 ALR2d 1100.

Right of public employees to form or join a labor organization affiliated with a federation of trade unions or which includes private employees, 40 ALR3d 728.

Validity of requirement that candidate or public officer have been residents of governmental unit for specified period, 65 ALR3d 1048.

20 C.J.S. Counties §§ 97 to 142.

§ 18-3-101. Time of qualifying.

All county officers elected at a general election shall qualify and assume their offices on the first Monday in January next following their election.

History.

Laws 1879, ch. 34, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 1903; R.S. 1899, § 1224; Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 7; 1909, ch. 85, § 2; C.S. 1910, §§ 1136, 1265; C.S. 1920, §§ 1370, 1515; Laws 1931, §§ 30-110, 30-306; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-101, 27-505; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-57, 18-98; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to constitutional provision authorizing election of county officers, see art. 12, § 5, Wyo. Const.

Salaries. —

The salaries of county officers become fixed at the date of their election, though they do not take office until the first Nickerson v. Winslow, 22 Wyo. 259, 138 P. 184, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 22 Wyo. 259, 138 P. 184, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1914).

§ 18-3-102. County officers required to execute bonds; amount; sureties; penalty.

  1. All county officers, except county attorneys, before assuming the duties of their office and within twenty (20) days after the commencement of the term for which they were elected or appointed, shall take, subscribe and file the oath of office, and execute and file their official bonds to the state of Wyoming to insure the honest and faithful performance of their duties, in the penal amounts specified and according to the following provisions:
    1. County assessor: a bond approved by the board of county commissioners of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with at least two (2) sureties who are residents of the county or of a responsible surety company;
    2. Repealed by Laws 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 2.
    3. County clerk: a bond filed with the county treasurer of not less than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) with at least two (2) sureties;
    4. County commissioners: a bond approved by the clerk of the district court of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00);
    5. County sheriff: a bond approved by the board of county commissioners of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) with sufficient surety;
    6. County surveyor: a bond of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with sufficient sureties;
    7. County treasurer: a bond in an amount prescribed by the board of county commissioners and filed in the office of the county clerk with an approved corporate surety company or at least three (3) sufficient sureties. If for any reason the bond has not been approved by the board of county commissioners, the bond may be approved by the county clerk, but final approval must be given by the board of county commissioners at their next regular meeting. If the board of county commissioners has not prescribed the amount of the bond it shall be not less than the total amount of taxes levied for the year;
    8. County coroner: a bond as specified in W.S. 7-4-101.
  2. The board of county commissioners may require any county officer who receives county revenue to execute a bond in the penal amount of one and one-fourth (1 1/4) times the amount of revenue received.
  3. Deputy county assessors appointed as provided by W.S. 18-3-107(e) shall execute a bond with the county in the penal sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) conditioned that they will faithfully and impartially observe the laws relating to the listing, assessing and valuing of all property.
  4. Whenever the board of county commissioners requires any county officer to execute a new or additional bond, the county clerk shall immediately give personal notice to that officer. If the bond is not executed within twenty (20) days after receipt of the notice, the board of county commissioners shall declare the office vacant and shall appoint a qualified person to hold the office as provided by W.S. 22-18-111.
  5. Sureties of official bonds as provided in this section shall be residents of the state and have a net worth of twice the amount secured by the bond and each shall sign an affidavit, which will be endorsed on the bond, of his net worth. Any surety who willfully and corruptly makes a false affidavit as to his qualifications is guilty of false swearing.
  6. If a surety ceases to possess the required qualifications, the board of county commissioners shall require the county officer giving the bond to execute a new one.
  7. Any action to recover on the bonds provided in this section shall be in the name of the people.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 11,§§ 1 to 3, 5, 6, 8; ch. 28, art. IV, § 1; art. VII, § 1; art. VIII, §§ 1, 4; art. XI, §§ 2, 6; Laws 1882, ch. 52,§ 1; C.L. 1886, ch. 58,§ 1; R.S. 1887, §§ 1858, 1889, 1893, 1902,1907, 1910 to 1915; Laws 1890-91, ch. 45,§ 1; ch. 57, § 7; 1899, ch. 11, § 1; R.S. 1899, §§ 1056, 1083, 1103, 1111,1184, 1223, 1228 to 1231, 1243 to 1245; Laws 1901, ch. 35,§ 1; 1907, ch. 80, §§ 4,12; 1909, ch. 85, § 4; C.S. 1910, §§ 1135, 1140 to 1143, 1155to 1157, 1162, 1181, 1212, 1262, 1272, 1290.; Laws 1915, ch. 3, § 1; C.S. 1920, §§ 1369, 1376 to 1379, 1391to 1393, 1408, 1427, 1450, 1459, 1512, 1522, 1542.; Laws 1925, ch. 31,§ 1; ch. 33, § 1; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-109, 30-119 to 30-122,30-134 to 30-136, 30-303, 30-313, 30-401, 30-601, 30-801, 30-1001; Laws 1937, ch. 85,§§ 3, 5 to 7; 1939, ch. 39, § 1; 1945, ch. 147, § 1; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-103, 27-107, 27-109 to27-114, 27-502, 27-507, 27-601, 27-801, 27-1001, 27-1201, 27-1301; Laws 1949, ch. 13,§ 1; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-62 to 18-69, 18-95, 18-100,18-109, 18-144, 18-172, 18-192, 18-199; Laws 1977, ch. 45,§ 2; ch. 124, § 3; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 2; 1998, ch. 5, § 2; ch. 100, § 2; 2003, ch. 17, § 1; 2017 ch. 26, § 1, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in (c) substituted “18-3-107(e)” for “39-13-102(a)”.

§ 18-3-103. Offices and records to be kept within county; exceptions; records open to public inspection; removal for purposes of copying; penalty.

  1. Each county officer except the county attorney, the county coroner and the county sheriff if the county jail is not located in the county seat, shall keep his office at the county seat of the county in an office provided by the county. If the county does not provide an office then the office shall be maintained at a place approved by the board of county commissioners:
    1. The county clerk, county sheriff and county treasurer shall be furnished offices in the courthouse or building used as such;
    2. The county and prosecuting attorney and the county attorney shall be furnished suitable office space at the expense of the county which shall if practicable be located at or near the courthouse;
    3. The office of the county assessor may be with the office of another county officer as determined by the board of county commissioners;
    4. The office of the county coroner may be located at any suitable location determined by the county coroner with the approval of the board of county commissioners.
  2. All county officers shall keep their offices open during the usual business hours of each day excluding Saturdays, Sundays, legal holidays and other days as established by the county commissioners through resolution.
  3. All books, papers and electronic records required to be in county offices are open to the examination of any person without fee. The officer in charge of any documents may temporarily remove them for lawful reproduction purposes and during the period of removal shall not be subject to any penalty. Any officer or person not complying with the provisions of this subsection shall forfeit five dollars ($5.00) for each day he fails to comply.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. XI, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 1901; Laws 1890-91, ch. 54, § 14; 1895, ch. 76, § 20; R.S. 1899, §§ 1141, 1222, 1246; Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 6; C.S. 1910, §§ 1134, 1158, 1242, 1264; Laws 1915, ch. 141, § 1; C.S. 1920, §§ 1368, 1394, 1458, 1489, 1514; Laws 1925, ch. 61, § 1; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-108, 30-137, 30-305, 30-410, 30-507; Laws 1937, ch. 46, § 1; 1945, ch. 92, § 1; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-102, 27-303, 27-504, 27-609, 27-702; Laws 1957, ch. 117, § 1; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-58, 18-76, 18-97, 18-112, 18-119; Laws 1973, ch. 86, § 2; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 1; 2000, ch. 38, § 1; 2003, ch. 17, § 1; 2013 ch. 105, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; 2019 ch. 3, § 1, effective July 1, 2019.

Cross references. —

As to county seats, see § 18-1-201.

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, added “Saturdays” following “day excluding” and added “legal holidays and other days as established by the county commissioners through resolution” in (b).

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in (c) inserted “and electronic records” preceding “required.”

Inspecting, copying of records. —

This section gives no right to inspect and make copies of court records, and a deposition and letters transmitted with the deposition were not part of the records after the case has been concluded. King v. King, 25 Wyo. 275, 168 P. 730, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1917).

Provisions for office space permissive only. —

The provision that commissioners may furnish office space for the county and prosecuting attorney is permissive only. Ward v. Board of Comm'rs, 36 Wyo. 460, 36 Wyo. 461, 256 P. 1039, 1927 Wyo. LEXIS 54 (Wyo. 1927).

Election contest. —

In an election contest a defeated candidate has a right upon showing of a special interest, to inspect affidavits on file in connection with the case. State ex rel. Romsa v. Grace, 43 Wyo. 454, 5 P.2d 301, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1931).

Inspection. —

Petition filed in an election contest did not show such special interest so as to entitle defeated candidate to inspect affidavits on file. State ex rel. Romsa v. Grace, 43 Wyo. 454, 5 P.2d 301, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 40 (Wyo. 1931).

Stated in

W.A.R.M. v. Bonds, 866 P.2d 1291, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1994).

§ 18-3-104. Copies of instruments and transcripts of records as evidence.

Copies of all documents, writs, proceedings, instruments, papers and writings filed or deposited in the office of any district judge, county clerk or county treasurer and transcripts from books of record or proceedings kept by any such officers, with the seal of his office affixed, is prima facie evidence in all cases.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. XI, § 3; R.S. 1887, § 1904; R.S. 1899, § 1235; C.S. 1910, § 1147; C.S. 1920, § 1383; R.S. 1931, § 30-126; C.S. 1945, § 27-104; W.S. 1957, § 18-59; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Law reviews. —

See case note, “Constitutional Law — An Indigent's Right to a Free Trial Transcript. Mayer v. City of Chicago, 404 U.S. 189, 30 L. Ed. 2d 372, 92 S. Ct. 410, 1971 U.S. LEXIS 298 (1971),” VII Land & Water L. Rev. 707 (1972).

§ 18-3-105. Powers and compensation in special cases.

Whenever any county officer is required to perform the official duties of any other officer of this state he shall have for that time the same powers given by law to the officer whose duties he performs and shall receive the same compensation for his services.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. XI, § 3; R.S. 1887, § 1904; R.S. 1899, § 1235; C.S. 1910, § 1147; C.S. 1920, § 1383; R.S. 1931, § 30-126; C.S. 1945, § 27-104; W.S. 1957, § 18-60; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-3-106. Full-time officers enumerated.

Each county clerk, county treasurer, clerk of the district court, county assessor and county sheriff shall devote full time to the duties of their respective offices during the term for which they were elected or appointed. In counties which are not served by a district attorney and in which the population exceeds nine thousand (9,000) but is less than sixty thousand (60,000), the county and prosecuting attorney shall devote full-time to the duties of his office whenever a majority of the county commissioners in that county resolve that a full-time county and prosecuting attorney is necessary. In counties which are not served by a district attorney and in which the population does not exceed nine thousand (9,000), as well as in counties which are served by a district attorney, the county commissioners may designate the office of county attorney and the office of county and prosecuting attorney as a full-time office. The designations shall be made by resolution at the time salaries are set under W.S. 18-3-107(a).

History.

Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 7; 1909, ch. 85, § 2; C.S. 1910, § 1265; C.S. 1920, § 1515; Laws 1931, ch. 73, § 18; R.S. 1931, § 30-306; Laws 1945, ch. 95, § 1; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-117, 27-505; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-70, 18-98; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 21, § 2.

§ 18-3-107. Annual salaries of certain officers; additional compensation prohibited; exception as to traveling and other expenses; compensation of county commissioner; appointment and salaries of deputies, clerks, stenographers and other assistants.

  1. County officers shall be paid as follows:
    1. The county assessor, part-time county and prosecuting attorneys, part-time county attorneys, county clerk, clerk of district court, county sheriff and county treasurer in their respective counties shall receive as annual salaries:
      1. Repealed Laws 2009, ch. 142, § 2.
      2. From and after January 1, 2007, not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) nor more than seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00);
      3. From and after January 3, 2011, not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) nor more than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00).
    2. Full-time county attorneys and full-time county and prosecuting attorneys shall receive as annual salaries:
      1. Repealed Laws 2009, ch. 142, § 2.
      2. From and after January 1, 2007, not less than thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00) nor more than eighty-five thousand dollars ($85,000.00);
      3. From and after January 1, 2009 and to the extent permitted under the constitution and statutory law, not less than thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00) nor more than the salary authorized for a district attorney under W.S. 9-1-802(d).
    3. Salaries shall be paid in equal monthly installments. The board of county commissioners of each county shall meet not later than June 1, 1978, and on or before the same date each four (4) years thereafter, for the purpose of setting salaries, which shall not be changed during the term of each official for whom a salary is determined.
  2. The salaries provided in subsection (a) of this section shall compensate county officers for all of the duties prescribed by law to be performed by them, and no such officer shall receive from federal, state or county funds any additional or separate salary or compensation other than as above specified. This restriction shall not apply to traveling and other expenses nor to compensation allowed for office or house rent when expressly provided by law nor to other benefits provided to all employees of the respective county.
  3. Each county commissioner will be paid such compensation as the board of county commissioners determines by resolution. No county commissioner may receive more than the lowest compensation paid any elected county officer in the same county who serves full-time as specified in W.S. 18-3-106.
  4. The board of county commissioners shall meet not later than June 1, 1978, and on or before the same date each four (4) years thereafter for the purpose of setting their salaries for the following four (4) years, commencing January 1. The salary amount, when determined, cannot be increased during the period for which established. In addition thereof, each commissioner shall be paid his actual expenses while away from his home on official county business and not exceeding the same mileage allowance as received by state employees for each mile actually and necessarily traveled other than in a county owned vehicle in going to and returning from the meetings of the board and in the discharge of the duties of his office. Only one (1) mileage allowance shall be allowed per vehicle per trip. No commissioner’s salary or expense for any purpose shall be charged to any account other than the county commissioner’s account in the county budget. No commissioner shall be allowed any other salary from the county other than that herein stipulated.
  5. By and with the consent of the board of county commissioners of the respective counties, the county assessor, county clerk, clerk of the district court, county and prosecuting attorney and county treasurer in each county in the state may appoint one (1) or more deputies for each of the above-named offices who shall receive an annual salary of not less than twenty percent (20%) of the above named officer’s salary to be established by the board of county commissioners and also appoint such other clerks, stenographers and assistants as may be necessary to properly administer the affairs of any county office.
  6. Subject to legislative appropriation, the state will pay a portion of each county and prosecuting attorney and assistant county and prosecuting attorney’s salary as provided in this subsection. The state will pay fifty percent (50%) of the salary of the county and prosecuting attorney per year to each qualifying county. The state will pay thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) or fifty percent (50%) of the salary of each assistant to the county and prosecuting attorney, whichever is less, per year. Payments under this section shall be made annually on or before June 30. In any fiscal year in which the legislative appropriation is insufficient to make all payments authorized by this subsection, the state treasurer shall provide a reduced payment by multiplying the payment authorized under this subsection by a fraction, the numerator of which is equal to the remaining legislative appropriation for the program for the biennial budget period and the denominator of which is equal to the total payments to be made under this subsection for the current fiscal year.
  7. The board of county commissioners of the respective counties may appoint one (1) or more assistants or staff positions, whose salary shall be established by the board of county commissioners, as may be necessary to properly administer the affairs of the board of county commissioners. Persons appointed to an assistant or staff position shall not perform any duties statutorily delegated to any other county elected official.

History.

Laws 1945, ch. 166, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 27-302; Laws 1949, ch. 108, § 1; 1953, ch. 71, § 1; 1957, ch. 191, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 18-74; Laws 1961, ch. 33, § 1; 1965, ch. 101, § 1; 1967, ch. 74, § 1; 1969, ch. 124, § 2; ch. 175, §§ 1, 2; 1973, ch. 60, § 1; ch. 85, § 1; 1977, ch. 15, § 1; ch. 124, § 1; 1978, Sp. Sess., ch. 4, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 13, § 1; Sp. Sess., ch. 21, § 2; 1993, ch. 152, § 1; 1998, ch. 95, § 1; 1999, ch. 131, § 1; 2004, ch. 50, § 1; 2005, ch. 162, § 1; 2006, ch. 29, § 1; 2007, ch. 30, § 1; ch. 31, § 1; ch. 215, § 1; 2009, ch. 142, §§ 1, 2; 2013 ch. 176, § 1, effective July 1, 2013.

Cross references. —

For constitutional provision that legislature shall fix salaries not determined by constitution, see art. 14, § 1, Wyo. Const.

For provision requiring salaries paid to be fixed and definite, with certain exceptions, see art. 14, § 1, Wyo. Const.

As to travel allowances to county attorney, see §§ 18-3-304 and 18-3-110.

As to quarters or rental allowance allowed sheriff in connection with keeping prisoners in jail, see § 18-3-603.

The 2004 amendment, effective July 1, 2004, in (c) deleted “other” following “compensation paid any,” and added “who serves full-time as specified in W.S. 18-3-106.”

The 2005 amendment, effective July 1, 2005, rewrote (a), adding the paragraph and subparagraph designations, and increasing salary ranges of the specified county officers.

The 2006 amendment, effective July 1, 2006, added (g).

The 2007 amendments. —

The first 2007 amendment, by ch. 30, § 1, effective July 1, 2007, rewrote (f), changing dollar amounts.

The second 2007 amendment, by ch. 31, § 1, effective July 1, 2007, added (a)(ii)(C).

This section is set out as reconciled by the Wyoming legislative service office.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, repealed (a)(i)(A), which read: “From and after January 1, 1999, not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) nor more than sixty thousand dollars ($60,000.00)”; added (a)(i)(C); and repealed (a)(ii)(A), which read: “From and after January 1, 1999, not less than thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00) nor more than seventy thousand dollars ($70,000.00).”

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, repealed (a)(i)(A), which read: “From and after January 1, 1999, not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) nor more than sixty thousand dollars ($60,000.00)”; added (a)(i)(C); and repealed (a)(ii)(A), which read: “From and after January 1, 1999, not less than thirty-five thousand dollars ($35,000.00) nor more than seventy thousand dollars ($70,000.00).”

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, in (f) inserted “Subject to legislative appropriation, the state will pay a portion of each county and prosecuting attorney and assistant county and prosecuting attorney’s salary as provided in this subsection” and added the last sentence.

Appropriations. —

Laws 2007, ch. 30, § 2 provides as follows: “There is appropriated from the general fund one million nine hundred thirty-six thousand dollars ($1,936,000.00) to the attorney general's office for the purposes of this act for the fiscal period from July 1, 2007 to June 30, 2008.”

Prevailing clauses. —

Laws 2013, ch. 176, § 2, directs: “This act shall be given precedence and shall prevail over any other act enacted into law during the same session in which this act is enacted to the extent that any other act is in conflict with amendments made by this act.”

Repealing clauses. —

Section 2, ch. 166, Laws 1945, reads: “Sections 30-311 (Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 8, as amended), 30-403, 30-503, 30-802, 30-905, 30-1102 (Laws 1895, ch. 76, §§ 2 to 6, 14, as amended), Wyoming Revised Statutes, 1931, and § 31-227, Wyoming Revised Statutes, 1931, as amended and reenacted by chapter 80, Session Laws of Wyoming, 1941, chapter 52, Session Laws of Wyoming, 1943 (Laws 1895, ch. 76, § 7, as amended) and all other acts or parts of acts in conflict with this act are hereby repealed.”

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2007, ch. 215, § 4, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Constitutionality of use of assessed valuation of county for year next subsequent to election. —

Where a district court has determined that by reason of the design, neglect or default of county commissioners or other such officers, an assessed valuation has been set which does not fairly represent the valuation of such county for such year and upon which certain county officers' salaries have been based, use of the assessed valuation of the said county in the year next subsequent to their election and qualification in the computation and determination of salaries of such county officers, which would result in payment to said county officers of a salary different from that based upon a standard which does not fairly represent the valuation of such county for such year would violate art. 14, § 1, Wyo. Const., providing that officers be paid fixed and definite salaries, and art. 3, § 32, Wyo. Const., prohibiting increase or decrease of such salaries after election. Barber v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 222, 277 P.2d 977, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1954).

Amendment. —

The 1911 amendment to former § 18-73, which provided that its provisions should not take effect until after December 31, 1912, making changes in classification of counties, thus affecting the compensation due officials, did not become effective until the day fixed and amendment was a nullity until that time. Nickerson v. Winslow, 22 Wyo. 259, 138 P. 184, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 22 Wyo. 259, 138 P. 184, 1914 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1914).

Application under 1945 amendment. —

Plaintiff, who was appointed to fill a vacancy in the office of county treasurer on August 1, 1945, did not come within the exception in the 1945 amendment to this section which provided that act did not apply “to any county officers now holding office.” Ballangee v. Board of County Comm'rs, 66 Wyo. 390, 212 P.2d 71, 1949 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1949).

Effect of 1949 amendment. —

The amendment of 1949 to this section could not have effect of raising sheriff's salary during his term of office where it provided standard by which increased salary would be possible, in view of provision of art. 3, § 32, Wyo. Const., that no law should increase salary of public officer after his election or appointment and art. 14, § 1, Wyo. Const., that various public officers should be paid fixed and definite salaries. These provisions may not be circumvented by indirect changes. Blackburn v. Board of County Comm'rs, 67 Wyo. 494, 226 P.2d 784, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo. 1951).

Salary of county clerk. —

No change can be made in the salary of a county clerk during his term, notwithstanding a change in the assessed valuation of the county, which would place it in a higher or lower class. Guthrie v. Board of Comm'rs, 7 Wyo. 95, 50 P. 229, 1897 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1897).

Salary of treasurers of the counties of the several classes must continue the same throughout an official year, and cannot be made more or less for the last than the first part, though an assessment made within the year shows that it was an “assessed valuation” of a higher or lower class. Board of Comm'rs v. Burns, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 3 Wyo. 691, 29 P. 894, 1892 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1892).

Expense of office. —

Statutory compensation for use of automobile by sheriff was not “emolument” which could not be increased or diminished after sheriff's appointment or election under constitutional provision prohibiting change in officer's salary or emolument after his election or appointment. Taxpayers' League of Carbon County v. McPherson, 49 Wyo. 251, 54 P.2d 897, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 48 (Wyo. 1936).

Evidence of approval of deputy. —

Treasurer's written appointment of deputy, filed with county clerk with letter requesting county board to approve appointment with board chairman's endorsement thereon showing approval were in absence of journal record thereof admissible in evidence to show what action had been taken by board. Board of Comm'rs v. Stone, 7 Wyo. 280, 51 P. 605, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1898).

Ratification of appointment of deputy. —

Auditing and allowing salary of deputy county officer, whose appointment must be consented to by county board is sufficient approval of the official appointed and a ratification of his appointment. Griggs v. Board of Comm'rs, 5 Wyo. 274, 40 P. 304, 1895 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1895).

Acts within scope of duties. —

Approving budgets and determining compensation for the county coroner's office are statutory functions expressly within the scope of duties required of a member of a board of county commissioners. Therefore allegations of insufficient budget allocations and determination of inadequate compensation levels could not form the basis of a claim for tortious conduct against members of a board of county commissioners. Veile v. Board of County Comm'rs, 860 P.2d 1174, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 163 (Wyo. 1993).

Stated in

W.A.R.M. v. Bonds, 866 P.2d 1291, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1994).

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. State ex rel. Yeadon, 971 P.2d 129, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 187 (Wyo. 1998).

Law reviews. —

For case note, “Local Government Law — Platte County's Cost of Living Adjustment: Is It an Unconstitutional In-Term Adjustment of an Elected Officer's Salary?,” see XXXV Land & Water L. Rev. 549 (2000).

§ 18-3-108. Salaries paid in monthly installments; allowance by commissioners.

The salaries of county officers shall be paid in equal monthly installments by the county in which they serve and shall be allowed at the first regular monthly meeting of the board of county commissioners occurring after the rendition of service.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 76, § 20; R.S. 1899, § 1246; C.S. 1910, § 1158; C.S. 1920, § 1394; R.S. 1931, § 30-137; Laws 1945, ch. 92, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 27-303; W.S. 1957, § 18-75; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

For constitutional provisions that legislature shall designate and fix salaries of county officers, see art. 14, § 3, Wyo. Const.

Editor's notes. —

Chapter 76, Laws 1895, as amended, was the general basic law concerning fees and salaries of county officers, and it originally consisted of 23 sections. Sections 2 to 7 and 14 have been repealed. For the remaining sections of the act appearing in this compilation see the Table of Disposition of Acts.

This section is mandatory. Ballangee v. Board of County Comm'rs, 66 Wyo. 390, 212 P.2d 71, 1949 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1949).

Determination by commissioners. —

Determination by board of county commissioners that office of justice of peace in certain precinct is salaried office will not be disturbed in absence of proof that board erred in its determination of fact. Davis v. Board of Comm'rs, 4 Wyo. 477, 35 P. 467, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1894).

Cited in

Ballantyne v. Bower, 17 Wyo. 356, 99 P. 869, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (1909).

§ 18-3-109. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2010, ch. 69, § 208.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1895, ch. 76, § 23; R.S. 1899, § 1238; C.S. 1910, § 1150; C.S. 1920, § 1386; R.S. 1931, § 30-129; C.S. 1945, § 27-306; Laws 1953, ch. 121, § 1; 1957, ch. 144, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 18-78; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1, related to definition of assessed valuation.

Laws 2010, ch. 69, § 501, makes the act effective July 1, 2010.

§ 18-3-110. Reimbursement for traveling expenses; receipt required.

Any county officer whose official duties require him to travel away from the county seat shall be reimbursed by the county for his actual and necessary traveling expenses and mileage as provided by W.S. 9-3-103. The county sheriff may also be reimbursed for travel away from the county jail for official duties, if the jail is not located in the county seat. No officer requesting mileage expenses shall claim additional transportation expense. The board of county commissioners shall not allow payment for traveling expenses unless there are receipts for all monies expended.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 92, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1227; C.S. 1910, § 1139; Laws 1913, ch. 13, § 1; C.S. 1920, §§ 1373, 1375; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-113, 30-115; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-307, 27-308; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-79, 18-80; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2000, ch. 38, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to per diem and traveling expenses of state officers and employees, see § 9-3-102.

As to travel allowances for county attorney, see § 18-3-304.

Deputy sheriff not entitled to reimbursement. —

Because a deputy sheriff was not a “county officer” as provided by § 18-3-102, he was not entitled to reimbursement of any expenses under this section. Smith v. Board of County Comm'rs of County of Sublette, 891 P.2d 88, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 44 (Wyo. 1995).

§ 18-3-111. Responsibility of officers.

All county officers are responsible for the acts of their deputies and assistants, and as such are liable on their official bonds.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 74, § 11; R.S. 1899, § 1240; C.S. 1910, § 1152; C.S. 1920, § 1388; R.S. 1931, § 30-131; C.S. 1945, § 27-402; W.S. 1957, § 18-86; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to bonds of officers generally, see § 18-3-102.

Applied in

Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Liability of public officer for the defaults and misfeasances of clerks, assistants or deputies, 71 ALR2d 1140.

Liability of county clerk or prothonotary, or surety on bond, for negligent or wrongful acts of deputies or assistants, 71 ALR2d 1140.

Personal liability of public officer for killing or injuring animal while carrying out statutory duties with respect to it, 2 ALR3d 822.

Liability of governmental entity or public officer for personal injury or damages arising out of vehicular accident due to negligent or defective design of highway, 45 ALR3d 875, 58 ALR4th 559.

§ 18-3-112. Powers; bonds.

All deputy county officers have the same power and authority as their principal, and all official acts performed by them have the same force and effect as if done by their principal. All officers appointing deputies and assistants may require from them bond for their own protection, in such sum as they see fit.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 74, § 12; R.S. 1899, § 1241; C.S. 1910, § 1153; C.S. 1920, § 1389; R.S. 1931, § 30-132; C.S. 1945, § 27-403; W.S. 1957, § 18-87; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Applied in

Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

Article 2. Assessors

  • § 18-3-201.  Qualifications; certification and education.
  • § 18-3-202.  Oath.
  • § 18-3-203.  Supplies.
  • § 18-3-204.  Duties generally.
  • § 18-3-205.  Interfering with assessor; failure to return property; penalties.
  • § 18-3-206.  Penalties.

Cross references. —

For provision that no county assessor shall be appointed deputy sheriff, see § 18-3-602.

For constitutional provisions that legislature shall designate county officers and fix salaries of county officers, see art. 14, § 3, Wyo. Const.

As to taxation and property generally, see art. 15, §§ 1 to 16, Wyo. Const.

For duty of county assessor as to assessment of tax made from maintaining nuisance, see § 6-6-207.

As to filling of vacancy in office of county assessor, see § 22-18-111.

For duty of county assessor as to tax levy in special cemetery districts, see § 35-8-314.

For duty of county commissioners and county assessor as to tax levy in connection with fire protection districts, see § 35-9-203.

As to duty of county assessor with reference to assessments made in connection with power districts, see § 37-7-121.

For duties of county assessor in relation to taxation and revenue generally, see title 39.

For duties of county assessors in relation to water conservancy districts, irrigation districts, etc., generally, see title 41.

§ 18-3-201. Qualifications; certification and education.

  1. There shall be elected in each county a county assessor as provided by the Wyoming Election Code of 1973 as amended, who shall be a qualified elector and own real property in the county in which he is elected. The county assessor shall be a resident of the county in which the county assessor serves, beginning on the first day of the term and through the last day of the term for which the county assessor serves.
  2. The department of revenue, after consultation with the president of the county assessor’s association, shall:
    1. Establish, implement and maintain a mandatory system of education and training for all property tax appraisers;
    2. Establish standards and criteria for certification;
    3. Provide a temporary and permanent certification program based on education, relevant experience or examination; and
    4. Report excessive absences of any county assessor from required education programs to the appropriate board of county commissioners and to the governor.
  3. As used in this section “property tax appraiser” means any employee of the state or any county, including elected county assessors, who makes valuation judgments used as a basis for ad valorem taxation.
  4. No individual shall perform the duties or exercise the authority of a property tax appraiser unless the person is certified by the department of revenue. No certificate shall be issued to any individual who has not demonstrated to the department of revenue that the individual is competent to perform the necessary work or administer the necessary operation of an assessor’s office. An individual may serve as county assessor without certification for one (1) elected term and the remainder of any unexpired term to which appointed.
  5. The director of the ad valorem tax division, under the direction of the department of revenue, shall provide for examination of applicants for certificates and shall conduct or sponsor in-service or pre-entry training programs on the technical, legal and administrative aspects of the appraisal and assessment process. For this purpose, the director may cooperate with educational institutions, and regional, state or national appraisal and assessing organizations, and shall receive the advice of the president of the county assessor’s association, to develop training programs.
  6. The director, upon appropriation by the legislature, shall also provide for the costs of obtaining and presenting schools including, but not limited to, normal costs of tuition, books and instructor expenses. The direct expenses related to students, such as travel, housing and meals while attending the schools, shall be the direct responsibility of each respective entity.

History.

Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 2; C.S. 1910, § 1260; C.S. 1920, § 1510; R.S. 1931, § 30-301; Laws 1945, ch. 164, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 27-501; W.S. 1957, § 18-94; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1986, ch. 78, § 1; 1991, ch. 174, § 2; 1995, ch. 209, § 1; 2010, ch. 69, § 203; 2021 ch. 165, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, in (d), deleted the former last sentence which read: “Individuals occupying the position of county assessor as of the effective date of this act shall be deemed certified until January 1, 1991.”

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, added the second sentence in (a).

Editor's notes. —

Section 2, ch. 164, Laws 1945, reads: “Effective until the first Monday in January of 1947, each county assessor is hereby designated as the person to prepare and keep currently posted, plat books of the real property in his county, the duties connected therewith and those of county assessor being hereby declared compatible; for services connected with such plat books, such assessors shall receive compensation fixed by the board of county commissioners on an annual basis not exceeding $1,000.00 in first and second class counties or in third class counties, $800.00.”

The office of assessor was originally created by ch. 28, C.L. 1876, which was a general law for the organization of county government.

Applicability. —

Laws 2021, ch. 165, § 2, provides: "The residency requirements of this act shall apply to elected or appointed county officers whose terms commence on or after the effective date of this act."

§ 18-3-202. Oath.

Before entering upon the duties of his office, the county assessor shall take and subscribe the following oath or affirmation: “I, . . . . . having been elected assessor of . . . . . county, state of Wyoming, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will faithfully and impartially perform the duties of assessor of the county of . . . . . , state of Wyoming, according to law and to the best of my ability, and that I will without fear or favor assess all taxable property within the county of . . . . . , at its fair value. So help me God”.

History.

Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 5; 1909, ch. 85, § 1; C.S. 1910, § 1263; C.S. 1920, § 1513; R.S. 1931, § 30-304; C.S. 1945, § 27-503; W.S. 1957, § 18-96; Laws 1959, ch. 56, § 2; 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to restrictions upon employment of attorneys under this section, see § 18-3-520.

As to habeas corpus generally, see §§ 1-27-101 to 1-27-134.

As to appointment of an attorney to prosecute an action of quo warranto when county attorney disabled, see § 1-31-106.

Stated in

Scott Realty Co. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 395 P.2d 289, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 1964).

Cited in

Ketcham v. State, 618 P.2d 1356, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 320 (Wyo. 1980).

§ 18-3-203. Supplies.

The county assessor shall be furnished with books, assessment roll, stationery and supplies as necessary for the proper discharge of his duties.

History.

Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 6; C.S. 1910, § 1264; C.S. 1920, § 1514; R.S. 1931, § 30-305; C.S. 1945, § 27-504; W.S. 1957, § 18-97; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

For duty of county commissioners to provide county officers with stationery and supplies, see § 18-3-514.

Applied in

Ketcham v. State, 618 P.2d 1356, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 320 (Wyo. 1980).

§ 18-3-204. Duties generally.

  1. Each county assessor shall:
    1. Keep his office open during the usual business hours with the exception of the time he is away in the performance of his duties making assessments and listing property for the purpose of taxation;
    2. Secure data concerning the listing and taxation of property within his county and gather data from public records and other sources as will enable him to assess all property at its fair value;
    3. Examine the county records relating to transfers of property and gather from all reliable sources information of the changes of ownership of property, and record transfers of property to enable him to assess all property to its rightful owner or owners;
    4. Gather information relating to land passing from the government of the United States into private ownership under the public land laws of the United States, and make records to enable him to list and assess such property to the owner or owners thereof;
    5. When he is not making the assessment for the current year, devote himself to a study of property valuations in his county, and he may subpoena witnesses, administer oaths, examine them under oath, and require certified copies of any part of any public records or documents within his county necessary during the course of such investigation. Whenever any subpoena is issued by the county assessor, it shall be served by the county sheriff without charge to the county. Any witness or person subpoenaed by the county assessor shall receive the same fees as allowed in civil actions;
    6. Prepare the assessment schedule in duplicate and leave with the property owner or person having control of the taxable property a copy of the assessment schedule. If any changes are subsequently made to the assessment schedule by the county assessor or his deputies, the county assessor shall immediately notify the property owner or person having control of the taxable property of the change;
    7. After the county board of equalization has finished their equalization of property for taxation and corrections have been designated by them, complete the roll and make the corrections and changes designated by the board, correctly foot the roll, and when completed subscribe and make the following oath which shall be attached to the roll: “I,  . . . . . , county assessor within and for the county of  . . . . . , state of Wyoming, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I or my deputies have demanded, received and reviewed from every property owner or person having control of taxable property within the county of  . . . . . , State of Wyoming, a complete and detailed statement of the amount and fair value of all taxable property and that I or my deputies have viewed the property listed, and have revised and corrected the statements where necessary; and that I have to the best of my knowledge and ability valued the property at its fair value; and in no case have I or my deputies knowingly omitted to demand a statement of the description and value of property in the county, and that I have not knowingly omitted to perform any duty required by me by law, and have not connived at any evasion or violation of any requirements of law in relation to the listing and valuation of property. So help me God.”;
    8. Immediately after the taxes are levied each year make the tax list in tabular form and in alphabetical order upon the form and in the manner prescribed by law;
    9. Faithfully and diligently follow and apply the orders, procedures and formulae of the department of revenue or orders of the state board of equalization for the appraisal and assessment of all taxable property;
    10. Attend continuing education programs not to exceed forty (40) classroom hours per year provided by or approved by the department of revenue.

History.

Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 7; 1909, ch. 85, §§ 2, 7; C.S. 1910, §§ 1265, 1275; Laws 1915, ch. 47, §§ 1, 2; C.S. 1920, §§ 1515, 1526, 1527; Laws 1931, ch. 73, § 18; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-306, 30-318, 30-319; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-505, 27-510, 27-511; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-98, 18-103, 18-104; Laws 1959, ch. 56, § 3; 1977, ch. 45, § 4; ch. 124, §§ 1, 4; 1985, ch. 148, § 1; 1995, ch. 209, § 1.

Cross references. —

For duty of county assessors to collect agricultural statistics, see chapter 3 of title 11.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Assessment in name of true owner. —

In absence of statute to contrary, real property must be assessed for taxation in name of true owner, if known. McCarthy v. Union Pac. R.R., 58 Wyo. 308, 131 P.2d 326, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1942).

Where person named Michael S. “Madden” was record owner of land, assessment thereof in name of “Madden Bros.” pursuant thereto, must be held void. McCarthy v. Union Pac. R.R., 58 Wyo. 308, 131 P.2d 326, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1942).

Owner of record. —

Term “owner” so far as real estate is concerned, means owner of record. McCarthy v. Union Pac. R.R., 58 Wyo. 308, 131 P.2d 326, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1942).

Subsequent parties in interest. —

Requirement that assessment of realty be made in name of owner may be invoked also by parties subsequently receiving interest in such property. McCarthy v. Union Pac. R.R., 58 Wyo. 308, 131 P.2d 326, 1942 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1942).

Assessor's oath. —

Assessment roll signed by assessor with statutory oath but not taken before an officer authorized to administer oaths, held insufficient to give validity to delinquent tax sale. United States v. Klink, 3 F. Supp. 208, 1933 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 1578 (D. Wyo. 1933).

Assessor's oath, required to be attached to assessment roll, is designed to safeguard taypayers' interests. Brewer v. Kulien, 42 Wyo. 314, 294 P. 777, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1930).

County assessor's failure to attach oath to assessment roll invalidates tax sale, where title is claimed thereunder. Brewer v. Kulien, 42 Wyo. 314, 294 P. 777, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1930).

In an action to quiet title to land acquired under tax sale, it was incumbent on the plaintiff to show that assessor's oath was attached to the tax roll before any sale in connection therewith took place, and on a failure to so show the plaintiff could not prevail. Sidlo, Simons, Day & Co. v. Phillips, 48 Wyo. 390, 49 P.2d 243, 1935 Wyo. LEXIS 42 (Wyo. 1935), overruled, Texas W. Oil & Gas Corp. v. First Interstate Bank, 743 P.2d 857, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 514 (Wyo. 1987). But see Texas W. Oil & Gas Corp. v. First Interstate Bank, 743 P.2d 857, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 514 (Wyo. 1987), reaff'd, 749 P.2d 278, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 23 (Wyo. 1988).

Adding, deducting from valuation. —

Law does not require final valuation of property to be made by assessors at any specified date and they are authorized to add to and deduct from valuations on schedules when they list property for taxation. Corthell v. Board of Comm'rs, 44 Wyo. 71, 8 P.2d 812, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1932).

Tax value of personal property is fair actual cash market value.—

The value of personal property for purposes of taxation should be estimated according to the fair actual cash market value or the price that the property would sell for in cash in the usual course of business. J. Ray McDermott & Co. v. Hudson, 370 P.2d 364, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 77 (Wyo. 1962).

Presumption. —

It must be presumed that when county assessment roll is laid before state board of equalization (now department of revenue and taxation) valuations of various owners have been fully equalized as between themselves. Bunten v. Rock Springs Grazing Ass'n, 29 Wyo. 461, 215 P. 244, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo. 1923).

Action on county assessment roll. —

County assessment roll is not to be sent to state board of equalization (now department of revenue and taxation) until county board has completed all adjustments at its July meeting, and the roll is not complete or final, so as to authorize tax levy, until acted upon by the state board. Baker v. Paxton, 29 Wyo. 500, 215 P. 257, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 27 (Wyo. 1923).

Applied in

Weaver v. State Bd. of Equalization, 511 P.2d 97, 1973 Wyo. LEXIS 165 (Wyo. 1973).

Quoted in

Scott Realty Co. v. State Bd. of Equalization, 395 P.2d 289, 1964 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 1964).

Stated in

Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987).

Law reviews. —

See “Remedies for Defects in General Property Tax Assessments in Wyoming,” 4 Wyo. L.J. 240.

For note, “The Common-Law Rule Against Holding Incompatible Offices — Abolishing the ‘Office’ Limitation,” see IX Land & Water L. Rev. 667 (1974).

§ 18-3-205. Interfering with assessor; failure to return property; penalties.

  1. Any person interfering with the county assessor or deputy county assessor in the discharge of his duties, or any person refusing to allow the county assessor, deputy county assessor or representative of the department of revenue to examine any property pursuant to W.S. 39-13-103(b)(v), is guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction shall be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), or imprisoned for not more than six (6) months in jail, or both.
  2. Any person who fails to report taxable property as provided in W.S. 39-13-107(a)(i) may be assessed a civil fee of five dollars ($5.00) for every day the report is not filed, not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). Civil fees under this subsection shall be added to the assessment for that taxpayer.

History.


Laws 1909, ch. 85, §§ 5, 6; C.S. 1910, §§ 1273, 1274; C.S. 1920, §§ 1524, 1525; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-316, 30-317; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-508, 27-509; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-101, 18-102; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; W.S. 1977, § 18-3-206; Laws 1984, ch. 70, § 1; 1991, ch. 174, § 2; 1995, ch. 209, § 1; 1998, ch. 5, § 2; 2021 ch. 158, § 1, effective January 1, 2022.

The 2021 amendment , effective January 1, 2022, rewrote (b), which read, "Any person who fails to return any taxable property owned by him or under his control is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), imprisoned in the county jail not exceeding ninety (90) days, or both."

Editor's notes. —

Section 18-3-205, which was enacted by § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, and which related to dividing of counties into assessment districts and appointment, etc., of deputy assessors, was repealed pursuant to § 4, ch. 124, Laws 1977. Accordingly, §§ 18-3-206 and 18-3-207 have been redesignated as §§ 18-3-205 and 18-3-206, respectively, in order to maintain proper numerical sequence.

Failure of assessor to give notice of addition of property to schedule. —

Where omitted property was subject to taxation, failure of assessor to give notice of the addition of omitted automobile to his schedule, was not error of such fundamental nature as to avoid tax. Corthell v. Board of Comm'rs, 44 Wyo. 71, 8 P.2d 812, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1932).

§ 18-3-206. Penalties.

  1. Any county assessor who fails to perform the duties provided by W.S. 18-3-201 through 18-3-206 is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00).
  2. Any county assessor who swears falsely to any oath provided by W.S. 18-3-201 through 18-3-206 is guilty of false swearing.
  3. Any county assessor, deputy assessor or member of any county board of equalization who knowingly and willfully values or equalizes taxable property at other than its fair value is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), imprisoned in the county jail not exceeding ninety (90) days or both, and shall forfeit his office.

History.

Laws 1907, ch. 80, § 11; C.S. 1910, § 1271; C.S. 1920, § 1521; R.S. 1931, § 30-312; C.S. 1945, § 27-506; W.S. 1957, § 18-99; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to perjury generally, see §§ 6-5-301 and 6-5-302.

Editor's notes. —

Section 18-3-208, which was enacted by § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, and which related to defining “fair value,” was repealed pursuant to § 4, ch. 124, Laws 1977. See also Editor's note to § 18-3-205.

Stated in

Simons v. Laramie County Sch. Dist., 741 P.2d 1116, 1987 Wyo. LEXIS 496 (Wyo. 1987).

Article 3. County and Prosecuting Attorneys

  • § 18-3-301.  Office created; qualifications; certificate of election; counties empowered to consolidate.
  • § 18-3-302.  Duties generally; employment of other attorneys by county.
  • § 18-3-303.  Fees or salary; restriction upon employment; failure to perform official duties.
  • § 18-3-304.  Travel allowances.
  • § 18-3-305.  [Repealed.]

Appropriations. —

Laws 2005, ch. 202, § 1, appropriates $300,000 to the attorney general from the general fund to fund a special prosecution account to assist individual counties in the prosecution of criminal defendants in cases where the extraordinary actual costs of prosecution is unusually expensive, as defined by rules and regulations of the attorney general. Funds in the special prosecution account are to be disbursed at the discretion of the attorney general only after written request of a prosecuting attorney, who must submit supporting budget information for the prosecutor's actual prosecution expenses along with projected costs of prosecution for the case involved. Funds in the special prosecution account are not to be used for expenses of the office of the attorney general.

Laws 2005, ch. 202, § 2, makes the act is effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2005.

Cross references. —

For provision exempting county attorney from provision requiring county officers to be kept at county seat, see § 18-3-103.

For authority and duties of county attorneys relative to criminal procedure generally, see title 7.

For duty of county attorney relative to Pure Seed Law, see § 11-12-118.

As to duty of county attorney to defend contested ballot proposition in countywide proposition, see § 22-17-107.

For duty of county attorney to institute proceedings against parties permitting waste water to damage, etc., highways, upon report of road supervisor, see § 24-1-116.

For duties of county attorney relative to mentally ill persons generally, see title 25.

For duties of county attorneys in relation to labor and employment generally, see title 27.

For duty of county attorneys to represent Wyoming oil and gas conservation commission when called upon by commission, see § 30-5-103.

For duties of county attorneys in relation to public health and safety generally, see title 35.

For duties of county attorneys in relation to public utilities generally, see title 37.

For duties of county attorneys relative to trade and commerce generally, see title 40.

For duty of county attorney to appear and defend division superintendent or water commissioner in matters pertaining to water, see § 41-3-604.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

56 Am. Jur. 2d Municipal Corporations, Counties, etc. §§ 90, 91, 235; 63C Am. Jur. 2d Prosecuting Attorneys § 1 et seq.

Validity, under state law, of appointment of independent special prosecutor to handle political or controversial prosecutions or investigations of persons other than regular prosecutor, 84 ALR3d 29.

Validity, under state law, of appointment of special prosecutor where regular prosecutor is charged with, or being investigated for, criminal or impeachable offense, 84 ALR3d 115.

Availability of writ of prohibition or similar remedy against acts of public prosecutor, 16 ALR4th 112.

27 C.J.S. District and Prosecuting Attorneys § 1 et seq.

§ 18-3-301. Office created; qualifications; certificate of election; counties empowered to consolidate.

  1. In judicial districts in which the office of district attorney has not been created there shall be elected in each county a county and prosecuting attorney who at the time of his nomination and election and during his term of office, shall be a member of the bar of this state. A copy of his certificate of election and oath shall be filed by the county and prosecuting attorney with the clerk of the district court for his county or counties. In those judicial districts in which the office of district attorney has been created the county commissioners shall appoint an attorney to the office of county attorney for a term of one (1) year, who may be reappointed on a year-to-year basis. The county commissioners may remove the county attorney for cause.
  2. The boards of county commissioners of two (2) or more contiguous counties not served by a district attorney may by resolution consolidate the offices of, and agree to be served by, a single county and prosecuting attorney who shall be elected by a vote of the electors of all the counties within the consolidated area.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. VIII, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 1893; R.S. 1899, § 1103; C.S. 1910, § 1204; Laws 1915, ch. 3, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 1450; Laws 1925, ch. 33, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 30-401; C.S. 1945, § 27-601; W.S. 1957, § 18-109; Laws 1975, ch. 195, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 21, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

Sections 1, 2, ch. 195, Laws 1975, would have amended or enacted provisions of W.S. 1957 similar to this section, effective January 1, 1978. However, § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, revised such provisions, also effective January 1, 1978.

Quoted in

State v. Wyo. State Hosp. (In re RB), 2013 WY 15, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Feb. 6, 2013).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Authority of attorney acting in official capacity to dismiss or otherwise terminate action, 56 ALR2d 1290.

Prosecuting attorney as a witness in criminal case, 54 ALR3d 100.

Power of private citizen to institute criminal proceedings without authorization or approval by prosecuting attorney, 66 ALR3d 732.

Immunity of prosecuting attorney or similar officer from action for false arrest or imprisonment, 79 ALR3d 882.

Disqualification of prosecuting attorney in state criminal case on account of relationship with accused, 42 ALR5th 581.

§ 18-3-302. Duties generally; employment of other attorneys by county.

  1. Each county attorney shall:
    1. Act in all courts in the state as legal counsel for his county or counties and its officers acting in their official capacity and prosecute or defend all suits instituted by or against his county or counties or its officers;
    2. Give his opinion in writing upon the request of any county officer of his county or counties, without fee, upon all questions of law relating to the duties of such officer and file and preserve in his office a copy of all such opinions;
    3. Examine the bonds offered by every county officer before the bonds are approved by the board of county commissioners and report in writing to the board of county commissioners or to the judge of the district court whether the bonds are executed as required by law;
    4. Perform other duties as prescribed by law.
  2. In any county in a judicial district in which the office of district attorney has not been created, the county and prosecuting attorney shall have the jurisdiction, responsibilities, and duties of the district attorney and of the county attorney.
  3. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the county commissioners of any county or consolidation of counties from employing one (1) or more attorneys to appear and prosecute or defend or assist the county and prosecuting attorney in behalf of the people of the state or such county or consolidation of counties in any action or proceeding, whether civil or criminal. In such case, the nature and necessity of the employment shall appear in the record of the board or boards. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the board of county commissioners of a county which has consolidated from independently employing one (1) or more attorneys to serve their respective counties.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. VIII, §§ 2, 3; Laws 1879, ch. 8, § 2; 1882, ch. 45, § 18; R.S. 1887, §§ 1894, 1895, 1897; R.S. 1899, §§ 1104, 1106, 1108; C.S. 1910, §§ 1205, 1207, 1209; C.S. 1920, §§ 1451, 1453, 1455; Laws 1931, ch. 92, § 1; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-402, 30-404, 30-406; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-602, 27-604, 27-606; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-111, 18-113, 18-115; Laws 1973, ch. 146, § 1; 1975, ch. 195, § 2; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 21, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

Section 2, ch. 195, Laws 1975, would have amended provisions of W.S. 1957 similar to this section, effective January 1, 1978. However, § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, revised such provisions, also effective January 1, 1978.

According to a previous compiler, § 2, ch. 8, Laws 1879, did not specifically amend § 2, art. VIII, ch. 28, C.L. 1876, but the 2 sections were combined as § 1104, R.S. 1899, and the combined sections were amended by § 1, ch. 92, Laws 1931. Section 2, ch. 8, Laws 1879, as originally enacted, appears herein as § 18-3-520.

By ch. 163, Laws 1945, the county and prosecuting attorney was made juvenile delinquent officer in first class counties until the first Monday in January, 1947.

Scope of prosecutorial immunity in conduct of office. —

To the extent that the securing of information is necessary to a prosecutor's decision to initiate a criminal prosecution and in the preparation of said case, the shield of absolute immunity attaches and the prosecutor cannot be held liable for alleged tortious conduct. Blake v. Rupe, 651 P.2d 1096, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 383 (Wyo. 1982), cert. denied, 459 U.S. 1208, 103 S. Ct. 1199, 75 L. Ed. 2d 442, 1983 U.S. LEXIS 3435 (U.S. 1983).

Argument by prosecuting attorney. —

The prosecuting attorney acts as attorney for the state and not in a judicial capacity, so that statement in argument on evidence, “I am going to ask you to convict a murderer,” is not erroneous, as a statement of opinion. Ross v. State, 8 Wyo. 351, 57 P. 924, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1899).

Prosecutors have no authority to grant immunity. —

A prosecuting attorney (district attorney or county attorney) in Wyoming has no authority to grant immunity to a witness. Hall v. State, 851 P.2d 1262, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 1993).

Attorney's fee. —

County attorney was not entitled to additional fee for prosecuting action to abate liquor nuisance. State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1928).

The state, in proceeding to abate liquor nuisance, was not entitled to tax reasonable attorney's fees which statute allows successful complainant, as the compensation of the county attorney is covered by his salary. State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (Wyo. 1928).

Private counsel. —

The board of county commissioners may engage private counsel, in absence of county attorney, or in case of his refusal to act. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

County commissioners were authorized to employ an attorney to assist the board in suit brought to compel it to designate a particular paper as the official paper of the county. Appel v. State, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1900).

The board of commissioners is the judge of the necessity of employing an attorney to assist the county attorney, and its determination thereon can only be attacked for fraud. Appel v. State, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1900).

Use of special federal prosecutor. —

State's use of a federal prosecutor as a special prosecutor in the defendant's capital murder trial was not error under Wyo. Const. art. 6, § 19 or Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-3-302(c); under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 6-2-103(d)(i), review for error, including constitutional error, has been limited to the use of special prosecutors with a financial or personal interest in the prosecution. Olsen v. State, 2003 WY 46, 67 P.3d 536, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 57 (Wyo. 2003).

Costs for special prosecutors. —

Statute contemplates that “costs” on change of venue shall include reasonable allowance for special assistant prosecuting attorney. Board of Comm'rs v. Board of Comm'rs, 40 Wyo. 144, 275 P. 102, 1929 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1929).

Change of venue. —

On change of venue in criminal case to another county, exceptions as to authority of county attorney of county where action was commenced to sign, verify and file pleading relating to a defect if any, appearing on its face, should be taken by motion to quash and were waived by defendant's plea of not guilty. State v. Kusel, 29 Wyo. 287, 213 P. 367, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1923).

Facts govern. —

Where county commissioners had no personal interest in suits and action was not against them individually, commissioners had power as board representing county to employ private attorneys to defend actions and to pay them, assertion in pleadings that county was not sued being a mere conclusion. The facts govern. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

Individual interest, effect. —

Where county commissioners were charged with fraudulently conspiring to extort money from county treasury, being individually interested in action, they were unable to exercise proper discretion in employing private attorneys and could not impose liability on county for paying them. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

Loss of jurisdiction. —

On change of venue the county from which the change was taken loses jurisdiction to proceed to try accused on a second information charging the same offense. Keefe v. District Court of Judicial Dist., 16 Wyo. 381, 94 P. 459, 1908 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1908).

Risk of accusation. —

When one accepts public office he assumes risk of defending himself even against unfounded accusations at own expense. Board of Comm'rs v. Casper Nat'l Bank, 56 Wyo. 132, 105 P.2d 578, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1940).

Unlawful trial. —

In prosecution before justice of the peace of an offense over which he had no jurisdiction save as an examining magistrate, where complaints were signed and sworn to before the county attorney, and the justice unlawfully tried the cause and imposed a fine without evidence that county was in any manner implicated in the proceedings, it was not liable in damages as for a tort. Houtz v. Board of Comm'rs, 11 Wyo. 152, 70 P. 840, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1902).

Stated in

Hilderbrand v. Padget, 678 P.2d 870, 1984 Wyo. LEXIS 271 (Wyo. 1984).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Authority of attorney acting in official capacity to dismiss or otherwise terminate action, 56 ALR2d 1290.

§ 18-3-303. Fees or salary; restriction upon employment; failure to perform official duties.

  1. Each county attorney and their deputies shall receive such fees, salary or both as allowed by the board of county commissioners. When counties have consolidated the office of county and prosecuting attorney pursuant to W.S. 18-3-301(b) the salary of county and prosecuting attorneys shall be apportioned between the counties by agreement of the boards of county commissioners, but a county which has consolidated may independently employ a deputy county and prosecuting attorney. The boards of county commissioners of each county which have consolidated shall meet once every four (4) years to set such salaries.
  2. The board of county commissioners, or boards of county commissioners when counties have consolidated pursuant to W.S. 18-3-301(b), may prohibit county and prosecuting attorneys or their deputies from engaging in the private practice of law directly or indirectly. This section shall not prohibit the county and prosecuting attorney from completing all civil cases not in conflict with the interests of the county or counties, in which he is counsel and pending in court before he takes office.
  3. The county attorney shall not receive any fee from or prosecute or defend any individual or corporation in any civil or criminal suit or proceeding at law in which this state or his county or counties may be a party.
  4. If the attorney fails, neglects or refuses to perform any official duties enjoined upon him by law he and his sureties are liable on his official bond in a sum not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), in the discretion of the court having jurisdiction.
  5. Repealed by Laws 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 2.
  6. Repealed by Laws 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 21, § 3.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. VIII, § 4; Laws 1882, ch. 45, § 18; R.S. 1887, § 1896; R.S. 1899, § 1107; C.S. 1910, § 1208; C.S. 1920, § 1454; R.S. 1931, § 30-405; C.S. 1945, § 27-604; W.S. 1957, § 18-114; Laws 1975, ch. 195, § 2; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 21, § 3; Sp. Sess., ch. 22, §§ 1, 2; 2010, ch. 69, § 203.

Cross references. —

For constitutional provision that all state, city, county, town and school officers (with certain exceptions) shall be paid fixed and definite salaries, see art. 14, §§ 1 and 2, Wyo. Const.

For provisions that legislature shall designate and fix salaries of county officers, see art. 14, § 3, Wyo. Const.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, in (a), substituted “once every four (4) years” for “not later than June 1, 1978, and each four (4) years thereafter.”

Editor's notes. —

Section 2, ch. 195, Laws 1975, would have amended provisions of W.S. 1957 similar to this section, effective January 1, 1978. However, § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, revised such provisions, also effective January 1, 1978.

Section 18, ch. 45, Laws 1882, did not specifically amend § 4, art. VIII, ch. 28, C.L. 1876. Prior to the enactment of ch. 45, Laws 1882, the first part of this section provided as follows: “Each county attorney shall receive such fees as may be allowed him by law, ….” Section 18, ch. 45, Laws 1882, provided a salary and fee schedule for county and prosecuting attorneys. As a result the compilers of the 1899 Revised Statutes inserted the words “and prosecuting” and “or salary or both.” The salary and fee schedule fixed by the 1882 act is now obsolete.

In general. —

The county and prosecuting attorney is attorney for the state and not the attorney for the defendant. Ross v. State, 8 Wyo. 351, 57 P. 924, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1899).

Injunction. —

Where an injunction was issued restraining the county and prosecuting attorney from prosecuting a party for violating the anti-gambling law, the bond or undertaking properly ran to the attorney individually, as neither the state nor the county was a party. Littleton v. Burgess, 16 Wyo. 58, 91 P. 832, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 1907).

Applied in

State v. Hambrick, 65 Wyo. 1, 196 P.2d 661, 1948 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (1948).

Cited in

State ex rel. Cone v. Bernweiser, 39 Wyo. 314, 271 P. 13, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 98 (1928).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Constitutionality and construction of statute prohibiting a prosecuting attorney from engaging in the private practice of law, 6 ALR3d 562.

Disqualification of prosecuting attorney in state criminal case on account of relationship with accused, 42 ALR5th 581.

§ 18-3-304. Travel allowances.

When any county attorney is called upon to render services for the county outside of his county or consolidation of counties, or within his county or consolidation of counties at a distance of more than ten (10) miles from the county seat, or more than ten (10) miles from his own residence, he may in the discretion of the board or boards of county commissioners receive his actual and necessary traveling expenses as provided by W.S. 9-3-103 in attending to such services, in addition to his salary as county attorney.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 63, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1109; C.S. 1910, § 1210; C.S. 1920, § 1456; R.S. 1931, § 30-407; Laws 1935, ch. 41, § 1; 1939, ch. 100, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 27-607; W.S. 1957, § 18-116; Laws 1975, ch. 141, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; ch. 195, § 2; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 1; 2004, ch. 130, § 1.

The 2004 amendment substituted “W.S. 9-3-103” for “W.S. 9-1-118.”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

Editor's notes. —

Section 2, ch. 195, Laws 1977, would have amended provisions of W.S. 1957 similar to his section, effective January 1, 1978. However, § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, revised such provisions, also effective January 1, 1978.

Chapter 41, Laws 1935, consists of 5 sections and relates to fees and expenses of county attorneys, sheriffs, constables, witnesses and other public officers. For other sections of this act in this compilation, see the Table of Disposition of Acts.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

This section applies only when service is rendered for the county. Wyoming State Treasurer ex rel. Workmen's Compensation Dep't v. Christiansen, 491 P.2d 1251, 1971 Wyo. LEXIS 273 (Wyo. 1971).

§ 18-3-305. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1890, ch. 73, § 149, related to assistant prosecutors.

Article 4. County Clerks

  • § 18-3-401.  Office created; election.
  • § 18-3-402.  Duties generally.

Cross references. —

As to appointment of clerk by commissioners in connection with the formation of a new county, see § 18-1-306.

As to salary of county clerk, see § 18-3-107.

For duty of county clerk to notify county attorney of appeal from board of commissioners on disallowance of claim, see § 18-3-513.
