For duty of county clerk to endorse a certificate upon viaduct and subway bonds, see § 18-4-406.

As to hours of labor for state and county employees, see § 27-5-101.

For authority of county clerks and deputies to administer oaths, see § 1-2-102.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

15A Am. Jur. 2d Clerks of Court § 1 et seq.; 56 Am. Jur. 2d Municipal Corporations, Counties, etc. §§ 90, 91, 235; 66 Am. Jur. 2d Records and Recording Laws §§ 1 to 81.

20 C.J.S. Counties §§ 97 to 142.

§ 18-3-401. Office created; election.

There shall be elected in each county a county clerk, who shall be a resident of the county in which the county clerk serves, beginning on the first day of the term and through the last day of the term for which the county clerk serves.

History.

Laws 1890-91, ch. 54, § 1; 1895, ch. 73, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1136; C.S. 1910, § 1237; C.S. 1920, § 1484; R.S. 1931, § 30-501; Laws 1937, ch. 85, § 2; C.S. 1945, § 27-701; W.S. 1957, § 18-118; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2021 ch. 165, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, added ", who shall be a resident of the county in which the county clerk serves, beginning on the first day of the term and through the last day of the term for which the county clerk serves."

Editor's notes. —

The office of county clerk was originally created by ch. 28, C.L. 1876.

Chapter 85, Laws 1937, consisting of 13 sections, was a general law providing for the terms and election of county officers. Sections 1 (assessor) and 9 (elections) were repealed by § 3, ch. 164, Laws 1945, and § 21, ch. 127, Laws 1951, respectively. For the remaining sections appearing herein see the Table of Disposition of Acts.

Applicability. —

Laws 2021, ch. 165, § 2, provides: "The residency requirements of this act shall apply to elected or appointed county officers whose terms commence on or after the effective date of this act."

Allegation of malfeasance insufficient. —

Allegation at close of an indictment that a defendant county clerk “was then and there unlawfully and corruptly guilty of malfeasance” is insufficient. McCarthy v. Territory, 1 Wyo. 311, 1876 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1876).

Nature of duties imposed by law. —

When duties are imposed upon a public officer, such as a county clerk, by law rather than by some appointing power, such duties are usually governmental and not ministerial. Denver Buick v. Pearson, 465 P.2d 512, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 157 (Wyo. 1970).

When county clerk's bond protects; ministerial duties. —

A county clerk's bond protects if the official misappropriates public funds, because there would be no immunity in such a case. It also protects when a county clerk or his deputies default in the performance of ministerial duties. A duty is ministerial when the law prescribes the mode and occasion of its performance with such certainty that nothing is left to judgment or discretion — a duty not involving official discretion. Spaniol Ford, Inc. v. Froggatt, 478 P.2d 598, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 1970).

The issuance of a certificate of title to a motor vehicle by a county clerk is a governmental function. Spaniol Ford, Inc. v. Froggatt, 478 P.2d 598, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 1970).

The county clerk is cloaked with governmental immunity in the performance of such a duty. Spaniol Ford, Inc. v. Froggatt, 478 P.2d 598, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 1970).

Bonding company not liable if principal is immune from suit. —

There is no authority in this state for holding a county clerk's bonding company liable for an act or default of the county clerk when the county clerk is immune from suit. It would be an anomaly to hold the bonding company liable if its principal is not liable. Spaniol Ford, Inc. v. Froggatt, 478 P.2d 598, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 1970).

Liability on county clerk's bond. —

There can be no liability on a county clerk's bond unless the county clerk is liable for some default. In the absence of a statute imposing liability, a clerk is not liable for defaults or negligent acts of himself or deputies in the performance of governmental duties imposed by statute. Spaniol Ford, Inc. v. Froggatt, 478 P.2d 598, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 1970).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Liability of county clerk or prothonotary, or surety on bond, for negligent or wrongful acts of deputies or assistants, 71 ALR2d 1140.

§ 18-3-402. Duties generally.

  1. The county clerk shall:
    1. Act as clerk to the board of county commissioners and as such shall:
      1. Attend all sessions of the board of county commissioners either in person or by deputy;
      2. Keep the seal, records and papers of the board of county commissioners;
      3. Keep a record of all proceedings of the board;
      4. Make regular entries of all the board’s resolutions, orders and decisions in all questions coming before it;
      5. Sign all orders issued by the board for the payment of money and preserve and file all accounts acted upon by the board with a memorandum of its action thereon;
      6. Perform other duties as required by the board of county commissioners.
    2. Keep a record of all licenses, except marriage licenses, giving the names of the persons to whom such licenses are issued with the date, amount and purpose for which the license was issued;
    3. Keep blank county warrants or blank orders which shall be properly filled out before any warrants are delivered. He shall not deliver any warrant until it is properly signed by the chairman of the board of county commissioners, countersigned by the county treasurer and attested by himself with the county seal;
    4. Keep a seal provided  by the board of county commissioners, the impression, ink stamp or digital equivalent of  which shall contain the words “The State of Wyoming, County  Clerk”, together with the name of the county;
    5. Designate upon every account audited and allowed the amount allowed and file such accounts as well as those not allowed in separate accounts. He shall not sign or issue any county warrants unless ordered by the board of county commissioners. He shall number each warrant issued;
    6. Have custody and keep all books, records, deeds, maps, papers and copies thereof deposited or kept in his office as required by law. All deeds, mortgages, and other instruments in writing authorized by law to be recorded or filed in his office and left in his office shall be:
      1. Recorded in distinct handwriting or by typing, photostating, photographing, printing or other reproduction, either in whole or in part, in suitable books; or
      2. Recorded on microfilm, microcards or other permanent record retention medium. All reproduction processes shall be instituted and used pursuant to W.S. 9-2-413. Maps may either be recorded as herein provided or if the copying is unlikely to provide a satisfactory record, the county clerk may keep the originals or tracings thereof, undamaged and unfolded and make prints available for public use.
    7. Record any deed containing a metes and bounds description which may be accompanied by a map prepared in compliance with law and delineating the land described in the deed. If a map delineating the land has been previously recorded, the deed may make reference to the recorded map;
    8. Require any person presenting a document for recording which is legible but not sufficiently clear to produce a readable copy to substitute a clear original or legible true copy of the original document;
    9. Keep in his office a general index, direct and inverted, in which he shall make correct entries of every instrument recorded or filed under appropriate headings, entering the names of the grantors and grantees in alphabetical order. He shall make correct entries in the index of every instrument required by law to be entered therein. He shall immediately note in the appropriate index whenever any mortgage, bond or other instrument has been released or discharged from record, whether by written release or by recording a deed of release;
    10. Keep a record specifying the time of reception, the names of the grantors, the names of the grantees, from whom received, to whom delivered and the fees received:
      1. Whenever any instrument is received for recording, immediately endorse upon the instrument his certificate, noting the day, hour and minute of its reception, the reference where recorded, the fees received for recording and date of record;
      2. The date of record of all instruments requiring recording or filing shall be the date of filing;
      3. Whenever any instrument has been filed the county clerk shall immediately make an entry of the same, and after the instrument requiring recording is recorded he shall immediately deliver it to the person authorized to receive it;
      4. No county clerk shall perform any of these duties unless any required fee has been paid.
    11. Keep abstract records in which all transfers and mortgages of real property and all liens upon real estate are briefly entered. All instruments affecting real estate and left for record or filed in the office shall be abstracted against all lands described in the instrument either directly or by reference to another properly recorded instrument as soon as practicable in the order in which received:
      1. The county clerk shall enter in the abstract all recorded transfers of real estate and all mortgages, construction liens and judgment liens;
      2. All abstract entries of land shall describe the legal division of land or subdivision, naming section, township and range according to the United States surveys when the same is described in the instrument filed for record. The abstract entries shall include:
        1. The name of the grantor or grantee;
        2. The name of the mortgagor or mortgagee or the parties thereto;
        3. The character of the instrument;
        4. The consideration stated in the instrument;
        5. The date of the instrument;
        6. The date of filing in the clerk’s office;
        7. The description of the premises;
        8. Repealed by Laws 2019, ch. 3, §  2.
      3. All abstract entries of town lots shall be made in a similar manner to those of lands and shall reference the number of the lot and block.
    12. File or file  and record every notice, abstract or statement of any lien or claim  or release or discharge thereof in favor of the United States or any  department or bureau thereof as provided by the laws of the United  States when any such instrument has been prepared in conformity to  the laws of the United States and is presented for filing or filing  and recording:
      1. The county clerk shall number such notices, abstracts or statements in the order in which they are filed and if they are required to be recorded he shall record them in accordance with subparagraph (xi)(B) of this subsection, with the character of the instrument being called “federal lien”;
      2. No fee shall be charged for the performance of these services and the failure to file, record or index properly the notice, abstract or statement shall not affect the validity or legality of any such lien, claim, release or discharge.
    13. Accept and use as official records, when furnished to him without charge, records containing printed forms of water right contracts, forms for subscription to the stock of corporations or associations whereby water rights are acquired and forms of deeds of water rights from all corporations and water user associations organized for constructing, maintaining or operating ditches, reservoirs or other water works for irrigation, mining, milling or power purposes;
    14. Issue certificates under the seal of the county relating to the selection or relinquishment of state or school lands required by the state board of land commissioners without requiring the payment of fees:
      1. At the request of the state board of land commissioners the county clerk shall record and abstract all contracts between the United States and the state of Wyoming. All deeds, relinquishments or assignments executed by the authority of the state board of land commissioners shall be executed under his seal without requiring the payment of fees.
    15. Endorse a certificate upon every bond or evidence of debt issued pursuant to law that the same is within the lawful debt limit of the county and is issued according to law. Such certificates shall be signed in his official character;
    16. Collect and remit to the county treasurer the following fees:
      1. Recording charges for any instrument — first page  . . . . . $12.00
      2. Abstract of personal property (per year) . . . . . $1.00
      3. Acknowledgments  . . . . . $2.00
      4. Bond oath and notary public commission — first page  . . . . . $12.00
      5. Military discharge and separation papers
      6. Marriage license  . . . . . $30.00
      7. Marriage license certified copy  . . . . . $5.00
      8. Repealed by Laws 2002, Sp. Sess., ch. 96, § 2.
      9. Certification  . . . . . $5.00
      10. State tax liens  . . . . . $20.00
      11. Additional recording charge for any instrument with more than five (5)
      12. Additional recording charge for each section (including quarter and quarter-quarter, if applicable), block, lot or tract —
      13. Plats filed (including cemeteries and amended plats)  . . . . . $75.00
      14. Liens filed pursuant to Title 29 — first page  . . . . . $12.00
      15. Filing charge for each corner record or certificate  . . . . . $5.00
      16. Recording charge for any instrument containing more than
      17. Liens filed upon real property pursuant to W.S. 20-6-106(y) . . . . . $12.00
      18. For filing and indexing an original financing and termination statement  . . . . . $20.00
      19. For statements of amendment, continuation or assignment  . . . . . $5.00
      20. For lien search and certification of filings of record and affixing the seal  . . . . . $20.00
      21. Repealed by Laws 2010, ch. 69, § 204.
    17. Permit any person authorized by the board of county commissioners of any new county or of any bonded abstract company, and at the expense of the new county or abstract company, to examine the records of all deeds, mortgages, maps and other instruments which affect any property located within the boundaries of the new county, and to transcribe,photograph or reproduce the same:
      1. The county clerk shall compare the transcribed,photographed or reproduced instruments in his office and shall certify to the county clerk of the new county or the abstract company that they are true and correct copies of the originals. The county clerk certifying the instruments shall not receive any additional payment for time spent in comparing and certifying the instruments. All expenses shall be paid by the new county;
      2. The county clerk of the new county or the bonded abstract company shall index and abstract all transcribed,photographed or reproduced instruments in accordance with paragraphs (vi) through (xii) of this subsection which shall be received in evidence and have the same effect as if they had been originally filed in the new county.
    18. Deliver upon the written demand of the county clerk of any new county all records containing abstracts of lands in townships lying wholly within the boundaries of the new county and all records containing abstracts of townsites and town lots lying wholly within the boundaries of the new county together with the plats of the townsites or town lots. When the county clerk of the new county has received the records and abstracts they shall become a part of the records of the new county and no further abstracts of the instruments are required;
    19. Repealed by Laws 2010, ch. 34, § 2.
    20. Deliver to his successor in office all books, records, papers and other items belonging to his office;
    21. Remit all monies coming into his office to the county treasurer;
    22. Perform other duties as prescribed by law, as county clerk and register of deeds;
    23. Perform all duties or general accounting required to implement the Uniform Municipal Fiscal Procedures Act [§§ 16-4-101 to 16-4-124];
    24. File maps as defined in W.S. 33-29-801. The county clerk shall charge a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for filing the maps;
    25. If the county clerk accepts electronic recordings of deeds, mortgages, conveyances, patents, certificates, instruments and other like documents, establish procedures to govern the electronic recordings consistent with rules promulgated by the department of enterprise technology services pursuant to W.S. 34-1-405.
  2. No individual, corporation or governmental entity is exempt from payment of fees in advance.
  3. A county clerk may charge a reasonable fee for a copy or a reproduction of a public record, but the fee shall not exceed the actual cost of duplication of the record. As used in this subsection, “actual cost of duplication” means the cost of materials and supplies used to duplicate or reproduce the record, but shall not include the cost of labor or the overhead associated with the duplication.
  4. Each county clerk shall, after receiving a proposed budget for a special district or other specified entity under W.S. 9-1-507(a)(viii), ensure that the proposed budget is forwarded to the board of county commissioners and county assessor.

Each additional page . . . . . $3.00

Each additional page . . . . . $3.00

(first recording) . . . . . No Charge

(L) Release of state tax liens . . . . . INCLUDED IN FILING FEE

grantors or grantees of a different surname or more than five (5) claim names — each

additional name . . . . . $1.00

description in excess of ten (10) . . . . . $1.00

Each additional page . . . . . $3.00

two (2) real estate descriptions by book and page only — each

additional description . . . . . $2.00

Each additional page . . . . . $3.00

Additional recording charge for each additional collateral description . . . . . $1.00

For each additional certificate of title upon which

the lien is note for perfection . . . . . $1.00

History.

Sess., ch. 17, § 2; 1987, ch. 23, § 1; 1989, ch. 44, § 1; 1991, ch. 107, § 1; 1993, ch. 192, § 1; 1995, ch. 158, § 1; 2002 Sp. Sess., ch. 96, §§ 1, 2; 2004, ch. 130, § 1; 2009, ch. 168, § 206; 2010, ch. 34, § 2; ch. 69, § 204; 2013 ch. 11, § 2, effective July 1, 2013; 2016 ch. 60, § 2, effective January 1, 2017; 2017 ch. 62, § 2, effective July 1, 2017; 2019 ch. 3, §§ 1, 2, effective July 1, 2019; 2021 ch. 149, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, in (a)(xxii), deleted “either” preceding “as county clerk” and deleted “or as ex officio register of deeds” from the end.

The second 2010 amendment, by ch. 69, § 204, effective July 1, 2010, repealed former (a)(xvi)(Y), pertaining to obsolete filing and indexing termination statements.

While neither amendment gave effect to the either, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2013 amendments. —

The first 2013 amendment, by ch. 11, § 2, effective July 1, 2013, substituted “33-29-801” for “33-29-139” in (a)(xxiv).

The second 2013 amendment, by ch. 77, § 1, effective July 1, 2013, in (a)(vii) substituted “five dollars ($5.00)” for “two dollars ($2.00)”; in deleted “or the county clerk may prepare a true copy by handwriting or typewriting and attach the same to the original as part of the document for making the permanent photographic record. The county clerk shall charge a fee of fifty cents ($.50) per one hundred (100) words for preparing a true copy,” rewrote (xvi); and in (xxiv) “fifty dollars ($50.00)” and “twenty-five dollars ($25.00).”

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2019 amendments. —

in (a)(iii), deleted “a book of” and “with a blank margin” and added “blank”; in (a)(iv), added “ink stamp or digital equivalent”; in (a)(vii), deleted “The county clerk shall charge a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for recording these maps”; in (a)(ix), deleted “in the proper column and opposite the entry”; in the introductory language in (a)(x), substituted “record” for “receiving book, each page of which is divided into six (6) columns,” in (a)(x)(A), substituted “reference” for “book and page”; in (a)(x)(C), deleted “writing the name of the person to whom it is delivered in the appropriate column”; in the introductory language in (a)(xi), substituted “records” for “books provided by the board of county commissioners”; in (a)(xi)(C), substituted “and” for “but,” “reference” for “be in a separate book provided by the board of county commissioners and,” deleted “shall appear in the headlines”; in (a)(xii)(A), substituted “accordance with subparagraph (xi)(B) of this subsection, with the character of the instrument being called ‘federal lien’ ” for “a well bound book to be called ‘federal lien record.’ All instruments which require filing or recording shall be indexed alphabetically under the names of the persons named or affected in a well bound book called ‘index to federal liens’ ”; in (a)(xiii), substituted “records” for “record books” and “records” for “books,” added “to,” deleted “The charge for recording such instruments is ten cents ($.10) per folio of one hundred (100) words actually written in pen and ink or typewritten,” and made related changes; in the introductory language in (a)(xvii), substituted “transcribe, photograph or reproduce” for “transcribe or photograph,” and deleted “in books provided by the new county or abstract company”; in (a)(xvii)(A), in the first sentence, substituted “transcribed, photographed or reproduced” for “transcribed or photographed,” substituted “instruments” for “transcripts or photographs” and “any additional payment” for “fifty cents ($.50) per hour,” and added “not” after “shall”; in (a)(xvii)(B), deleted “in the proper books,” substituted “transcribed, photographed or reproduced” for “transcribed or photographed,” and added “in accordance with paragraphs (vi) through (xii) of this subsection”; in (a)(xviii), substituted “records” for “books of record” and “records” for “books.”

The second 2019 amendment, by ch. 3, § 2, effective July 1, 2019, repealed former (a)(xi)(B)(VIII), which read: “Other pertinent remarks as will show the instrument was properly witnessed and acknowledged.”

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, added “$” preceding the dollar values throughout (a)(xvi).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subparagraph (a)(xvi)(B), (a)(xvi)(I) or (a)(xvi)(V) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Effective date. —

Laws 2016, ch. 60 § 4, makes the act effective January 1, 2017. Approved March 4, 2016.

Applicability of section. —

Former section 18-142.1 requiring county clerk to compile list of qualified jurors was not applicable to a trial held in August, 1973, following the passage and approval of the section in March, 1973, because the section did not require its mandate to be fulfilled until the following January. Boyd v. State, 528 P.2d 287, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 247 (Wyo. 1974), cert. denied, 423 U.S. 871, 96 S. Ct. 137, 46 L. Ed. 2d 102, 1975 U.S. LEXIS 2819 (U.S. 1975).

Construction.—

Use of the word shall in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 29-6-206(a)(ii) (2017), as well as in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-3-402(a)(xii), means the county clerk’s recording obligation is mandatory, not discretionary. Tuttle v. Lee, 2018 WY 104, 425 P.3d 998, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 108 (Wyo. 2018).

Clerk authority.—

District court properly dismissed a property owner’s declaratory judgment action seeking to require a county clerk to remove a notice of federal tax lien (NFTL) from the property record where the clerk had a mandatory obligation under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 29-6-206(a)(ii) and 18-3-402(a)(xii) to file the NFTL, and nothing in her general statutory authority or her authority under the Uniform Federal Lien Registration Act, Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 29-6-201 et seq. (2017), permitted her to independently question the underlying validity of the NFTL, remove it from the property record, or record a document declaring it invalid. Tuttle v. Lee, 2018 WY 104, 425 P.3d 998, 2018 Wyo. LEXIS 108 (Wyo. 2018).

Attendance at board proceedings. —

Although no detailed agenda was required for administrative meetings of board of county commissioners with its staff, county clerk was required to attend executive sessions to make minutes and preserve a record of those meetings. Fontaine v. Board of County Comm'rs, 4 P.3d 890, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 92 (Wyo. 2000).

Liability on county clerk's bond. —

There can be no liability on a county clerk's bond unless the county clerk is liable for some default. In the absence of a statute imposing liability, a clerk is not liable for defaults or negligent acts of himself or deputies in the performance of governmental duties imposed by statute. Spaniol Ford, Inc. v. Froggatt, 478 P.2d 598, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 1970).

When county clerk's bond protects; ministerial duties. —

A county clerk's bond protects if the official misappropriates public funds, because there would be no immunity in such a case. It also protects when a county clerk or his deputies default in the performance of ministerial duties. A duty is ministerial when the law prescribes the mode and occasion of its performance with such certainty that nothing is left to judgment or discretion — a duty not involving official discretion. Spaniol Ford, Inc. v. Froggatt, 478 P.2d 598, 1970 Wyo. LEXIS 216 (Wyo. 1970).

Cost of new county records. —

In an action to fix the liabilities and property between an old and a new county carved therefrom, this section was cited to the effect that there was no provision therein for apportioning the cost of the new county in securing the records. Board of Comm'rs v. Board of Comm'rs, 25 Wyo. 172, 166 P. 674, 1917 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1917).

Rule that subsequent grantee not required to search records anterior to vesting of title in his grantor not applicable in view of this section. —

The rule that a subsequent grantee is not required to search the records in point of time anterior to the vesting of the legal title in his grantor is based on the reason that a duty should not be imposed on him of examining the records indefinitely. Such rule does not apply in this state since this section 18-3-402 requires an abstract of each and every instrument left for record, so that anyone interested in any tract of land may turn to the proper page of the abstract, and find almost at a glance, a description of every instrument, whether anterior or subsequent to the vesting of the legal title in his grantor. Balch v. Arnold, 9 Wyo. 17, 59 P. 434, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1899).

Presumption of compliance. —

Where petition in action against county alleged that plaintiff, a practicing physician, to save the life of a person who was injured, amputated his arm, and gave him proper surgical and medical attention, and that such medical and surgical attention was reasonably worth a certain sum; that plaintiff filed with the county clerk a verified claim, but that a copy of the claim was not attached to the petition, for the reason that it had been mislaid or lost, a reasonable construction of the petition showed that the account must have been presented for allowance in accordance with the statute. Board of Comm'rs v. Denebrink, 15 Wyo. 342, 89 P. 7, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1907).

Prima facie evidence. —

Original instruments on file in county clerk's office as well as copies thereof are admissible as prima facie evidence. Universal Credit Co. v. Wyoming Motor Co., 59 Wyo. 80, 136 P.2d 512, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 6 (Wyo. 1943).

Parol evidence permitted. —

Where this section 18-3-402 required the county clerk to record all proceedings of the county commissioners, a particular proceeding, omitted from the record, may be established by parol evidence, as the section did not make such record the only evidence of the official acts of the board. Board of Comm'rs v. Stone, 7 Wyo. 280, 51 P. 605, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (Wyo. 1898).

Applied in

Dorador v. State, 573 P.2d 839, 1978 Wyo. LEXIS 257 (Wyo. 1978).

Cited in

Board of Comm'rs v. Stone, 7 Wyo. 280, 51 P. 605, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 3 (1898); Appel v. State ex rel. Shutter-Cottrell, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (1900); Board of County Comm'rs v. Denebrink, 15 Wyo. 342, 89 P. 7, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 14, 9 L.R.A. (n.s.) 1234 (1907); Board of County Comm'rs v. Patrick, 18 Wyo. 130, 104 P. 531, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (1909).

Law reviews. —

For a note dealing with title examination of conveyances by strangers to title, see 1 Wyo. L.J. 119.

See comment, “Subsidence Regulations,” VI Land & Water L. Rev. 543 (1971).

See article, “Governmental Immunity from Damage Actions in Wyoming,” VII Land & Water L. Rev. 229 (1972).

See comment, “Remedial Title Legislation for Wyoming,” VII Land & Water L. Rev. 561 (1972).

See “Mining Patent Application Procedure,” IX Wyo. L.J. 240.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity of requirement or practice of selecting prospective jurors exclusively from list of registered voters, 80 ALR3d 869.

Library References.

American Law of Mining, 2nd Edition § 92.03 (Matthew Bender).

Article 5. County Commissioners

  • § 18-3-506.  Seal; meetings open to public; rules and regulations.
  • § 18-3-507.  Selection of chairman.
  • § 18-3-508.  Chairman to administer oaths and sign orders.
  • § 18-3-509.  Fire protection.
  • § 18-3-510.  Claims against county to be itemized and verified; penalty.
  • § 18-3-511.  Presentation, auditing and payment of claims; issuance of tax-anticipation warrants; limitation and form of warrants; effect of acceptance.
  • § 18-3-512.  [Repealed.]
  • § 18-3-513.  Appeal on disallowance of claim.

  • § 18-3-515.  Preparation and publication of annual statements.
  • § 18-3-516.  Publication of proceedings; publication of salary information of certain officials and employees.
  • § 18-3-517.  Designation of official paper.
  • § 18-3-518.  Legal advertising; rates; type size requirements; “daily newspaper”; “weekly newspaper.”
  • § 18-3-519.  Requirements as to newspaper publishing legal notices.
  • § 18-3-520.  Restrictions upon employment of attorneys.

Cross references. —

As to county commissioners in relation to organization of new counties, see §§ 18-1-301 to 18-1-320.

As to general provisions relating to county officers, see §§ 18-3-101 to 18-3-112.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

§ 18-3-501. Composition; election for increasing the number; term; quorum; election for districting; procedures.

  1. Each board of county commissioners shall consist of three (3) qualified electors who shall be elected in the following manner: at the general election held in the year 1980 and every fourth year thereafter, there shall be elected one (1) commissioner for a term of four (4) years and at the general election held in the year of 1978 and every fourth year thereafter there shall be elected two (2) commissioners for a term of four (4) years each. Any two (2) members of the board constitute a quorum and are competent to act. In addition to the other residency requirements imposed by this section, each county commissioner shall be a resident of the county in which the county commissioner serves, beginning on the first day of the term and through the last day of the term for which the county commissioner serves.
  2. Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, any county may increase the membership of its board of county commissioners from three (3) to five (5) members if a proposition for the increase is submitted to a vote of the qualified electors of the county and a majority of those casting their ballots vote in favor of the increase. Additional offices created under this subsection shall be filled at the general election next following the election at which the increase was approved. At that general election, not more than one (1) commissioner shall be elected for a term of two (2) years, and the election ballots shall so state. Each term shall otherwise be four (4) years.
  3. The proposition to increase the membership of the board of county commissioners shall be at the expense of the county and be submitted to the electors of the county upon receipt by the county clerk of a petition requesting the election signed by at least ten percent (10%) of the qualified electors of the county. To be counted the electors shall be registered voters when the completed petition is submitted for verification. The number of electors required shall be determined by the number of votes cast at the last general election. The election shall be at the direction and under the supervision of the county clerk. The petition shall be in substantially the following form:
  4. The proposition may be submitted at any general election . A notice of election shall be given in at least one (1) newspaper of general circulation published in the county wherein the election is to be held and shall specify the object of the election. The notice shall be published at least once each week for a thirty (30) day period preceding the election. At the election the ballots shall contain the words “for increasing the membership of the board of county commissioners from three (3) to five (5) members”, and “against increasing the membership of the board of county commissioners from three (3) to five (5) members”.
  5. If a county votes to increase the membership of its board of county commissioners under subsection (b) of this section, three (3) members of the board constitute a quorum and are competent to act.
  6. Any county may decrease the membership of its board of county commissioners from five (5) to three (3) members in the same petition and proposition process as an increase under subsections (b) and (c) of this section. The vote to decrease membership shall be in the general election preceding the election of three (3) commissioners. Notice of the election shall be given as provided in subsection (d) of this section.
  7. Any county in which the electors vote to increase the number of county commissioners from three (3) to five (5) as provided by this section may be divided into five (5) districts if a proposition for districting is submitted to a vote of the qualified electorate of the county and a majority of those casting their ballots vote in favor of the districting. The proposition for districting shall be submitted to a vote in the manner provided by subsections (c) and (d) of this section. At the election, the ballot shall contain the words “for dividing the county into five (5) county commissioner election districts” and “against dividing the county into five (5) county commissioner election districts”. The proposition to increase the number of county commissioners and the proposition for districting may appear on the ballot at the same general election, however the ballots shall state that the proposition for districting is contingent upon approval of the proposition to increase the number of commissioners. The petition required by subsection (c) of this section may contain both the proposition to increase the number of commissioners and the proposition for districting, or the propositions may be circulated and submitted on separate petitions. If the proposition for districting is not approved, the commissioners shall represent the county on at-large basis.
  8. If the proposition for districting is approved, the board of county commissioners shall devise a districting plan dividing the county into districts as nearly equal in population as practicable considering the geographic, economic and social characteristics of the county. The districting plan shall be made before March 1 next following the election at which the proposition for districting is approved and shall be effective as of March 1 the following year. The districting plan may provide that any commissioner elected after the effective date of the districting plan shall reside in and represent the district from which he is elected by the electors of that district, and, beginning January 1, 2012, that commissioners may serve at large or that district representation may be apportioned in any combination of single member, multi-member and at large representation, provided that in all cases commissioners represent a population as nearly equal as is practicable considering the geographic, economic and social characteristics of the county. Commissioners in office on the effective date of the districting plan shall serve the county at large until the regular expiration of their term. The districting plan shall designate which districts shall elect county commissioners in the general election next following the effective date of the districting plan. In any county in which the voters approved increasing the number of commissioners and districting at the same election, the districting plan shall also designate which district shall elect a county commissioner at the next general election for a term of two (2) years, as provided by subsection (b) of this section. The ballot shall state the term in the designated district to be for two (2) years. Thereafter, all terms shall be four (4) years.
  9. Appeals from the actions of the boards of county commissioners shall be as provided by law.
  10. If required to do so pursuant to a final court order or changes in population affecting the constitutionality of a current districting plan, the board of county commissioners may by resolution devise a districting or redistricting plan dividing the county into any number of districts necessary to meet the requirements of the court order or necessary to address the population changes. A districting or redistricting plan devised under this subsection may include single member or multi-member districts in which the candidates must reside and which are apportioned by population, districts in which candidates are elected at large, or any combination of districts in which candidates must reside and are apportioned by population or are elected at large provided that in all cases commissioners represent a population as nearly equal as is practicable considering the geographic, economic and social characteristics of the county. A districting or redistricting plan created under this subsection shall not be subject to a vote of the electors and shall go into effect after the next general election and shall be subject to the following:
    1. An initial districting plan created under this subsection shall provide for at least fifty-one percent (51%) of the commissioners to serve an initial term of two (2) years and the remainder to serve an initial term of four (4) years. Thereafter, all terms shall be four (4) years. The terms of all commissioners serving at the time of the approval of the districting plan shall expire at the end of the current year and all offices created under this subsection shall be filled at the general election held on the effective date of the districting plan;
    2. For a redistricting plan, commissioners in office on the effective date of the districting plan shall serve the county at large until the regular expiration of their term, if practical. The county commission shall determine whether honoring the four (4) year terms is practical.

This petition is for the purpose of requesting an election to increase the membership of the board of county commissioners from three (3) to five (5) members. If a proposition for the increase is submitted to a vote of the qualified electors of the county and a majority of those casting their ballots vote in favor of the increase, the additional offices created shall be filled at the general election held in (year). The eligible registered electors supporting the petition and numbering not less than ten percent (10%) of the total number of votes cast at the last general election in the county for which this petition is filed, are as follows: (Signature) (Printed Name) (Residence Address) (Date) VERIFICATION OF CIRCULATORS I, do hereby certify that I am a circulator of this petition, and I solely and personally circulated this petition, that all the signatures appearing herein were made in my presence from (month) (day), (year) through (month) (day), (year), and to the best of my knowledge and belief such signatures are those of the persons whose names they purport to be. (Signature) (Residence Address)

Click to view

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 8; Laws 1890-91, ch. 57, § 1; 1899, ch. 11, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1056; Laws 1901, ch. 35, § 1; C.S. 1910, § 1162; C.S. 1920, § 1408; R.S. 1931, § 30-601; Laws 1937, ch. 85, § 3; 1939, ch. 39, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 27-801; W.S. 1957, § 18-144; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1983, ch. 107, § 1; 1985, ch. 161, § 1; 2003, ch. 157, § 1; 2011, ch. 78, § 1; 2013 ch. 64, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; 2021 ch. 165, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (h), deleted “five (5)” preceding “districts” in the first sentence, and substituted the third sentence for the former one, which read: “Any commissioner elected after the effective date of the districting plan shall reside in and represent the district from which he is elected by the electors of that district”; and added (k).

The 2013 amendment, effective July 1, 2013, in (b) deleted “in odd-numbered years” in the second sentence, and deleted the third sentence; in (c) added the form; in (d) substituted the period for “or at an election date authorized under W.S. 22-21-103” in the first sentence; in (f) substituted “petition and proposition process” for “manner” in the first sentence, and deleted “ or at an election date authorized under W.S. 22-21-103 in the second sentence; in (g) substituted the comma for “or at an election date authorized under W.S. 22-21-103” in the fourth sentence.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, added the second sentence in (a).

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (i) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

The basic law establishing county officers and government was ch. 28, C.L. 1876.

Chapter 85, Laws 1937, was a general law relating to terms of county officers.

Applicability. —

Laws 2021, ch. 165, § 2, provides: "The residency requirements of this act shall apply to elected or appointed county officers whose terms commence on or after the effective date of this act."

Expenses. —

The county commissioners are entitled to the per diem compensation prescribed for the time actually and necessarily employed in going to and from regular and special meetings of the board. Board of Comm'rs v. Blakely, 20 Wyo. 259, 123 P. 72, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1912).

One-year contracts. —

Contract with county agricultural agent for 3 year term is unauthorized, as it would extend to time when personnel of the board of county commissioners would be changed and contracts for expenditure of county funds must be limited to 1 year. Hyde v. Board of Comm'rs, 47 Wyo. 101, 31 P.2d 75, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 9 (Wyo. 1934).

Propositions. —

Lawsuit was an election contest governed by Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 22-17-105 and 22-17-106 because it asked the court to (1) declare null and void an election in which voters passed a proposition returning the size of the county commission to three and (2) direct the county clerk to hold an election based on a board composed of five members. The remedy sought would have defeated the public interest in the stability and finality of election results and could only result from a declaration that the special election was void, which was the very essence of an election contest. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

Suit by three challengers to a ballot proposition that returned the size of the county commission to three was dismissed because the challengers failed to bring the contest within the time specified in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 22-17-105 and through the five electors required. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

“Proposition” to be placed on the “ballot” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-3-501 (size of county commission) is in fact a “ballot proposition” under Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 22-17-105 and 22-17-106. Rock v. Lankford, 2013 WY 61, 301 P.3d 1075, 2013 Wyo. LEXIS 66 (Wyo. 2013).

Quoted in

Mills v. Campbell County Canvassing Bd., 707 P.2d 747, 1985 Wyo. LEXIS 588 (Wyo. 1985).

Cited in

Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Geringer, 297 F.3d 1108, 2002 U.S. App. LEXIS 15353 (10th Cir. 2002).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Practitioner's Guide to Valuation and Assessment Appeals of State and Local Assessed Property,” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 173 (1997).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

“At-large” elections as violation of § 2 of Voting Rights Act of 1965 (42 U.S.C. § 1973), 92 ALR Fed 824.

What changes in voting practices or procedures must be precleared under § 5 of Voting Rights Act of 1965 (42 U.S.C. § 1973c) — Supreme Court cases, 146 ALR Fed 619.

§ 18-3-502. Meetings in counties.

Each board of county commissioners shall meet at the county seat of their respective counties on the first Tuesday in each month or at such other times as may be designated by resolution of the board or when it is necessary to meet for the transaction of urgent county business.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 9; R.S. 1887, § 1800; R.S. 1899, § 1057; Laws 1903, ch. 11, § 1; 1905, ch. 84, § 1; C.S. 1910, § 1163; C.S. 1920, § 1409; R.S. 1931, § 30-602; C.S. 1945, § 27-802; W.S. 1957, § 18-145; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; ch. 195, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

Section 2, ch. 195, Laws 1977, would have amended provisions of W.S. 1957 similar to this section, effective January 1, 1978. However, § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, revised such provisions, also effective January 1, 1978.

Quoted in

Gold v. Board of County Comm'rs, 658 P.2d 690, 1983 Wyo. LEXIS 279 (Wyo. 1983).

Cited in

Board of Comm'rs v. Blakely, 20 Wyo. 259, 123 P. 72, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (1912).

§ 18-3-503. Length of sessions.

The board of county commissioners may sit four (4) days or longer at each regular session and two (2) days at each special session, but shall not receive any compensation for any length of time over four (4) days at regular sessions, and over two (2) days at special sessions.

History.

Laws 1905, ch. 84, § 3; C.S. 1910, § 1165; C.S. 1920, § 1411; R.S. 1931, § 30-604; C.S. 1945, § 27-804; W.S. 1957, § 18-147; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Expenses. —

Commissioners are only entitled to the per diem compensation for 4 days at regular meetings and 2 days at special meetings. Board of Comm'rs v. Blakely, 20 Wyo. 259, 123 P. 72, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1912).

§ 18-3-504. Powers and duties generally.

  1. Each board of county commissioners may:
    1. Make such orders concerning the property of the county as they deem expedient;
    2. Examine and settle all accounts of receipts and expenses of the county and examine, settle and allow all accounts against the county and issue county orders therefor as provided by law;
    3. Provide for the construction and maintenance of county buildings and insure them in the name of the county treasurer for the benefit of the county. If there are no county buildings they may provide suitable rooms for county purposes;
    4. Apportion and order the levying of taxes as provided by law;
    5. Represent the county, including but not limited to representing the county as a cooperating agency with special expertise in matters related to the National Environmental Policy Act and in federal land planning, implementation and management actions as provided for by W.S. 18-5-208(a), care for the county property and manage the business and concerns of the county in all cases where no provision is made by law;
    6. Lay out, alter or discontinue any road running through the county and for such purpose acquire the use of lands therein either by gift, prescription, dedication, the exercise of the right of eminent domain, purchase or lease and perform such other duties respecting roads as required by law;
    7. Grant licenses for keeping ferries, toll bridges and toll gates as prescribed by law;
    8. Perform such other duties as prescribed by law;
    9. By resolution, prohibit or authorize and regulate the operation of golf carts as defined by W.S. 31-5-102(a)(lxi) on public roads and streets within unincorporated areas of the county.
  2. Each board of county commissioners may provide snow removal services on any roads within the county designated as school bus routes by the board of trustees of any school district in the county.
  3. Each board of county commissioners shall provide for the burial or cremation of the human remains of any deceased person not receiving personal opportunities with employment responsibilities (POWER) assistance, supplemental security income or Medicaid under the Wyoming Public Assistance and Social Services Act at the time of death and without sufficient means in his own estate or other resources to provide burial or cremation. The amount paid under this subsection for burial or cremation shall not exceed one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). Each board shall account for the county expenses incurred under this subsection during a fiscal year. By August 1 of each year, a county may request reimbursement by the department of family services for the expenses incurred under this subsection for the preceding fiscal year. The department of family services shall reimburse the expenses in accordance with W.S. 35-1-428(c).
  4. Each board of county commissioners shall, after receiving a proposed budget for a special district or other specified entity under W.S. 18-3-402(d), ensure that the proposed budget is posted on the appropriate area of the website of the county. The posting of the budget shall include the date, time and location of a special district budget session during which final action will be taken on the proposed budget. If a proposed budget is not provided to the county clerk as required by W.S. 9-1-507(a), the board of county commissioners may not approve funding of the special district mill levy. Upon approval of the mill levy for each special district, the final approved budget shall be posted on the appropriate area of the website of the county.
  5. All bids and contracts for capital construction projects shall be in accord with the Wyoming contractor preference laws of title 16, chapter 6.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 11; R.S. 1887, § 1801; R.S. 1899, § 1058; C.S. 1910, § 1166; Laws 1905, ch. 54, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 1412; R.S. 1931, § 30-605; C.S. 1945, § 27-806; Laws 1949, ch. 137, § 1; 1951, ch. 127, § 21; W.S. 1957, § 18-149; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1978, ch. 19, § 1; 1981, ch. 174, § 2; 1986, ch. 83, § 1; 1991, ch. 235, § 1; 1997, ch. 59, § 1; ch. 196, § 1; 2012, ch. 13, § 1; 2013 ch. 45, § 1, effective July 1, 2013; 2013 ch. 134, § 1, effective July 1, 2014; 2017 ch. 62, § 2, effective July 1, 2017; 2021 ch. 33, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

Cross references. —

As to tax levy and appropriations for predatory animal district, see § 11-6-210.

As to powers and duties of commissioners concerning public highways, see § 24-1-104.

As to regulation by commissioners of motor vehicle sizes and weight limits, see § 31-18-802.

The 2012 amendment, inserted “including but not limited to representing the county as a cooperating agency with special expertise in matters related to the National Environmental Policy Act and in federal land planning, implementation and management actions as provided for by W.S. 18-5-208(a)” in (a)(v).

Laws 2012, ch. 13 § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 6, 2012.

The 2013 amendments. —

The first 2013 amendment, by ch. 45, § 1, effective July 1, 2013, added (d).

The second 2013 amendment, by ch. 134, § 1, effective July 1, 2014, added (e).

This section is set out as reconciled by the Wyoming legislative service office.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, in (c), added "or cremation" following "the burial" in the first sentence and added the second through fifth sentences.

Public Assistance and Social Services Act. —

The Public Assistance and Social Services Act, referred to in subsection (c), means Laws 1937, ch. 88, §§ 1 through 48, which appeared as various sections throughout chapters 1 and 2 of title 42, before title 42 was revised in 1988. See Table of Disposition of Acts in Volume 11 and “Revision of title” note at beginning of title 42.

Applicability. —

Laws 2021, ch. 33, § 2, provides: “This act shall only apply to expenses incurred under W.S. 18-3-504(c), 19-14-101(a) and 42-2-103(c) on or after the effective date of this act.”

For discussion of legislative and judicial history of section, see Big Horn County Comm'rs v. Hinckley, 593 P.2d 573, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 399 (Wyo. 1979).

In general. —

The board is empowered generally to represent the county, and have the management of the business and concerns of the county, in all cases where no other provision is made by law. Appel v. State, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1900).

Implied contract, nonapplicability. —

County is not liable on theory of implied contract for benefits received, to contractor who constructed road upon oral authorization from individual members of board of county commissioners when same was not a county road. George W. Condon Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 56 Wyo. 38, 103 P.2d 401, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1940).

Duty to settle accounts. —

It is the duty of the board of county commissioners of each county to examine and settle all accounts of the receipts and expenses of the county, and to examine, settle, and allow all accounts chargeable against the county, and, when so settled and allowed, to issue county orders therefor. Stoll v. Board of Comm'rs, 6 Wyo. 231, 44 P. 58, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1896).

The board has power and authority to settle all accounts against the county. Houtz v. Board of Comm'rs, 11 Wyo. 152, 70 P. 840, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1902).

Acts within scope of duties. —

Approving budgets and determining compensation for the county coroner's office are statutory functions expressly within the scope of duties required of a member of a board of county commissioners. Therefore allegations of insufficient budget allocations and determination of inadequate compensation levels could not form the basis of a claim for tortious conduct against members of a board of county commissioners. Veile v. Board of County Comm'rs, 860 P.2d 1174, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 163 (Wyo. 1993).

Allowance of claims. —

Where county commissioners contracted with attorney to defend county in court actions, allowed claim for retainer and issued certificates of indebtedness, but later passed resolution that attorneys had not rendered service, cancelled certificates and ordered treasurer not to pay them, allowance of claim and issuance of certificates did not preclude county from contesting the claim, as certificates are merely orders on the treasurer to pay when funds available, and may be revoked and payment stopped if later a defense develops which justifies recision of contract. Treasurer in a mandamus action may plead the resolution and order of commissioners as his defense. State ex rel. Robertson Inv. Co. v. Patterson, 47 Wyo. 416, 38 P.2d 617, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 1934).

County road, implied establishment. —

County road cannot be established by implication through construction thereof under invalid agreement with members of board of county commissioners, individually, when road was not of statutory width and on completion was not taken over by commissioners. George W. Condon Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 56 Wyo. 38, 103 P.2d 401, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1940).

Private roads. —

The board of county commissioners has no authority to take charge and control of a private road on behalf of the county since its powers are limited to duly established county roads. George W. Condon Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 56 Wyo. 38, 103 P.2d 401, 1940 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1940).

Acquisition by prescriptive title authorized when purpose is to lay out road, etc. —

This section authorizes boards of county commissioners to acquire title to lands by prescription in furtherance of their purpose to lay out or alter a road. Rocky Mountain Sheep Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 11, 269 P.2d 314, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1954).

Prescriptive title must be evidenced by more formal acts than public user or working of road by county. —

If a board of county commissioners relies upon the county's having obtained prescriptive title to lands within a right-of-way, or any part thereof, in order to avoid the payment of damage for their taking, the inception of such prescriptive title must be evidenced by more formal acts than the user of the road by the public or by the county's construction and maintenance of the road because, in order to be empowered to acquire such prescriptive title, the records of the county must show not only the survey plat of the road but also the proceedings of the board in relation to the road's location, establishment or alteration, thus making manifest the county's purpose to acquire the lands involved. Rocky Mountain Sheep Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 11, 269 P.2d 314, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1954).

Purpose cannot be said to exist when records fails to show necessary action. —

When county records fail to show that board has taken action necessary to legally establish a public road under §§ 24-1-101 and 24-3-118 it cannot be said that the purpose to lay out or alter such road exists. Rocky Mountain Sheep Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 73 Wyo. 11, 269 P.2d 314, 1954 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1954).

Compensation. —

Principle that the commissioners of county can only act as a board in transacting county business does not necessarily control question of their per diem compensation. Board of Comm'rs v. Blakely, 20 Wyo. 259, 123 P. 72, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1912).

When mandamus lies to compel highway repair. —

Mandamus is recognized as a proper remedy to compel public officers to take care of and keep in repair public highways only when the exercise is so apparent and obvious that the refusal to act is the result of a determination not to discharge a plain duty. Board of County Comm'rs v. State, 369 P.2d 537, 1962 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1962).

Transaction of business. —

While county commissioners can only transact business as a board, this does not necessarily control question of their per diem compensation, though such principle may properly be considered in determining meaning of provision allowing commissioners per diem pay. Board of Comm'rs v. Blakely, 20 Wyo. 259, 123 P. 72, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1912).

Commissioners can only act as a board in the transaction of business of the county at the county seat, yet a commissioner in going from his home to the meeting and returning therefrom is employed in the duties of his office. Board of Comm'rs v. Blakely, 20 Wyo. 259, 123 P. 72, 1912 Wyo. LEXIS 34 (Wyo. 1912).

Applied in

Davis v. Board of County Comm'rs, 495 P.2d 21, 1972 Wyo. LEXIS 239 (Wyo. 1972).

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Chaplin, 5 Wyo. 74, 37 P. 370, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (1894); In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (1898); Miller v. Campbell County, 722 F. Supp. 687, 1989 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11685 (D. Wyo. 1989); Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Geringer, 297 F.3d 1108, 2002 U.S. App. LEXIS 15353 (10th Cir. 2002).

§ 18-3-505. Commissioners may authorize acceptance of negotiable paper in payment of fees; negotiable paper defined; no personal liability of county officers; date of payment; effect of dishonor; seizure.

  1. Each board of county commissioners may except where expressly prohibited by law authorize any county officer, agent or employee to accept negotiable paper as defined in subsection (c) of this section including paper arising from the use of a lender credit card as defined in W.S. 40-14-140(a)(ix) in payment of any tax, assessment, license, permit, fee, fine or other money owing to the county or collectible by the county in behalf of the state or other unit of government, or in payment of any bail deposit or other trust deposit. Any fees assessed for processing a credit card payment may be borne by the county or person tendering payment. Any fees assessed for processing a credit card payment collected on behalf of the state shall be borne by the county or person tendering payment and not by the state. With respect to lender credit card transactions the county is entitled to promptly present all negotiable paper to the bank upon which the negotiable paper is drawn for payment without any right of setoff or defense on the part of the issuer except as follows:
    1. Acceptance by the county of an expired card;
    2. Acceptance of a card for payment of an amount in excess of what the issuer authorized the county to accept;
    3. Negotiable paper that is so improperly completed that the issuer cannot identify the card holder.
  2. Any defense, claim or action that an individual using negotiable paper or a lender credit card might have against issuers of the card shall not apply to the county, its officers, agents or employees or relieve the individual of responsibility for payment.
  3. As used in this section “negotiable paper” means money orders, checks and drafts, including, without limitation, sales drafts and checks and drafts signed by a holder of a lender credit card issued by a bank maintaining a revolving loan account as defined in W.S. 40-14-308, for lender credit card holders.
  4. Any county officer, agent or employee who accepts negotiable paper pursuant to and in conformity with authorization from the board of county commissioners is not personally liable if the paper is dishonored. Any losses arising from dishonored paper shall be allocated to the respective funds for which the negotiable paper was accepted. In the event of losses from dishonored paper when the county or any of its officers are collecting funds for the state or any other level or unit of government, such losses shall be allocated to and accepted by the governmental entity for whom the collections were made.
  5. The acceptance of negotiable paper constitutes conditional payment for the amount owing. If the paper is not dishonored the payment shall be effective on the date the paper was accepted by the county officer, agent or employee. If the paper is dishonored in the course of collection the conditional payment is of no effect and any receipt, certificate or license issued upon acceptance of the negotiable paper is void. In the event any property including motor vehicle license plates is transferred or issued by the county or any of its officers, agents or employees upon acceptance of negotiable paper, and the paper is subsequently dishonored the county may rescind the transaction and a sheriff or other law enforcement officer may without prior court proceedings seize the property. Neither the rescission nor seizure relieves the person presenting the negotiable paper from further civil or criminal liabilities as may be provided by law.

History.

Laws 1973, ch. 47, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1999, ch. 22, § 1; 2010, ch. 82, § 1.

The 2010 amendment, made stylistic change in (c).

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo.Const. Approved March 9, 2010

§ 18-3-506. Seal; meetings open to public; rules and regulations.

Every board of county commissioners shall have a seal and may alter it. They shall sit with open doors and all persons conducting themselves in an orderly manner may attend their meetings. They may establish rules and regulations to govern the transaction of their business.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 12; R.S. 1887, § 1802; R.S. 1899, § 1059; C.S. 1910, § 1167; C.S. 1920, § 1413; R.S. 1931, § 30-606; C.S. 1945, § 27-807; W.S. 1957, § 18-150; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to seal kept by county clerks, see § 18-3-402(a)(iv).

In general. —

All meetings of the board are public. North Laramie Land Co. v. Hoffman, 30 Wyo. 238, 30 Wyo. 239, 219 P. 561, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1923), aff'd, 268 U.S. 276, 45 S. Ct. 491, 69 L. Ed. 953, 1925 U.S. LEXIS 568 (U.S. 1925).

Stated in

State ex rel. State Hwy. Comm'n v. Meeker, 75 Wyo. 210, 294 P.2d 603, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1956);School Dist. No. 9 v. District Boundary Bd., 351 P.2d 106, 1960 Wyo. LEXIS 56 (Wyo. 1960).

Cited in

Grand Island & N.W.R.R. v. Baker, 6 Wyo. 369, 45 P. 494, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 21, 34 L.R.A. 835 (1896).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction, and application of statutes making public proceedings open to the public, 38 ALR3d 1070, 34 ALR5th 591.

Attorney-client exception under state law making proceedings by public bodies open to the public, 34 ALR5th 591.

§ 18-3-507. Selection of chairman.

The board of county commissioners shall at the first meeting after their election or appointment elect one (1) member chairman, who shall preside at all meetings, except in his absence any of the other members may act as temporary chairman.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 13; R.S. 1887, § 1803; R.S. 1899, § 1060; C.S. 1910, § 1168; C.S. 1920, § 1414; R.S. 1931, § 30-607; C.S. 1945, § 27-808; W.S. 1957, § 18-151; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2010, ch. 82, § 1.

The 2010 amendment, made stylistic change.

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2010.

Temporary chairman. —

When the chairman of the board of county commissioners is absent, the temporary chairman has authority to assist in making up the jury list. Askins v. Basil, 1933 OK 79, 162 Okla. 76, 19 P.2d 177, 1933 Okla. LEXIS 507 (Okla. 1933).

§ 18-3-508. Chairman to administer oaths and sign orders.

The chairman of the board of county commissioners may administer oaths to any person concerning any matter submitted to the board or connected with their powers and duties, and shall sign all county orders.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 14; R.S. 1887, § 1804; R.S. 1899, § 1061; C.S. 1910, § 1169; C.S. 1920, § 1415; R.S. 1931, § 30-608; C.S. 1945, § 27-809; W.S. 1957, § 18-152; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to officers authorized to administer oaths generally, see § 1-2-102.

As to authority of commissioners generally to administer oaths, see § 1-2-102.

As to manner and form of administering oath, see § 1-2-103.

§ 18-3-509. Fire protection.

  1. The board of county commissioners may provide fire protection for persons and property within the boundaries of the county, and may:
    1. Contract to give or receive fire protection to or from one (1) or more municipal corporations or private organizations;
    2. Provide fire protection jointly with one (1) or more municipal corporations or private organizations;
    3. Contribute toward the support of any fire department in return for fire protection service;
    4. Contract to participate in the emergency fire suppression account program pursuant to W.S. 36-1-401 through 36-1-404.
  2. The board of county commissioners of any county contracting with any municipal corporation, private organization or fire department in return for fire protection service may make an appropriation in its annual budget for the purchase of fire equipment or for the maintenance and support of the fire protection and may annually levy a tax of not more than one (1) mill on the taxable valuation of the property in the county except property within any incorporated city or town or rural fire district. The levy shall be made at the same time as other levies for county and school purposes and the proceeds from the levy shall be kept in a special fund by the county treasurer and used solely for the purpose of fire protection:
    1. The administration and expenditures of the special fund is the responsibility of the board of county commissioners. The board of county commissioners of any county entering into a contract with any municipal corporation or private organization shall provide that the municipal corporation or private organization shall reimburse the county for the use of fire fighting equipment on such terms as the contracting parties may agree.

History.

Laws 1961, ch. 70, §§ 1, 2; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1982, ch. 9, § 1; 1986, ch. 51, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

There is no paragraph (b)(ii) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Counties may not regulate fireworks. —

Sections 35-10-203, 18-3-509, 35-9-401 through 35-9-402, and 35-9-301 through 35-9-304 provide no grants of authority, express or implied, allowing counties to regulate fireworks. Dunnegan v. Laramie County Comm'rs, 852 P.2d 1138, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 95 (Wyo. 1993).

§ 18-3-510. Claims against county to be itemized and verified; penalty.

  1. No claim against the county shall be allowed by the board of county commissioners unless it is properly dated and itemized and the value of each item specifically described, and when no specified fees are allowed by law, the date that such services were rendered and the time actually and necessarily devoted to the performance of any service. Each claim shall be accompanied by an affidavit, stating that the claim is just and correct and that no part of the claim has been paid by the county or other person. The board of county commissioners may disallow any account, in whole or in part, when so rendered and verified, and may require further evidence of the truth and propriety of the claim. This section does not apply to claims under W.S. 1-39-101 through 1-39-120.
  2. The board of county commissioners shall be held responsible on their official bonds to the full amount of any claim allowed, to be recovered in an action of debt for the use of the county, should the evidence show that any part of any claim has been allowed by any board of county commissioners contrary to the provisions of this section.

History.

Laws 1879, ch. 32, §§ 1, 2; R.S. 1887, §§ 1805, 1806; R.S. 1899, §§ 1062, 1063; C.S. 1910, §§ 1170, 1171; C.S. 1920, §§ 1416, 1417; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-609, 30-610; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-810, 27-811; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-153, 18-154; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1979, ch. 157, § 2; 2010, ch. 82, § 1; 2017 ch. 41, § 1, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2010 amendment, substituted “1-39-121” for “1-39-119” in (a).

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2010.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in the last sentence of (a), substituted “1-39-120” for “1-39-121.”

Editor's notes. —

Section 1, ch. 32, Laws 1879, repealed § 15, art. I, ch. 28, C.L. 1876, and inserted this section in lieu thereof.

Condition precedent to action. —

Presentation to town of verified claim is necessary before commencement of action thereon against the town. Town Council of Hudson v. Ladd, 37 Wyo. 419, 263 P. 703, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1928).

Reasonable construction. —

Where petition of a doctor alleged that verified claim had been filed with the county clerk, but that copy was not attached for the reason that it had been lost or mislaid, reasonable construction of the petition showed that the account must have been presented for allowance in accordance with statute. Board of Comm'rs v. Denebrink, 15 Wyo. 342, 89 P. 7, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1907).

Requirements of presentment. —

Where attorney for one having claim against a county sent written communication to the board, demanding “recovery back” of certain money stated to have been paid into the county treasury under duress by 3 persons named, who had assigned claims against the county to the claimant but where communication was not verified, nor alleged to whom money had been paid, or other circumstances relative to the claim, there was no presentment authorizing the commissioners to act on it. Houtz v. Board of Comm'rs, 11 Wyo. 152, 70 P. 840, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1902).

Removal of commissioner. —

To justify the removal of county commissioner for payment of claim for unitemized claims, neglect should involve willful design or indicate habitual inattention to public business, since not every technical violation of statute or official duty will justify summary removal. State v. Scott, 35 Wyo. 108, 247 P. 699, 1926 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1926).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Power of county or its officials to compromise claim, 15 ALR2d 1359.

Power to remit, release, or compromise tax claim, 28 ALR2d 1425.

Waiver of, or estoppel to assert, failure to give required notice of claim of injury to municipality, county, or other governmental agency or body, 65 ALR2d 1278.

Amount of damages stated in notice of claim against municipality or county as limiting amount of recovery, 24 ALR3d 965.

§ 18-3-511. Presentation, auditing and payment of claims; issuance of tax-anticipation warrants; limitation and form of warrants; effect of acceptance.

  1. All claims and demands against a county shall be presented for audit and allowance to the board of county commissioners before any action in court is maintainable. All claims when allowed shall be paid by a county warrant or order drawn by the board on the county treasurer upon the proper funds in the treasury for the amount of the claims. The warrant or order shall be signed by the permanent or temporary chairman of the board, attested by the county clerk under the seal of the county, and countersigned and registered by the county treasurer. The warrant or order shall specify the amount of the claim or service and be numbered and dated in the order in which it is issued. Such warrants and orders are payable on demand and shall be drawn and issued upon the county treasurer only when there are sufficient monies in the appropriate fund in the treasury to pay such warrants and orders.
  2. Whenever there are no monies in the proper fund of the county treasury to meet the necessary expenses of the county, the board of county commissioners may authorize county warrants and orders to be drawn and issued in anticipation of the collection of taxes already levied. The aggregate amount of such warrants or orders may not exceed eighty percent (80%) of the total amount of taxes levied. The warrants and orders so drawn and issued shall show that they are payable solely from the fund on which they are drawn and the taxes levied to form the fund when collected. These warrants and orders do not increase the indebtedness of the county.
  3. County warrants and orders may be in such form as the county commissioners provide and made payable to the order of the payee or bearer. The person or persons to whom the warrants and orders are allowed and delivered are held to have accepted the same in full payment and satisfaction of the claim for which it was issued. The warrants shall be paid only from the fund drawn upon, and the collected taxes paid into the county treasury to create, constitute and form the fund. The taxes provided by law shall be paid into the fund until all warrants drawn are fully paid including principal and interest.

History.

Laws 1893, ch. 33, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1216; C.S. 1910, § 1128; C.S. 1920, § 1362; R.S. 1931, § 30-102; C.S. 1945, § 27-812; W.S. 1957, § 18-155; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

As amended by § 1, ch. 33, Laws 1893, this section contained a proviso clause, reading as follows: “Provided, that the provisions of this law shall in nowise affect the lawful warrants and orders of any county, which were issued prior to the passage of this law, and are outstanding and unpaid, but such warrants and the debt thereof, unless ratified as independent debts, within the limitations of the constitution, as provided by law, and redeemed under the funding statutes shall be paid, both principal and interest, in the order of their registry, from the fund on which they were drawn.”

“Claims and demands.” —

The phrase “claims and demands” embraces all claims and demands based on money demand. Houtz v. Board of Comm'rs, 11 Wyo. 152, 70 P. 840, 1902 Wyo. LEXIS 30 (Wyo. 1902).

Acceptors of warrants limited to claim against fund againstwhich issued and not against general credit. —

The intent of this section is that when warrants or certificates of indebtedness are issued against a limited fund and the fund is exhausted, no further claim against the general credit of the county shall exist on the part of those who have accepted such warrants. Ballangee v. Board of County Comm'rs, 66 Wyo. 390, 212 P.2d 71, 1949 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1949).

Debt limitation. —

The limitation of indebtedness imposed by art. 16, §§ 3, 4, Wyo. Const., providing that no county shall create any indebtedness exceeding 2 percent of the assessed value of property, and that no debt in excess of taxes for the current year shall be created by any county except by vote of the people, applies to all debts of the county, whether compulsory obligations imposed by law for salaries or bounties or voluntary obligations entered into for any purpose. Grand I. & N. W. R.R. v. Baker, 6 Wyo. 369, 45 P. 494, 1896 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1896).

Proof of presentation and rejection. —

A court was without jurisdiction to enter judgment against an executrix in the absence of pleading and proof that the claim had been presented and rejected. Delfelder v. Farmers' State Bank, 38 Wyo. 481, 269 P. 418, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 72 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 38 Wyo. 481, 269 P. 418, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 73 (Wyo. 1928).

Presentation to town. —

Presentation to town of verified claim is necessary before commencement of action thereon against the town. Town Council of Hudson v. Ladd, 37 Wyo. 419, 263 P. 703, 1928 Wyo. LEXIS 15 (Wyo. 1928).

Presumption of compliance. —

A petition for mandamus to compel chairman of board of commissioners to sign a warrant, which states that the board allowed petitioner's claim and ordered it paid, and the clerk drew warrant therefor, is not demurrable for failure to state that there were funds in the treasury to pay the same and that an itemized statement was filed, since on demurrer it will be presumed that the officers did not violate the law. Appel v. State, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1900).

Reasonable construction of petition as in accordance with statute.—
