Where in action against county, petition alleged that plaintiff, a practicing physician, in order to save the life of a person who was injured, amputated his arm, gave proper surgical and medical attention, and that such medical and surgical attention was reasonably worth a certain sum; that plaintiff filed with the county clerk a verified claim, but that a copy of the claim was not attached to the complaint for the reason that it had been mislaid, or lost, a reasonable construction of petition showed that account must have been presented for allowance in accordance with the statute. Board of Comm'rs v. Denebrink, 15 Wyo. 342, 89 P. 7, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1907).

Disallowance of claims. —

Where county commissioners contracted with attorney to defend county in court actions, allowed claim for retainer and issued certificates of indebtedness, which were registered and assigned by payees for value, but later passed resolution to effect that attorneys had not rendered service, cancelled certificates and ordered treasurer not to pay them, allowance of claim and issuance of certificates did not preclude county from contesting claim, as certificates are merely orders on the treasurer to pay when funds available, and may be revoked and payment stopped if later a defense develops which justifies rescission of contract. Treasurer in mandamus action may plead the resolution and order of commissioners as his defense. State ex rel. Robertson Inv. Co. v. Patterson, 47 Wyo. 416, 38 P.2d 617, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 1934).

Creation of new county. —

The provisions of this section for audit and allowance does not apply to the adjustment of county debts and property between a parent county and one created out of part of its territory. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Rollins & Sons, 9 Wyo. 281, 62 P. 351, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (1900); Board of County Comm'rs v. Laramie County Sch. Dist. No. One, 884 P.2d 946, 1994 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo. 1994).

§ 18-3-512. [Repealed.]

Repealed by Laws 2011, ch. 129, § 207.

Editor's Notes. —

This section, which derived from Laws 1893, ch. 33, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 1217; C.S. 1910, § 1129; C.S. 1920, § 1363; R.S. 1931, § 30-103; C.S. 1945, § 27-813; W.S. 1957, § 18-156; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1, related to separate accounts to be kept for taxes levied and collected.

Laws 2011, ch. 129, § 601, makes the act effective July 1, 2011.

Repealing clauses. —

Section 3, ch. 33, Laws 1893, repealed all laws and parts of laws in conflict therewith.

Cited in

In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (1898); Board of County Comm'rs v. Rollins & Sons, 9 Wyo. 281, 62 P. 351, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (1900).

§ 18-3-513. Appeal on disallowance of claim.

  1. When any claim against a county is disallowed by the board of commissioners, the claimant may appeal the decision of the board to the district court for the county by serving a written notice of appeal on the clerk and chairman of the board within ten (10) days after the decision, and by executing a bond to the county with sufficient security, approved by the clerk of the board, conditioned for the faithful prosecution of the appeal and payment of all costs adjudged against the appellant.
  2. When the appeal is perfected, the clerk of the board shall immediately give notice to the county attorney. The clerk shall make a brief return of the proceedings before the board with the decision properly certified and file the same together with the bond and all papers in the case in his possession with the clerk of the district court. The appeal shall be entered, tried and determined and costs awarded the same as appeals from circuit courts. This section does not apply to claims under W.S. 1-39-101 through 1-39-120.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, §§ 17, 18; R.S. 1887, §§ 1808, 1809; R.S. 1899, §§ 1064, 1065; C.S. 1910, §§ 1172, 1173; C.S. 1920, §§ 1418, 1419; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-611, 30-612; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-814, 27-815; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-157, 18-158; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1979, ch. 157, § 2; 2004, ch. 42, § 1; 2010, ch. 82, § 1; 2017 ch. 41, § 1, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2004 amendment, in (b), substituted “circuit courts” for “justice courts.”

Laws 2004, ch. 42, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 3, 2004.

The 2010 amendment, substituted “1-39-121” for “1-39-119” in (b).

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2010.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, in the last sentence of (b), substituted “1-39-120” for “1-39-121.”

Revocation of allowance of claim. —

Though county commissioners allowed claim and issued certificates of indebtedness, they may thereafter revoke allowance of claim and stop payment if they believe there is a defense to the claim. State ex rel. Robertson Inv. Co. v. Patterson, 47 Wyo. 416, 38 P.2d 617, 1934 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 1934).

Direct action in lieu of appeal. —

A claimant whose voucher to a city has been rejected may institute direct action for the recovery of the amount claimed, rather than proceeding under statute by appeal to the district court. Fanning v. City of Laramie, 402 P.2d 460, 1965 Wyo. LEXIS 144 (Wyo. 1965), commented on in 1 Land & Water L. Rev. 532 (1966).

Quoted in

Atlantic Richfield Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 569 P.2d 1267, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 318 (Wyo. 1977).

§ 18-3-514. County officers to be provided with stationery and supplies.

Each board of county commissioners at the expense of the county shall annually furnish to the county assessor and county treasurer suitable blank books and forms necessary for their respective offices prepared in accordance with law. The board shall also provide suitable books and stationery for each of the county officers together with appropriate cases, equipment and furniture for the safe and convenient keeping of all the officer’s books, documents and papers and shall provide official seals when required by law.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 19; R.S. 1887, § 1810; R.S. 1899, § 1066; C.S. 1910, § 1174; C.S. 1920, § 1420; R.S. 1931, § 30-613; C.S. 1945, § 27-816; W.S. 1957, § 18-159; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2019 ch. 3, § 1, effective July 1, 2019.

Cross references. —

As to public printing and supplies, with reference to the state generally, see § 16-6-301.

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, in the second sentence, added “equipment” after “cases.”

§ 18-3-515. Preparation and publication of annual statements.

Each board of county commissioners at their regular July meeting shall request a statement of the receipts and expenditures of the county during the preceding twelve (12) months setting forth the source and amount of all receipts and the purpose and the amount of all expenditures to be prepared upon reconciliation of all accounts by the county treasurer and county clerk, not later than September 30. The statement shall be signed by the chairman and clerk of the board and shall be posted on the county’s designated official website in the manner provided in W.S. 18-3-516(f) and published at least once in the county’s designated official newspaper.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 20; R.S. 1887, § 1811; R.S. 1899, § 1067; C.S. 1910, § 1175; C.S. 1920, § 1421; R.S. 1931, § 30-614; C.S. 1945, § 27-817; W.S. 1957, § 18-160; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1985, ch. 34, § 1; 2010, ch. 34, § 1; 2014 ch. 85, § 1, effective July 1, 2014.

The 2010 amendment, substituted “request a statement” for “have prepared a statement”; inserted “to be prepared upon reconciliation of all accounts by the county treasurer and county clerk, not later than September 30”; and substituted “of general circulation” for “printed.”

Laws 2010, ch. 34 § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2010.

The 2014 amendment, effective July 1, 2014, in the last sentence, inserted “posted on the county's designated official website in the manner provided in W.S. 18-3-516(f) and,” substituted “once in the county's designated official” for “two (2) times in a,” and deleted “of general circulation in the county, or if there is none, by posting the statement in three (3) public places in the county.”

§ 18-3-516. Publication of proceedings; publication of salary information of certain officials and employees.

  1. Each board of county commissioners shall post a comprehensive summary of the entire proceedings of all regular and special meetings held by the board on the county’s official website in the manner provided in subsection (f) of this section and publish the comprehensive summary of the entire proceedings of all regular and special meetings held by them one (1) time in the county’s designated official newspaper. The county clerk of each county shall within twelve (12) working days after adjournment of every meeting for which the next scheduled meeting will be called to order in two (2) weeks time or less, or within eighteen (18) working days after adjournment of every meeting for which the next scheduled meeting will be called to order in more than two (2) weeks time, furnish the paper with a copy of the proceedings. Except for salaries and wages published under subsection (b) of this section, the copy shall include any bill presented to the board stating the amount of the bill, the amount allowed, the purpose of the bill and the claimant. Claims for part-time employees may be summarized by department without listing each part-time employee. The newspaper shall publish the copy of proceedings within nine (9) days after receipt. The board shall post on its official website, and if practicable publish, notice of the time of all regular and special meetings.
  2. Each board of county commissioners shall post on the county’s official website in the manner provided in subsection (f) of this section and publish separate from the minutes of the proceedings:
    1. Within sixty (60) days after the end of each fiscal year, the name, position, base annual salary of and amount of overtime pay paid to each full-time employee and each elected official. A brief statement shall accompany the salary publication specifying that all salaries are listed as base annual salaries or actual wages, not including any benefits such as health insurance costs, life insurance benefits and pension plans. The statement shall also indicate that any overtime that the employee earned and was paid by the county is included.
    2. Repealed by Laws 2014, ch. 85, §  2.
  3. Repealed by Laws 2014, ch. 85, §  2.
  4. Subsection (b) of this section shall not apply to undercover personnel working in the law enforcement field.
  5. Any nonprofit corporation which receives at least twenty-five percent (25%) of its total annual budget from county funds, state funds or both in combination shall annually submit a list of all full-time positions employed by the corporation and the wages and salaries paid each position, without the name of the employee, to the commission, board, council or agency from which the funds are received.
  6. For all publications required by statute to be posted on a county’s official website, the publication shall be posted at times required for publication in a designated official newspaper. Until June 30, 2016, each board of county commissioners shall cause to be published in the designated official newspaper once per month, no less than twelve (12) times per year, a general public notice pertaining to access to county information. After June 30, 2016, this general public notice shall be published at least once per year.

History.

Laws 1877, p. 92, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 1814; R.S. 1899, § 1070; C.S. 1910, § 1178; C.S. 1920, § 1424; R.S. 1931, § 30-617; C.S. 1945, § 27-821; W.S. 1957, § 18-161; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1983, ch. 54, § 1; 1986, ch. 44, § 1; 2004, ch. 130, § 1; 2007, ch. 82, § 1; 2014 ch. 85, §§ 1, 2, effective July 1, 2014; 2015 ch. 131, § 1, effective March 4, 2015; 2020 ch. 36, § 1, effective July 1, 2020.

The 2004 amendment, in (b)(i), inserted “that” following “wages do not include any overtime.”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

The 2007 amendment, in (a), substituted “twelve (12) working days after adjournment of every meeting for which the next scheduled meeting will be called to order in two (2) weeks time or less, or within eighteen (18) working days after adjournment of every meeting for which the next scheduled meeting will be called to order in more than two (2) weeks time” for “twelve (12) days after adjournment of every meeting.”

Laws 2007, ch. 82, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by Article 4, § 8 of the Wyoming Constitution. Approved February 21, 2007.

The 2020 amendment, effective July 1, 2020, in (b)(i) substituted “position, base annual salary of and amount of overtime pay paid to each” for “position and gross monthly salary of each,” “base annual salaries or actual wages” for “gross monthly salaries or actual monthly wages,” “benefits” for “fringe benefits,” “any overtime that the employee earned and was paid” for “the salaries or wages do not include any overtime that the employee may earn which would be paid,” and added “is included” at the end.

The 2014 amendments. —

The first 2014 amendment, by ch. 85, §§ 1, 2, effective July 1, 2014, in (a), rewrote the first sentence; inserted “port on its official website, and” following “board shall”; in the introductory paragraph of (b), inserted “post on the county's official website in the manner provided in subsection (f) of this section and” following “shall”; rewrote (b)(i); repealed former (b)(ii) which read: “During March of each year, a complete list of all chief administrative officials, assistant administrative officials, elected officials, department heads and full-time employees of the county specified by name and position, excluding salaries”; repealed former (c) which read: “As used in this section, 'department head' means any employee responsible for the operation of a major functional area of county government including any independently elected official”; and added (f).

The second 2014 amendment, by ch. 93, § 1, effective July 1, 2014, added (f).

This section is set out as reconciled by the Wyoming legislative service office.

The 2015 amendment, in (b)(i), deleted “and” at the end, and made a related change.

Laws 2015, ch. 131, § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2015.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

In general. —

All proceedings of the board must be published immediately. North Laramie Land Co. v. Hoffman, 30 Wyo. 238, 30 Wyo. 239, 219 P. 561, 1923 Wyo. LEXIS 43 (Wyo. 1923), aff'd, 268 U.S. 276, 45 S. Ct. 491, 69 L. Ed. 953, 1925 U.S. LEXIS 568 (U.S. 1925).

Stated in

State ex rel. State Hwy. Comm'n v. Meeker, 75 Wyo. 210, 294 P.2d 603, 1956 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1956).

§ 18-3-517. Designation of official paper.

When there is more than one (1) paper published in any county the board of county commissioners shall designate which one is the official paper of the county.

History.

Laws 1877, p. 93, § 6; R.S. 1887, § 1817; R.S. 1899, § 1071; C.S. 1910, § 1179; C.S. 1920, § 1425; R.S. 1931, § 30-618; C.S. 1945, § 27-822; W.S. 1957, § 18-162; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

In general. —

It is the duty of the board of commissioners to designate an official paper of the county, where there is more than 1 paper published in the county. Appel v. State, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1900).

Designation by commissioners. —

It is duty of board of county commissioners to designate official paper where more than 1 paper is published within county. Appel v. State, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1900).

Treasurer's discretion. —

The county treasurer may publish notice of sale of real property for delinquent taxes in any paper he may select, and the county is liable for the publication, as he is not bound to use the official paper. Albany County v. Chaplin, 5 Wyo. 74, 37 P. 370, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1894).

Notice of tax sales. —

County treasurer may publish notice of sale of realty for delinquent taxes in any paper he may select which need not be the official paper, and county is liable for the publication. Albany County v. Chaplin, 5 Wyo. 74, 37 P. 370, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1894).

§ 18-3-518. Legal advertising; rates; type size requirements; “daily newspaper”; “weekly newspaper.”

  1. Legal advertising required by law to be published shall be purchased at a rate not to exceed the amount charged by a daily newspaper at the lowest rate for display advertising or by a weekly newspaper at the open local display advertising rate. Weekly newspapers shall grant customary discounts or contractual rates to any local government fulfilling the requirements necessary to qualify for the discount or rate. Legal advertising shall be in the same type size used by that publisher in regular classified advertising columns, provided that such type size shall be no larger than nine (9) point type, with spacing between lines not to exceed one-half (1/2) point leading.
  2. As used in this section, “daily newspaper” means a newspaper published regularly at least five (5) times each week and “weekly newspaper” means a newspaper published regularly not more than five (5) times each week and at least once a week.

History.

Laws 1897, ch. 73, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1080; C.S. 1910, § 1075; Laws 1919, ch. 9, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 1308; R.S. 1931, § 29-309; C.S. 1945, § 27-823; Laws 1949, ch. 73, § 1; 1957, ch. 59, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 18-163; Laws 1971, ch. 84, § 1; 1977, ch. 91, § 1; ch. 124, § 1; 1983, ch. 54, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to public printing and supplies, with reference to the state generally, see § 16-6-301.

Editor's notes. —

Section 18-3-518, which was enacted by § 1, ch. 124, Laws 1977, has been deleted and § 18-163, W.S. 1957, which was amended by § 1, ch. 91, Laws 1977, by rewriting the first sentence and adding the second sentence, now appears as § 18-3-518.

Constitutionality. —

The amendatory act in connection with the original act did not violate art. 1, §§ 20, 30, 31, 34, 35 and art. 3, §§ 24, 27, 31, Wyo. Const.In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932).

Title of act. —

The title of this act amending § 18-3-519 “An act to amend and reenact § 1310, Wyoming Compiled Statutes, 1920, relating to and defining legal newspapers” was not in violation of art. 3, § 24, Wyo. Const.In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932).

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Chaplin, 5 Wyo. 74, 37 P. 370, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (1894); Pirie v. Kamps, 68 Wyo. 83, 229 P.2d 927, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 18, 26 A.L.R.2d 647 (1951).

§ 18-3-519. Requirements as to newspaper publishing legal notices.

  1. The publication of any legal notice, printing or advertising required by law is without force or effect unless published in a newspaper which has been regularly issued at least once each week for a period of fifty-two (52) consecutive weeks prior to the date of the first publication of the notice or advertisement, has a paid circulation of at least five hundred (500) and each page is not less than ten (10) inches by twelve and one-half (12.5) inches in size.
  2. The provisions of this section shall not apply in counties where no newspaper has been regularly issued for fifty-two (52) consecutive weeks, where there is only one (1) newspaper in the county, or in any county where no newspaper meets the requirements of this section.

History.

Laws 1897, ch. 73, § 4 [3]; R.S. 1899, § 1082; C.S. 1910, § 1077; C.S. 1920, § 1310; Laws 1931, ch. 85, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 29-311; C.S. 1945, § 27-825; Laws 1951, ch. 84, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 18-165; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2005, ch. 116, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to publication of notice generally, see §§ 1-6-201 to 1-6-204.

The 2005 amendment, in (a), substituted “twelve and one-half (12.5) inches” for “fourteen (14) inches,” and made a stylistic change.

Laws 2005, ch. 116, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved February 24, 2005.

Constitutionality. —

The amendatory act in connection with the original act did not violate art. 1, §§ 20, 30, 31, 34, 35 and art. 3, §§ 24, 27, 31, Wyo. Const.In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932).

Constitutionality of section. —

This section is a special law giving special privileges in contravention of art. 3, § 27, Wyo. Const. It confers particular privileges upon certain merchants and publishers, and imposes peculiar disabilities and burdensome conditions on other merchants and publishers, all of whom stand in the same relation to the law. It was not within the power of the legislature to evade the operation of the constitutional provisions by creating an arbitrary and unnatural distinction between persons thus related to the law. Pirie v. Kamps, 68 Wyo. 83, 229 P.2d 927, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1951).

Where a newspaper meets the requirements of this section it cannot raise the constitutionality of the 1931 amendment. In re Gillette Daily Journal, 45 Wyo. 173, 17 P.2d 665, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1933).

This section does not deprive anyone of his life or his property under art. 1, § 6, Wyo. Const.Pirie v. Kamps, 68 Wyo. 83, 229 P.2d 927, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (1951). See also In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932).

Interveners cannot claim unconstitutionality of act. —

In an action by a newspaper to have it declared a legal newspaper to which other newspapers intervened, the interveners cannot claim the unconstitutionality of the act on appeal. In re Gillette Daily Journal, 45 Wyo. 173, 17 P.2d 665, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1933).

Title of act. —

Title of this act amending this section, “An act to amend and reenact § 1310, Wyoming Compiled Statutes, 1920, relating to and defining legal newspapers,” was not in violation of art. 3, § 24, Wyo. Const.In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932).

Ordinary newspaper not privileged over tabloid. —

The aim of a statute relating to legal publications is, or should be, to have these publications made in a newspaper which is of general circulation in the community, so as to be generally read and so that the contents of the notice may be brought home to the public generally. No reason exists to give the publisher of an ordinary and standard newspaper a special privilege over that granted to the publisher of a tabloid newspaper if legal notices inserted in the newspaper of the latter subserve that general aim and the tabloid newspaper is regularly published for the length of time required by this section and has the required circulation. Pirie v. Kamps, 68 Wyo. 83, 229 P.2d 927, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1951).

Giving a strict and the ordinary construction to the term “page,” as used in this section, a tabloid newspaper would not be a legal newspaper within the meaning of this section, although that might not be true if it is liberally construed. Pirie v. Kamps, 68 Wyo. 83, 229 P.2d 927, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1951).

But whether a newspaper is one of general circulation is a matter of substance and not of size. Pirie v. Kamps, 68 Wyo. 83, 229 P.2d 927, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1951).

This section prescribes under what circumstances a published notice shall have the effect of a legal notice. The legislature has undoubtedly the right, in exercising the sovereign or police power of the state, to make reasonable regulations in regard to legal notices. The publication thereof is not a right, but at most a privilege, which the legislature bestows, and which it can modify or take away. In re Gillette Daily Journal, 44 Wyo. 226, 11 P.2d 265, 1932 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (Wyo. 1932); Pirie v. Kamps, 68 Wyo. 83, 229 P.2d 927, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1951).

This section does not prohibit the entering into a contract between the owner of a tabloid newspaper and the plaintiff or anyone else. Whether or not a publication made pursuant to such contract shall have the effect of a legal notice is a collateral matter. Still, to say that the right to have a notice published in a certain paper, and have it recognized as a legal notice, is part of the liberty of the people under art. 1, § 6, Wyo. Const., possibly stretches the term “liberty” too far. Pirie v. Kamps, 68 Wyo. 83, 229 P.2d 927, 1951 Wyo. LEXIS 18 (Wyo. 1951).

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Chaplin, 5 Wyo. 74, 37 P. 370, 1894 Wyo. LEXIS 20 (1894); State v. Pitet, 69 Wyo. 478, 243 P.2d 177, 1952 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (1952).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Application of requirement that newspaper be locally published for official notice publication, 85 ALR4th 581.

§ 18-3-520. Restrictions upon employment of attorneys.

No attorney shall be employed by the board of county commissioners except as provided by W.S. 18-2-110 and the nature and necessity of such employment shall appear in the record of the board.

History.

Laws 1879, ch. 8, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 1797; R.S. 1899, § 1079; C.S. 1910, § 1073; C.S. 1920, § 1306; R.S. 1931, § 29-307; C.S. 1945, § 27-826; W.S. 1957, § 18-166; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2004, ch. 130, § 1.

Cross references. —

For additional provision relating to employment of attorneys, see § 18-3-302.

The 2004 amendment substituted “W.S. 18-2-110” for “W.S. 18-2-107.”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Cited in

Appel v. State ex rel. Shutter-Cottrell, 9 Wyo. 187, 61 P. 1015, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (1900).

§ 18-3-521. Appropriation to encourage industrial development; advertising county resources.

Each board of county commissioners may make appropriations from the county general fund for advertising the resources of the county, for furthering its industrial development or for encouraging exhibits at fairs, expositions and conventions. The appropriation shall not be for the express aid of any private citizen, firm or corporation.

History.

Laws 1909, ch. 153, § 1; C.S. 1910, § 1336; C.S. 1920, § 1585; R.S. 1931, § 3-101; C.S. 1945, § 27-827; W.S. 1957, § 18-167; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1979, ch. 86, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to the Wyoming Business Council, see § 9-12-101 et seq.

As to power of governing body of city or town to appropriate funds for advertisement of resources, see § 15-1-111.

As to powers of municipalities and counties in relation to industrial development projects, see § 15-1-701.

Repealing clauses. —

Section 3, ch. 153, Laws 1909, repealed all laws and parts of laws in conflict therewith.

§ 18-3-522. Membership in organizations for furtherance of good government.

Each board of county commissioners may take out a county membership and cooperate with associations and organizations of other counties or county officials within or without this state for the furtherance of good government and the protection of county interests. The cost of membership may be paid with county funds.

History.

Laws 1945, ch. 136, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 27-828; W.S. 1957, § 18-168; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-3-523. Removal from office.

  1. If any county commissioner refuses or neglects without just cause to perform any duties required of him as a member of the board of county commissioners or knowingly commits any act which by law is in violation of his official oath and bond, charges in writing may be made against him before the district judge of the district in which the county is situated. Notice of filing and a copy of the charges shall be served upon the accused by the sheriff of the county within ten (10) days after the charges are filed with the clerk of the district court. The cause shall be tried not later than thirty (30) days from the filing of the charges and shall be by the court without the intervention of a jury. After submission of the proof the commissioner shall be removed from office by the governor of the state.
  2. If charges against a county commissioner are filed with the governor, he shall cause the accused commissioner to be served with a copy of the charges and notice of the time the governor will hear the matter. The hearing before the governor shall be not less than twenty (20) days after the date of the notice.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 21; R.S. 1887, § 1812; R.S. 1899, § 1068; C.S. 1910, § 1176; Laws 1913, ch. 67, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 1422; R.S. 1931, § 30-615; C.S. 1945, § 27-818; W.S. 1957, § 18-169; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to removal from office generally, see §§ 18-3-901 to 18-3-907.

§ 18-3-524. Appointments to fill vacancies; term.

  1. Within twenty (20) days after the office of any county commissioner becomes vacant the remaining members of the board shall declare a vacancy to exist and immediately give notice of the vacancy in writing to the chairman of the county central committee of the political party which the member whose office is vacant represented at the time of his election under W.S. 22-6-120(a)(vii), or at the time of his appointment if not elected to office. The chairman of the county central committee shall within twenty (20) days after receipt of the notice call a meeting of the county central committee. At the meeting the committee shall select three (3) persons qualified to fill the vacancy and transmit the names to the board of county commissioners. The board of county commissioners shall fill the vacancy within twenty (20) days after receiving the list from the county central committee by appointing one (1) of the persons whose names are submitted by the county central committee:
    1. If the county central committee fails to select and transmit the list of three (3) names to the board of county commissioners within twenty (20) days, the board shall fill the vacancy by the appointment of any qualified person belonging to the same political party the incumbent commissioner represented at the time of his election or appointment if not elected to office;
    2. If the incumbent commissioner did not represent any political party at the time of his election or appointment, the board of county commissioners shall publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the county notice that within twenty (20) days after publication any qualified person may make application directly to the county commissioners for appointment to fill the vacancy. Within twenty (20) days after the application deadline the county commissioners shall fill the vacancy by appointment of one (1) person qualified from those submitting applications.
  2. If the remaining members of the board of county commissioners fail to fill any vacancy in a board of county commissioners within the time specified in this section, any qualified elector of the county may file a petition with the clerk of the district court of the county in which the vacancy occurred requesting the judge of the district court to fill the vacancy:
    1. Within twenty (20) days after the petition is filed the judge shall fill the vacancy by appointing a qualified elector of the county belonging to the same political party the incumbent commissioner represented at the time of his election or appointment. If the incumbent commissioner did not represent any political party at the time of his election or appointment the judge may appoint any qualified person to fill the vacancy.
  3. Every person appointed county commissioner shall serve until a successor is elected at the next general election and takes office on the first Monday of the following January.
  4. For purposes of this section a person shall be considered to “represent” a political party if he was a nominee of that political party when elected to office or when appointed to fill a vacancy in office.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. I, § 23; R.S. 1887, § 1813; R.S. 1899, § 1069; C.S. 1910, § 1177; Laws 1915, ch. 60, §§ 1 to 4; C.S. 1920, §§ 1372, 1423; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-112, 30-616; Laws 1937, ch. 38, § 1; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-819, 27-820; Laws 1951, ch. 92, § 1; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-170, 18-171; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2003, ch. 82, § 1; 2004, ch. 22, § 1; 2011, ch. 115, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to filling vacancies generally, see §§ 22-18-101 to 22-18-112.

The 2004 amendment, in (a) and (b), clarified procedures for filing vacancies in specified offices, substituting provisions pertaining to a commissioner representing a political party rather than belonging to a political party; and added (d).

Laws 2004, ch. 22, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 2, 2004.

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, in (a)(ii), substituted “shall publish in a newspaper of general circulation in the county notice that within twenty (20) days after publication any qualified person may make application directly to the county commissioners for appointment to fill the vacancy” for “may appoint any qualified person to fill the vacancy,” and added the last sentence.

Editor's notes. —

This section replaces §§ 22 and 24, art. I, ch. 28, C.L. 1876.

There is no paragraph (b)(ii) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Notification. —

When a county commissioner changes his political affiliation during his term in office and subsequently resigns, board of county commissioners must notify political body to which member belonged at time of last election. Richards v. Board of County Comm'rs, 6 P.3d 1251, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 132 (Wyo. 2000).

Article 6. County Sheriffs

  • § 18-3-601.  Office created; election.
  • § 18-3-602.  Qualifications, appointment, duties and salary of undersheriff; deputies, reserve deputies, clerks, stenographers and assistants; appointment of deputies for special acts; appointment of deputies by county commissioners.
  • § 18-3-603.  Duty as custodian of jail and prisoners; requirements for boarding prisoners; quarters or rental allowance to be furnished by county.
  • § 18-3-604.  Service of process; attendance upon courts.
  • § 18-3-605.  Service of process on sheriff; appearing as attorney prohibited.
  • § 18-3-606.  Duty to preserve peace.
  • § 18-3-607.  Cash book to be kept by sheriff as ex officio county collector; entries to be made; inspection; receipts; penalties.
  • § 18-3-608.  Fees generally.
  • § 18-3-609.  Other duties.
  • § 18-3-610.  Custodian of jail when sheriff imprisoned.
  • § 18-3-611.  Sheriff's office employees; removal from office; hearings.

Cross references. —

As to bond of county officers generally, see § 18-3-102.

As to salary of county sheriff generally, see § 18-3-107.

As to prima facie malfeasance in office by sheriff, see § 18-3-906.

For provision that sheriff, etc., and prisoner shall not be subject to civil arrest when traveling through counties, see § 18-6-308.

As to the Wyoming peace officer's training commission, see § 9-1-701 et seq.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

56 Am. Jur. 2d Municipal Corporation, Counties, etc. §§ 90, 91, 235; 70 Am. Jur. 2d Sheriffs, Police and Constables § 1 et seq.

80 C.J.S. Sheriffs and Constables § 1 et seq.

§ 18-3-601. Office created; election.

There shall be elected in each county a county sheriff, who shall be a resident of the county in which the county sheriff serves, beginning on the first day of the term and through the last day of the term for which the county sheriff serves.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. IV, § 1; Laws 1882, ch. 45, § 7; R.S. 1887, § 1858; R.S. 1899, § 1111; C.S. 1910, § 1212; C.S. 1920, § 1459; R.S. 1931, § 30-801; Laws 1937, ch. 85, § 5; C.S. 1945, § 27-1001; W.S. 1957, § 18-172; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2021 ch. 165, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, added ", who shall be a resident of the county in which the county sheriff serves, beginning on the first day of the term and through the last day of the term for which the county sheriff serves."

Editor's notes. —

The basic law establishing county offices and government was ch. 28, C.L. 1876.

Prior to the enactment of ch. 45, Laws 1890-91, the sheriff was the county collector, as provided by §§ 1 to 11, art. IV, ch. 28, C.L. 1876. As to the disposition of these acts, see the Table of Disposition of Acts.

Chapter 85, Laws 1937, was a general law relating to terms of county officers.

Legislative intent. —

Statute providing undersheriff becomes sheriff upon vacancy in office of sheriff is read in pari materia with sections giving county commissioners power of appointment upon vacancy, providing that every elective office becomes vacant upon death or resignation, and relating to sheriff's bonds, indicates legislative intent that undersheriff act as sheriff only while vacancy exists. State ex rel. Peterson v. Ellsworth, 59 Wyo. 288, 139 P.2d 744, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1943).

Payment for jailer's services. —

Statutory provision that for any services rendered by an officer wherein no fees are allowed by law, reasonable compensation shall be allowed, did not apply to payment for services of jailer hired by the sheriff. Board of County Comm'rs v. Johnson, 2 Wyo. 259, 1880 Wyo. LEXIS 8 (Wyo. 1880).

Right to sue on sheriff's official bond must be predicated upon statute requiring bond, and only person injured or entitled to benefit of security may sue thereon in his own name. Tuttle v. Short, 42 Wyo. 1, 288 P. 524, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1930).

Survival of action. —

Administrator's claim under sheriff's bond is based upon rights of intestate which survived and passed to representative for benefit of estate. Tuttle v. Short, 42 Wyo. 1, 288 P. 524, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1930).

Cause of action for wrongful death, while under arrest and riding in sheriff's automobile, did not survive sheriff's death, hence was not maintainable against sheriff's administrator or surety upon sheriff's official bond. Tuttle v. Short, 42 Wyo. 1, 288 P. 524, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1930).

Tort action against sheriff's estate. —

In action against sheriff's administrator and surety on sheriff's bond which was in form joint and several, under which the state was obligee, where it appeared that plaintiff in custody of sheriff was riding with him and his deputy in automobile, and that plaintiff was injured when automobile operated by deputy plunged over cliff, plaintiff as person injured was entitled to bring action in his own name. Stephens v. Short, 41 Wyo. 324, 285 P. 797, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Wyo. 1930).

Transportation of prisoners. —

Sheriff owes duty to transport prisoner with reasonable care for latter's safety, separate and apart from promise contained in official bond. Tuttle v. Short, 42 Wyo. 1, 288 P. 524, 1930 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1930).

Stated in

Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

Cited in

Taxpayers' League v. McPherson, 49 Wyo. 251, 54 P.2d 897, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 48, 106 A.L.R. 767 (1936).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Civil liability, under federal civil rights statute (42 U.S.C. § 1983) of state officers who coerce or attempt to coerce confessions or pleas of guilty, 55 ALR2d 512.

Personal liability of sheriff, or his bond, for negligently causing personal injury or death, 60 ALR2d 873.

Power to appoint sheriff for term commencing at or after expiration of term of appointing officer or body, 75 ALR2d 1277.

Personal liability of policeman, sheriff, or similar peace officer or his bond, for injury suffered as a result of failure to enforce law or arrest law breaker, 41 ALR3d 700.

Liability for false arrest or imprisonment under warrant as affected by mistake as to identity of person arrested, 39 ALR4th 705.

§ 18-3-602. Qualifications, appointment, duties and salary of undersheriff; deputies, reserve deputies, clerks, stenographers and assistants; appointment of deputies for special acts; appointment of deputies by county commissioners.

  1. Each county sheriff may appoint an undersheriff who shall be a bona fide resident of the county, qualify as required by law for deputy sheriff and serve as sheriff in case of death, resignation or other disability of the sheriff until the board of county commissioners fill the vacancy. The person appointed shall qualify in accordance with law and may receive an annual salary fixed by the board of county commissioners at not less than twenty-five percent (25%) of the annual salary of the sheriff in their respective counties.
  2. With the consent of the board of county commissioners each county sheriff may appoint one (1) or more full-time deputies who may receive an annual salary fixed by the board of county commissioners at not less than twenty percent (20%) of the sheriff’s salary. The sheriff may also appoint other assistants as necessary to properly administer the affairs of the office.
  3. In addition to the authority granted under W.S. 7-2-106, each county sheriff may also appoint special deputies to perform particular acts, which shall be specified in each appointment and for whose official acts he is responsible. Such appointments are not required to be filed or revoked as in the case of regular deputies. No county assessor shall be appointed deputy sheriff.
  4. In addition to the authority granted under W.S. 7-2-106, each county sheriff may employ temporary deputies and assistants authorized by the board of county commissioners. The compensation of these deputies and assistants shall be fixed by the board of county commissioners.
  5. In addition to the authority granted under W.S. 7-2-106, each board of county commissioners, when extraordinary or unusual danger to life or property is in progress or is threatened and the regular county officers cannot maintain proper order, may appoint special deputy sheriffs only for the duration of the extraordinary or unusual danger. Each special deputy sheriff shall be:
    1. An elector of the county and shall take an oath to faithfully discharge the duties of the office;
    2. Subject to the orders of the county sheriff who is responsible for their acts, unless otherwise ordered by the board of county commissioners; and
    3. Compensated at a rate established by the board of county commissioners.
  6. Each county sheriff may appoint reserve deputy sheriffs to assist the sheriff as necessary to properly administer the affairs of the office. A reserve deputy sheriff acting less than full-time in the service of the county shall have peace officer authority, provided the reserve deputy sheriff has qualified pursuant to W.S. 9-1-701 through 9-1-707. The compensation for deputy reserve sheriffs shall be fixed by the board of county commissioners.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. IV, §§ 2, 3; Laws 1886, ch. 43, §§ 1 to 4; R.S. 1887, §§ 1859, 1860, 1863 to 1866; R.S. 1899, §§ 1117, 1118, 1121 to 1124; C.S. 1910, §§ 1218, 1219, 1222 to 1224; C.S. 1920, §§ 1465, 1466, 1469 to 1472; Laws 1925, ch. 110, § 1; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-807, 30-808, 30-811 to 30-814; Laws 1943, ch. 18, § 1; 1945, ch. 161, § 1; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-1002, 27-1003, 27-1016 to 27-1019; Laws 1949, ch. 116, § 1; 1953, ch. 159, § 1; 1957, ch. 191, § 2; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-173, 18-174, 18-187 to 18-190; Laws 1961, ch. 129, § 1; 1969, ch. 124, § 1; 1976, ch. 11, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, ch. 112, § 1; 2004, ch. 45, § 1; 2005, ch. 170, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to appointment of deputies and assistants generally, see § 18-3-107.

The 2004 amendment, in (c) through (e), added “In addition to the authority granted under W.S. 7-2-106” at the beginning.

Laws 2004, ch. 45, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2004.

The 2005 amendment added (f).

Laws 2005, ch. 170, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 2, 2005.

Legislative intent. —

Statute providing undersheriff becomes sheriff upon vacancy in office of sheriff is read in pari materia with sections giving county commissioners power of appointment upon vacancy, providing that every elective office becomes vacant upon death or resignation, and relating to sheriff's bonds, indicating legislative intent that undersheriff act as sheriff only while vacancy exists. State ex rel. Peterson v. Ellsworth, 59 Wyo. 288, 139 P.2d 744, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1943).

Modified construction. —

Even if this section could be construed as actually making undersheriff the sheriff, in case of death or resignation of incumbent, § 27-116, W.C.S. 1945, clearly modified it by making no exception to power to fill vacancy in any county office. State ex rel. Peterson v. Ellsworth, 59 Wyo. 288, 139 P.2d 744, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1943).

The 1943 amendment to this section definitely decided that undersheriff should serve only until vacancy should be filled and recognized and intended to make certain law as it had been for at least half a century. State ex rel. Peterson v. Ellsworth, 59 Wyo. 288, 139 P.2d 744, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1943).

Legislative acquiescence. —

Where attorney general construed that this section meant that undersheriff could hold office only until new sheriff was appointed pursuant to § 27-116, W.C.S. 1945, failure of legislature to amend statute for 17 years thereafter indicates legislative acquiescence in such construction. State ex rel. Peterson v. Ellsworth, 59 Wyo. 288, 139 P.2d 744, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1943).

Powers and duties. —

An undersheriff is in effect a deputy sheriff, so that a sale and deed executed by such undersheriff is valid. Delfelder v. Teton Land & Inv. Co., 46 Wyo. 142, 24 P.2d 702, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 37 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 46 Wyo. 142, 26 P.2d 153, 1933 Wyo. LEXIS 38 (Wyo. 1933).

Purpose. —

Since at common law authority of deputy sheriff ipso facto terminated when sheriff went out of office, statute, to remedy difficulty, provides duties shall in such cases be discharged by deputy or undersheriff only until vacancy is filled by appointment or election. State ex rel. Peterson v. Ellsworth, 59 Wyo. 288, 139 P.2d 744, 1943 Wyo. LEXIS 17 (Wyo. 1943).

The Fair Employment Practices Act has no application to the appointment of a deputy sheriff. Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

A deputy sheriff is an officer, not an employee; he is appointed, not hired. Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

A deputy sheriff is not an employee of either the sheriff or the board of county commissioners; he is appointed by the sheriff to fill a county office specifically authorized by law. Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976).

Discharge of appointees for political association. —

Where appointees of a sheriff who have been discharged by his successor claim that their first amendment right of association has been violated, the defendant must bear the burden of proof on the issue whether party affiliation (or particular political association and support) was an appropriate requirement for the effective performance of the public office involved, but the burden on the appointees is to prove that their discharge or threat of discharge was for the reason that they were affiliated with the ex-sheriff. Dickeson v. Quarberg, 844 F.2d 1435, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 5515 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1988).

No protected property interest. —

Because board of county commissioners cannot control sheriff's appointments under his independent office, such appointments create no constitutionally protected property interest. Bachmeier v. Hoffman, 1 P.3d 1236, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 78 (Wyo. 2000).

Appointed jailer and assistant, discharged by sheriff's successor, did not have property interest within the meaning of the fourteenth amendment with respect to their positions, since the sheriff's representations and any understandings he had with appointees were necessarily confined to his term of office under the Wyoming elective system. Dickeson v. Quarberg, 844 F.2d 1435, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 5515 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1988).

The board of county commissioners is not empowered to control the sheriff's appointments under his independent office created by the Wyoming statutes with respect to either the appointment of one plaintiff as a jailer or another plaintiff as an assistant, with her clerical, process service and other functions. Hence, no property interest is created by the personnel policies and practices of the board of county commissioners for purposes of the fourteenth amendment by reason of such appointments. Dickeson v. Quarberg, 844 F.2d 1435, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 5515 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1988).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity, construction, and application of regulation regarding outside employment of governmental employees or officers, 88 ALR2d 1235.

Validity, construction, and application of regulations regarding outside employment of governmental employees or officers, 62 ALR5th 671.

§ 18-3-603. Duty as custodian of jail and prisoners; requirements for boarding prisoners; quarters or rental allowance to be furnished by county.

  1. Each sheriff has charge of the jail and the prisoners therein confined in his county. The prisoners shall be kept by the sheriff or by a deputy or detention officer appointed for that purpose, and for whose acts he and his sureties are liable. The sheriff shall provide three (3) nutritionally balanced meals each day for each prisoner. Each sheriff shall make a monthly accounting to the board of county commissioners to show that the expenditures have actually been made.
  2. The sheriff shall not be charged rent for any building owned or controlled by the county and occupied by him as a residence. If a residence is not furnished the sheriff by the county, the sheriff may be allowed an amount established annually by the board of county commissioners on or before July 1 of each calendar year. The amount shall be paid monthly and shall not exceed the prevailing rate of the municipality in which the sheriff resides.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. IV, § 4; R.S. 1887, § 1867; Laws 1895, ch. 76, § 10; R.S. 1899, § 1129; Laws 1903, ch. 56, § 1; C.S. 1910, § 1230; Laws 1917, ch. 12, § 1; C.S. 1920, § 1477; R.S. 1931, § 30-819; Laws 1945, ch. 5, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 27-1004; Laws 1957, ch. 176, § 1; W.S. 1957, § 18-175; Laws 1973, ch. 18, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, ch. 82, § 1; 1995, ch. 122, § 2.

Discharge of appointees for political association. —

Where appointees of a sheriff who have been discharged by his successor claim that their first amendment right of association has been violated, the defendant must bear the burden of proof on the issue whether party affiliation (or particular political association and support) was an appropriate requirement for the effective performance of the public office involved, but the burden on the appointees is to prove that their discharge or threat of discharge was for the reason that they were affiliated with the ex-sheriff. Dickeson v. Quarberg, 844 F.2d 1435, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 5515 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1988).

Appointed jailer and assistant, discharged by sheriff's successor, did not have property interest within the meaning of the fourteenth amendment with respect to their positions, since the sheriff's representations and any understandings he had with appointees were necessarily confined to his term of office under the Wyoming elective system. Dickeson v. Quarberg, 844 F.2d 1435, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 5515 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1988).

The board of county commissioners is not empowered to control the sheriff's appointments under his independent office created by the Wyoming statutes with respect to either the appointment of one plaintiff as a jailer or another plaintiff as an assistant, with her clerical, process service and other functions. Hence, no property interest is created by the personnel policies and practices of the board of county commissioners for purposes of the fourteenth amendment by reason of such appointments. Dickeson v. Quarberg, 844 F.2d 1435, 1988 U.S. App. LEXIS 5515 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1988).

Applied in

Boyer-Gladden v. Hill, 2010 WY 12, 224 P.3d 21, 2010 Wyo. LEXIS 13 (Feb. 9, 2010).

Cited in

Park County Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Hodge, 792 P.2d 1390, 1990 Wyo. LEXIS 67 (Wyo. 1990).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Civil liability of sheriff or other officer charged with keeping jail or prison for act of deputy causing death or injury of prisoner, 14 ALR2d 353, 41 ALR3d 1021.

§ 18-3-604. Service of process; attendance upon courts.

The county sheriff or his deputy shall serve and execute according to law all processes, writs, precepts and orders issued by any court of record in his county or other lawful authority in all criminal and civil cases and he shall attend all courts of record in his county.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. IV, § 5; R.S. 1887, § 1868; R.S. 1899, § 1125; C.S. 1910, § 1226; C.S. 1920, § 1473; R.S. 1931, § 30-815; C.S. 1945, § 27-1005; W.S. 1957, § 18-176; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cited in

First Wyo. Bank v. Trans Mt. Sales & Leasing, Inc., 602 P.2d 1219, 1979 Wyo. LEXIS 484 (Wyo. 1979).

§ 18-3-605. Service of process on sheriff; appearing as attorney prohibited.

Every paper required by law to be served on the county sheriff may be served on him in person or left at his office during business hours. No sheriff or deputy shall appear or advise as attorney or counselor in any case in any court.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. IV, § 7; R.S. 1887, § 1870; R.S. 1899, § 1127; C.S. 1910, § 1228; C.S. 1920, § 1475; R.S. 1931, § 30-817; C.S. 1945, § 27-1007; W.S. 1957, § 18-177; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to process generally, see §§ 1-6-101 to 1-6-301.

§ 18-3-606. Duty to preserve peace.

Each county sheriff and deputy shall preserve the peace in the respective counties and suppress all affrays, riots, unlawful assemblies and insurrections. Each sheriff or deputy sheriff may call upon any person to assist in performing these duties or for the service of process in civil and criminal cases or for the apprehension or securing of any person for felony or breach of peace.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. IV, § 6; R.S. 1887, § 1869; R.S. 1889, § 1126; C.S. 1910, § 1227; C.S. 1920, § 1474; R.S. 1931, § 30-816; C.S. 1945, § 27-1006; W.S. 1957, § 18-178; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1985, ch. 212, § 3.

Warrantless arrest. —

Arrest of a party for mere drunkenness by a sheriff without warrant is unlawful. State v. Munger, 43 Wyo. 404, 4 P.2d 1094, 1931 Wyo. LEXIS 29 (Wyo. 1931).

Applied in

Pfister v. Niobrara County, 557 P.2d 735, 1976 Wyo. LEXIS 233 (Wyo. 1976); Hoblyn v. Johnson, 2002 WY 152, 55 P.3d 1219, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 173 (Wyo. 2002).

§ 18-3-607. Cash book to be kept by sheriff as ex officio county collector; entries to be made; inspection; receipts; penalties.

  1. Every county sheriff as ex officio county collector shall have and keep in his office a cash book in which shall be entered all monies paid him by virtue of his office, together with the date of payment, the name of the person paying the same and the purpose for which it was paid. Each cash book shall at all reasonable hours of the day be open to the inspection and examination of all persons desiring to examine it.
  2. Upon receiving any money the sheriff shall issue a receipt to the person paying the same, entering on the receipt the same information required to be entered in the cash book.
  3. Any county sheriff or deputy who fails to perform the duties specified in subsections (a) and (b) of this section or who fails to perform any other duties required by law is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). In addition the court may adjudge that the sheriff be removed from office.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. IV, §§ 8, 9, 11; R.S. 1887, §§ 1836, 1837, 1839; R.S. 1899, §§ 1097, 1098, 1100; C.S. 1910, §§ 1196, 1197, 1199; Laws 1919, ch. 27, § 1; C.S. 1920, §§ 1442, 1443, 1445; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-1116, 30-1117, 30-1119; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-1008, 27-1009, 27-1011; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-179 to 18-181; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

All sections were originally enacted as §§ 8, 9 and 11, art. IV, ch. 28, of C.L. 1876. Article IV of this act related solely to the sheriff. The county treasurer was made the collector of taxes by § 3, ch. 45, Laws 1890-91.

In general. —

This section requires to be entered in the cash book, among other things, every sum of money paid the collector by virtue of his office, the date of the payment, the name of the person paying the same, and the account upon which the same was paid. Lobban v. State, 9 Wyo. 377, 64 P. 82, 1901 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1901).

Tax receipt. —

Where taxes have been fully liquidated, the tax receipt should be one in full, not merely a statement of the amount paid. Lobban v. State, 9 Wyo. 377, 64 P. 82, 1901 Wyo. LEXIS 16 (Wyo. 1901).

Cited in

Roberts v. Board of County Comm'rs, 8 Wyo. 177, 56 P. 915, 1899 Wyo. LEXIS 7 (1899).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Power of sheriff to remit, release or compromise taxes, 28 ALR2d 1425.

§ 18-3-608. Fees generally.

  1. For the serving of process according to the Wyoming Rules of Civil Procedure, each county sheriff shall receive from the party requesting service a single fee, to be determined and set by the board of county commissioners after a public hearing, paid in advance to be credited to the county general fund, not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first three (3) attempts at service at a different time and date for each attempt. Thereafter a fee not to exceed ten dollars ($10.00) may be charged for each succeeding attempt. The court may waive the fees upon an adequate showing of indigency. Any fees waived may, pursuant to court order, be assessed and collected against any judgment rendered. Each county sheriff shall receive from the party for whom service is rendered in civil cases the following fees which shall be transmitted to the county treasurer to be credited to the county general fund and which shall be paid in advance if demanded by the sheriff from the party for whom the service is rendered:
    1. Deleted by Laws 1993, ch. 158, § 1.
    2. through (viii) Repealed by Laws 1993, ch. 158, § 2.
    3. Commission on money collected on execution or other final process, where the same is collected without sale of property:
      1. For the first five hundred dollars ($500.00), two percent (2%);
      2. For the second five hundred dollars ($500.00), one percent (1%);
      3. For all over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), one-half of one percent (0.5%).
    4. Where collection is made upon a sale of the property, the commissions allowed are as follows:
      1. On the first five hundred dollars ($500.00), four percent (4%);
      2. On the second five hundred dollars ($500.00), two percent (2%);
      3. On all over one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), one percent (1%).
    5. For advertising property for sale, one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50).
    6. and (xiii) Repealed by Laws 1993, ch. 158, § 2.
  2. When in the execution of his duties, it is necessary for the county sheriff to take, store, keep, maintain or subsist any property he is entitled to receive a reasonable allowance to cover all actual and necessary expenses of doing so. The allowance shall be fixed by the proper court upon affidavit made by the sheriff or his deputy or undersheriff, detailing all items of expense, and that the expenses were actually and necessarily incurred. The court before allowing the claim may require additional evidence to sustain the claim. The county sheriff before incurring any expense may require the party for whose benefit the expense is to be incurred to deposit a sum sufficient to meet the same. The allowance shall accrue to the sheriff, and he shall not be chargeable therewith.
  3. Repealed by Laws 1989, ch. 32, § 2.

History.

Laws 1895, ch. 76, §§ 11 to 13; R.S. 1899, §§ 1113 to 1115; C.S. 1910, §§ 1214 to 1216; C.S. 1920, §§ 1461 to 1463; Laws 1927, ch. 59, § 1; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-803 to 30-805; Laws 1935, ch. 41, § 2; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-1012 to 27-1014; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-182 to 18-184; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, Sp. Sess., ch. 22, § 1; 1983, ch. 103, § 1; 1989, ch. 32, § 2, ch. 76, § 1; 1993, ch. 158, §§ 1, 2; 1994, ch. 61, § 1; 2006, ch. 48, § 1; 2011, ch. 132, § 1; 2012, ch. 39, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to payment of expenses for return of accused to this state, see § 7-3-224.

As to fees of sheriff in connection with sale of lands to enforce liens relative to water rights under Carey Act, see § 36-7-508.

The 2006 amendment, effective July 1, 2006, substituted “thirty-five dollars ($35.00)” for “twenty dollars ($20.00)” in (a).

The 2011 amendment, effective July 1, 2011, substituted “fifty dollars ($50.00)” for “thirty-five dollars ($35.00),” and “ten dollars ($10.00)” for “five dollars ($5.00).”

The 2012 amendment, effective July 1, 2012, deleted “biannually” after “determined and set” in (a).

In general. —

A sheriff may demand his fees in advance. Beeman & Cashin Mercantile Co. v. Sorenson, 15 Wyo. 450, 89 P. 745, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 15 Wyo. 450, 89 P. 1135, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1907).

Construction. —

Provision that in addition to salary a sheriff may receive fees for services rendered in civil cases should be construed as including legal proceedings for protection or enforcement of private rights and redress of private wrongs. Messenger v. Board of Comm'rs, 19 Wyo. 309, 117 P. 126, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1911).

Inspection fees. —

Sheriff was not entitled to retain an inspection fee on horses within constitutional provision which allowed sheriff to receive as compensation in addition to his salary fees for services rendered to a party in civil cases. Messenger v. Board of Comm'rs, 19 Wyo. 309, 117 P. 126, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1911).

Under statute providing for an inspection of horses about to be transported or driven out of the state, fixing an inspection fee and making the sheriff the inspecting officer, the acts of the sheriff in making the inspection were not services rendered in civil cases within the meaning of art. 14, § 2, Wyo. Const., and the law, providing for the inspection, could provide that the fees should be paid into the general fund of the county. Messenger v. Board of Comm'rs, 19 Wyo. 309, 117 P. 126, 1911 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1911).

Vacation of order. —

Where order is vacated at a succeeding term, a new or amended affidavit might be filed, and the court had jurisdiction to hear and determine the same. Beeman & Cashin Mercantile Co. v. Sorenson, 15 Wyo. 450, 89 P. 745, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 15 Wyo. 450, 89 P. 1135, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1907).

Proof of ownership in attached property. —

It being permissible under statute to have the expense allowed and liability of the proper parties enforced for keeping of attached property in suit wherein attachment was levied, the same objections were open to the party attempted to be charged as though a separate action had been brought, and defendant was entitled upon motion, the purpose of which was to tax the costs of keeping attached property against him, to show that he was not the owner thereof. Beeman & Cashin Mercantile Co. v. Sorenson, 15 Wyo. 450, 89 P. 745, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 15 Wyo. 450, 89 P. 1135, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1907).

Expenses for attached property. —

After defendant paid judgment rendered against him, together with costs, plaintiff, at same term filed affidavit of deputy sheriff, showing expense in caring for attached property, and judge indorsed thereon “order allowed,” with no entry of formal order. The purpose of asking the order was to place liability for sheriff's expenses on defendant, and the order of allowance, (assuming judge's indorsement on the affidavit had effect of an order of allowance), having been granted without notice to defendant, could be vacated upon defendant's motion having been filed at the term the order was granted, and court had jurisdiction to determine same at the following term. Beeman & Cashin Mercantile Co. v. Sorenson, 15 Wyo. 450, 89 P. 745, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 25 (Wyo.), reh'g denied, 15 Wyo. 450, 89 P. 1135, 1907 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (Wyo. 1907).

Execution sale. —

Where judgment creditor bought property at execution sale for less than judgment debt, purchase price being credited upon the judgment, sheriff was entitled to commission allowed by this section on money collected on execution. Lyman v. Thorn, 24 Wyo. 326, 157 P. 887, 1916 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1916).

Commission at execution sale. —

A sheriff is entitled to commission at an execution sale where the judgment creditor purchases the property for less than the judgment debt, although no money actually changes hands and purchase price was merely credited upon the judgment and execution. Lyman v. Thorn, 24 Wyo. 326, 157 P. 887, 1916 Wyo. LEXIS 32 (Wyo. 1916).

Cited in

Taxpayers' League v. McPherson, 49 Wyo. 251, 54 P.2d 897, 1936 Wyo. LEXIS 48, 106 A.L.R. 767 (1936).

§ 18-3-609. Other duties.

  1. Each county sheriff shall:
    1. Pay and account for all monies which come into his office, as provided by law;
    2. Deliver to his successor in office or other person authorized by law to receive them all monies, books, papers and other property belonging to his office;
    3. Be the official responsible for coordination of all search and rescue operations within his jurisdiction;
    4. Perform all other duties required of him by law.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. IV, §§ 1, 10; Laws 1882, ch. 45, § 7; R.S. 1887, §§ 1858, 1871; R.S. 1899, §§ 1111, 1128; C.S. 1910, §§ 1212, 1229; C.S. 1920, §§ 1444, 1459; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-801, 30-808, 30-1118; Laws 1937, ch. 85, § 5; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-1001, 27-1010; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-172, 18-192; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1991, ch. 210, § 2.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

§ 18-3-610. Custodian of jail when sheriff imprisoned.

When the sheriff is committed to the jail of his county, the board of county commissioners shall appoint a special deputy sheriff to act as custodian thereof during the time the sheriff remains a prisoner.

History.


C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. VI, § 2; R.S. 1887, § 1877; R.S. 1899, § 1171; C.S. 1910, § 1277; C.S. 1920, § 1529; R.S. 1931, § 30-702; C.S. 1945, § 27-902; W.S. 1957, § 7-78; W.S. 1977, § 7-4-102; Laws 1985, ch. 212, § 2.

§ 18-3-611. Sheriff's office employees; removal from office; hearings.

  1. This section applies to sworn nonprobationary, full-time deputies of a sheriff’s department which employs at least twenty (20) sworn, full-time deputies. Except as provided by subsection (d) of this section, this section does not apply to any member of the executive staff. As used in this subsection, “member of the executive staff” means a deputy whose primary duties consist of the management of the department or a subdivision thereof, who regularly exercises discretionary powers as they relate to the employment status of employees and who is directly supervised by the sheriff.
  2. A deputy sheriff shall not be discharged from employment, reduced in rank or suspended without pay except for cause and after notice and opportunity for a hearing. The hearing and any appeal shall be conducted in accordance with the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. The hearing shall be closed unless both the sheriff and the deputy involved agree otherwise.
  3. A deputy sheriff accused of a matter for which the sheriff may discharge him may be suspended with pay for a reasonable length of time necessary to investigate and take final action on the matter, provided the deputy shall not be discharged in any final action without the opportunity for a hearing.
  4. A sheriff may in his discretion reduce in rank a member of the executive staff but shall not terminate him without cause.
  5. This section does not prohibit or restrict discharges from employment, in order of lowest ranking deputies first, for purposes of reorganization of the sheriff’s office or for the reason of lack of funds.

History.

Laws 1989, ch. 220, § 1; 2010, ch. 82, § 1.

The 2010 amendment, made stylistic change in (a).

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2010.

Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act. —

See § 16-3-101(a), (b)(xi).

Meaning of “cause.” —

“Cause,” to which this section refers when it states that a deputy sheriff may be terminated only “for cause,” necessarily means a cause or justification which bears a reasonable relationship to the deputy sheriff's ability and fitness to perform and discharge the duties of his or her position. Lucero v. Mathews, 901 P.2d 1115, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. 1995), reh'g denied, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. Sept. 26, 1995).

Procedure. —

A claim for damages against the state for breach of the employment relationship based either in contract or tort must proceed, if at all, in accordance with the Governmental Claims Act, § 1-39-101 et seq. Allen v. Lucero, 925 P.2d 228, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 138 (Wyo. 1996), reh'g denied, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. Oct. 29, 1996), overruled in part, Brown v. City of Casper, 2011 WY 35, 248 P.3d 1136, 2011 Wyo. LEXIS 36 (Wyo. 2011).

Due process right. —

Section 18-3-611 creates a property right in the position of a full-time deputy sheriff by requiring that any termination of employment be for cause and after notice and opportunity for a hearing. In addition to the statutory requirements for notice and opportunity to be heard, there is then a federal constitutional right to due process of law that demands notice of the cause for termination and a hearing on the existence of the cause prior to terminating employment of a full-time deputy sheriff. Lucero v. Mathews, 901 P.2d 1115, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. 1995), reh'g denied, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. Sept. 26, 1995).

This section imposed a substantive limitation on sheriff's discretion to reduce rank of a deputy sheriff, and thus deputy sheriff had a protected property interest in continued employment at his rank of lieutenant. Greene v. Barrett, 174 F.3d 1136, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 7516 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1999).

Deputy sheriff failed to show that his property right in continued employment at his rank was clearly established at time sheriff reduced his rank, and therefore sheriff was entitled to qualified immunity from deputy sheriff's civil rights suit. Greene v. Barrett, 174 F.3d 1136, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 7516 (10th Cir. Wyo. 1999).

Political patronage not cause for termination. —

Under § 18-3-611, political patronage and other expressions of the freedom of association and party affiliation are not cause or justification for which a deputy sheriff may be terminated. Lucero v. Mathews, 901 P.2d 1115, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 156 (Wyo. 1995), reh'g denied, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. Sept. 26, 1995).

Discharge upheld. —

Deputy sheriff failed to refute evidence of his absenteeism and dishonesty, and his discharge was therefore upheld. Fisch v. Allsop, 4 P.3d 204, 2000 Wyo. LEXIS 94 (Wyo. 2000).

Applied in

Laramie County Sheriff's Dep't v. Cook, 2012 WY 47, 272 P.3d 966, 2012 Wyo. LEXIS 50 (Mar. 28, 2012).

Stated in

Mondt v. Cheyenne Police Dep't, 924 P.2d 70, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 127 (Wyo. 1996).

Cited in

Metz v. Laramie County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 2007 WY 166, 173 P.3d 334, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 178 (Oct. 23, 2007).

Article 7. County Surveyors

  • § 18-3-701.  Qualifications; appointment; duty as supervisor of roads.
  • § 18-3-702.  Duty to make county surveys and keep plats.
  • § 18-3-703.  Records to be kept; copies to be furnished upon request; duty to file plats, maps and records of surveys made for county with county clerk; penalty for failure to file such records; authority of county commissioners to purchase records of private surveys.
  • § 18-3-704.  Establishment of lost corners.
  • § 18-3-705.  Compensation of surveyor; appointment and compensation of road supervisor in case surveyor does not act.

Cross references. —

For duty of county surveyors as to boundary disputes, see §§ 18-1-401 to 18-1-407.

As to bonds of county officers generally, see § 18-3-102.

For duty of county commissioners to provide county officers with stationery and supplies, see § 18-3-514.

For duty of county surveyors as to highways generally, see title 24.

As to surveyors and engineers generally, see §§ 33-29-114 through 33-29-139.

For authority of county surveyor relative to the platting, etc., of plats vacated in connection with the establishment of town sites, see § 34-12-111.

§ 18-3-701. Qualifications; appointment; duty as supervisor of roads.

Each board of county commissioners may appoint a county surveyor who is a licensed engineer or surveyor of the state of Wyoming. The board of county commissioners may also appoint the county surveyor to be the county supervisor of roads. If no licensed surveyor or engineer is available the board of county commissioners may appoint some other competent person to act as supervisor of roads.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. VII, § 1; 1886, ch. 58, § 1; R.S. 1887, § 1889; R.S. 1899, § 1184; C.S. 1910, § 1290; C.S. 1920, § 1542; Laws 1925, ch. 31, § 1; R.S. 1931, § 30-1001; Laws 1937, ch. 85, § 6; 1945, ch. 147, § 1; C.S. 1945, § 27-1201; W.S. 1957, § 18-192; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Editor's notes. —

The basic law establishing county offices and government was ch. 28, C.L. 1876.

Chapter 85, Laws 1937, was a general law relating to terms of county officers.

§ 18-3-702. Duty to make county surveys and keep plats.

  1. The county surveyor shall:
    1. Conduct all surveys in and for his county and keep a plat of all official surveys made by him on file in his office in strict conformity to the field notes of the survey;
    2. File a copy of a plat of legally established county roads in the United States land office of the district in which the roads are located;
    3. Execute any survey that is required by order of any court or upon application of any individual or corporation. The certificate of the county surveyor shall be admitted as legal evidence in any court of the state but the same may be explained or rebutted by other evidence.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. VII, § 2; Laws 1886, ch. 58, § 2; R.S. 1887, §§ 1890, 1891; R.S. 1899, §§ 1185, 1186; Laws 1907, ch. 39, § 2; C.S. 1910, §§ 1291, 1292, 2592; C.S. 1920, §§ 1543, 1544, 3085; R.S. 1931, §§ 30-1002, 30-1003, 42-115; C.S. 1945, §§ 27-1202, 27-1203, 66-515; W.S. 1957, §§ 18-193 to 18-195; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

For other provisions for survey of roads, see §§ 24-1-102 and 24-3-109.

As to platting and dedication, see §§ 34-12-101 to 34-12-115.

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

In general. —

In the absence of rebutting evidence, the surveyor's certificate is sufficient to warrant a finding of the court in favor of one claiming under it. Pool v. Baker, 23 Wyo. 539, 154 P. 328, 1916 Wyo. LEXIS 4 (Wyo. 1916).

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Patrick, 18 Wyo. 130, 104 P. 531, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (1909).

§ 18-3-703. Records to be kept; copies to be furnished upon request; duty to file plats, maps and records of surveys made for county with county clerk; penalty for failure to file such records; authority of county commissioners to purchase records of private surveys.

  1. The county surveyor shall keep a correct record of all surveys made by him in a book provided by the county which he shall transmit to his successor in office. He shall number each survey progressively and shall preserve a copy of field notes and calculations of each survey endorsing thereon its proper number. A copy of the survey and an accurate plat thereof, together with a certificate of survey shall be furnished by the surveyor to any person requiring the same.
  2. Each county surveyor shall file with the county clerk of the county wherein the land surveyed is located all plats, maps and survey records of surveys made by him in behalf of the county, and shall make such filings continuously as surveys are completed. The county clerk and the county commissioners may invoke the aid of any district court in the state to secure possession of such documents as are in the custody of the county surveyors which are the property of the county.
  3. It is unlawful for any county surveyor to fail to file plats, maps and survey records of surveys made as provided herein within thirty (30) days of the completion of the survey. Violators of this section are guilty of a misdemeanor and may be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisoned in the county jail not more than thirty (30) days, or both.
  4. Each board of county commissioners may purchase for a reasonable sum survey records made by surveyors.

History.

C.L. 1876, ch. 28, art. VII, § 3; R.S. 1887, § 1892; R.S. 1899, § 1187; C.S. 1910, § 1293; C.S. 1920, § 1545; R.S. 1931, § 30-1004; C.S. 1945, § 27-1204; W.S. 1957, § 18-196; Laws 1965, ch. 153, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2010, ch. 69, § 203.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, in (b), deleted “Not later than June 1, 1965” at the beginning, and made a stylistic change; and in (c), deleted “or to file such plats, maps and survey records of surveys made after June 1, 1965” following “as provided herein.”

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Patrick, 18 Wyo. 130, 104 P. 531, 1909 Wyo. LEXIS 26 (1909).

§ 18-3-704. Establishment of lost corners.

  1. Whenever the location of any monument which marks the corner of any tract or tracts of land is in dispute between the owners of the adjoining lands, the monument shall be established as follows:
    1.
