Both provide that the board of county commissioners shall cause to be levied annually upon all taxable property in the county, in addition to other authorized taxes, a tax in a sum sufficient to pay the interest on bonds as the same becomes due and to redeem the bonds upon maturity, said tax to be levied and collected in the same manner as other taxes in said county. Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1959).

Delegation of taxing authority sufficient under either statute to meet constitutional requirements. —

The delegation of taxing authority is sufficient under either §§ 18-4-301 to 18-4-303 and 18-4-306 to 18-4-310, relative to bonds generally, or §§ 18-4-401 to 18-4-409, relative to viaduct and subway bonds, to meet the requirements set forth in art. 15, § 13, Wyo. Const.Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (Wyo. 1959).

§ 18-4-402. Call for bond election; amount authorized; purpose.

Each board of county commissioners may submit to the electors of the county the question whether the board of county commissioners shall be authorized to issue bonds of the county in an amount which together with existing indebtedness shall not exceed the county’s constitutional debt limitation, for the purposes specified in W.S. 18-4-401.

History.

Laws 1921, ch. 167, § 2; R.S. 1931, § 29-802; C.S. 1945, § 28-502; W.S. 1957, § 18-255; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to bond elections generally, see §§ 22-21-101 to 22-21-112.

§ 18-4-403. Conduct of election.

The proposition to issue the bonds shall be submitted to the qualified electors of the county at an election called, conducted, canvassed and returned in the manner provided for bond elections by the Political Subdivision Bond Election Law, W.S. 22-21-101 through 22-21-112. The proposition submitted shall specify the amount of bonds to be issued, the rate of interest and the purpose for which it is proposed. At any election the official ballot shall contain the words “For Viaduct or Subway Bonds” and “Against Viaduct or Subway Bonds.”

History.

Laws 1921, ch. 167, § 3; R.S. 1931, § 29-803; C.S. 1945, § 28-503; W.S. 1957, § 18-256; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1996, ch. 97, § 2.

Cross references. —

As to bond elections generally, see §§ 22-21-101 to 22-21-112.

§ 18-4-404. Form, terms, conditions and execution of bonds; payment and interest; sale price.

  1. The viaduct or subway bonds:
    1. Shall be payable thirty (30) years from the date of issue;
    2. Shall be redeemable at the option of the county after ten (10) years;
    3. Shall bear interest payable on January 15 and July 15 each year;
    4. Shall be issued in any combination of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), five hundred dollars ($500.00) or one hundred dollars ($100.00) denominations;
    5. Shall be consecutively numbered from the number one (1);
    6. Shall be signed by the chairman of the board of county commissioners and attested by the county clerk who shall affix the county seal thereto;
    7. May have attached when negotiated, semiannual interest coupons signed by the county treasurer.
  2. At the request of the purchaser or holder the county treasurer shall issue to him registered bonds or shall exchange registered bonds for coupon bonds. The principal and interest shall be payable at the office of the county treasurer of the county, at the office of the state treasurer or at some bank in the City of New York as designated by the board of county commissioners. The bonds shall not be sold for less than their full or par value and the accrued interest thereon at the time of delivery.

History.

Laws 1921, ch. 167, § 4; R.S. 1931, § 29-804; C.S. 1945, § 28-504; Laws 1971, ch. 254, § 15; W.S. 1957, § 18-257; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, ch. 143, § 1; 1982, ch. 28, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to interest rates generally, see § 40-14-106(e).

§ 18-4-405. Notice of intention to issue and sell.

The board of county commissioners shall give notice by posting on the county’s official website in the manner provided in W.S. 18-3-516(f) and by publication in the county’s designated official newspaper.

History.

Laws 1921, ch. 167, § 5; R.S. 1931, § 29-805; C.S. 1945, § 28-505; W.S. 1957, § 18-258; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2014 ch. 85, § 1, effective July 1, 2014.

The 2014 amendment, rewrote the section which formally read: “The board of county commissioners shall give notice by publication in some newspaper published and of general circulation in the county if there be one; otherwise by three (3) notices posted in the county one (1) of which is posted at the courthouse door, of its intention to issue and negotiate the bonds and to invite bidders therefor. The notice shall also be published in some newspaper published and of general circulation in the cities of Cheyenne, Wyoming; Denver, Colorado; Chicago, Illinois and New York City, New York.”

§ 18-4-406. Registration and endorsement.

The county treasurer shall maintain records in which is registered all bonds showing the number of the bond, the amount, date of issue, to whom issued, date of redemption, rate of and payment of interest and the time and place of payment. The county clerk shall endorse and officially sign a certificate upon every bond that it is within the lawful debt limit of the county and is issued according to law.

History.

Laws 1921, ch. 167, § 6; R.S. 1931, § 29-806; C.S. 1945, § 28-506; W.S. 1957, § 18-259; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1980, ch. 49, § 2.

§ 18-4-407. Tax levy for purpose of redemption; restriction upon use of monies collected.

The board of county commissioners shall annually levy upon all taxable property in the county in addition to other authorized taxes a tax sufficient to pay the principal and interest on the bonds as they become due which shall be levied and collected in the same manner as other taxes in the county. The taxes collected shall be known as the viaduct or subway tax and shall only be used for the payment of interest and principal of the bonds.

History.

Laws 1921, ch. 167, § 7; R.S. 1931, § 29-807; C.S. 1945, § 28-507; W.S. 1957, § 18-260; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-4-408. Payment from general fund when tax not levied; reimbursement.

Should the tax for the payment of interest on any bonds not be levied or collected in time to meet the payment the interest shall be paid out of any monies in the general fund of the county and the money so used shall be repaid to the general fund from the first monies collected from viaduct or subway taxes.

History.

Laws 1921, ch. 167, § 8; R.S. 1931, § 29-808; C.S. 1945, § 28-508; W.S. 1957, § 18-261; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

§ 18-4-409. Redemption of bonds.

Any county issuing bonds shall annually after the tenth year redeem at least one-twentieth (1/20) of the bonds. The bonds redeemed each year shall be determined by lot.

History.

Laws 1921, ch. 167, § 9; R.S. 1931, § 29-809; C.S. 1945, § 28-509; W.S. 1957, § 18-262; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Article 5. Funding Bonds

  • § 18-4-501.  Issuance authorized; purpose; terms and conditions; provisions for payment and redemption.
  • § 18-4-502.  Funding indebtedness.
  • § 18-4-503.  Form of bonds; coupons covering interest.
  • § 18-4-504.  Notice of intention to issue and sell; printing and engraving; execution and sale; disposition of proceeds; redemption; records to be kept.
  • § 18-4-505.  Annual tax for purpose of redemption; payment of bonds guaranteed; effect of county division; payment out of general fund when tax not levied; reimbursement.
  • § 18-4-506.  Application of funds derived from sale of bonds; penalty for misappropriation.

Cross references. —

As to the General Obligation Public Securities Refunding Law, see § 16-5-101 et seq.

As to interest rates generally, see § 40-14-106(e).

§ 18-4-501. Issuance authorized; purpose; terms and conditions; provisions for payment and redemption.

  1. Each board of county commissioners may issue negotiable coupon bonds of their county for the purpose of paying, redeeming, funding or refunding the principal and interest of any indebtedness of their county when it can be done at a lower rate of interest to the benefit of the county. The bonds:
    1. Shall be issued as near as practicable in denominations of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) each, but may be issued in denominations of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and one hundred dollars ($100.00) when necessary;
    2. Shall bear interest;
    3. Shall be paid on January 1 and July 1 in each year at the office of the county treasurer or at a bank in New York City as designated by the board of county commissioners at the option of the holder;
    4. Shall be redeemed by the county in the following manner:
      1. Ten percent (10%) of the total amount issued shall be paid within ten (10) years from date of issue, and ten percent (10%) of the total amount shall be paid annually thereafter until all bonds are paid, making the last bond redeemable twenty (20) years from date of issue; or
      2. Any part thereof may at the option of the county issuing them be redeemed in numerical order after five (5) years from the date of issue if the time and option is stated upon the face of each bond.
    5. May be issued serially as provided by W.S. 16-5-302.
  2. The total amount of bonds issued at any time together with the existing indebtedness of the county shall not exceed the constitutional debt limitations for counties.

History.

Laws 1888, ch. 27, § 1; 1890, ch. 28, § 1; R.S. 1899, § 1209; C.S. 1910, § 1121; C.S. 1920, § 1355; Laws 1931, ch. 73, § 16; R.S. 1931, § 29-711; C.S. 1945, § 28-301; W.S. 1957, § 18-263; Laws 1971, ch. 254, § 16; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1981, ch. 143, § 1; 1982, ch. 28, § 1; 2004, ch. 130, § 1.

The 2004 amendment, in (a)(v), substituted “W.S. 16-5-302” for “W.S. 9-625.”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Power to issue bonds. —

In action by a county against a bond investment company for breach of contract for the purchase of refunding bonds, the county had power to issue the bonds and a defense that the county did not have power to issue refunding bonds to retire those issued under the 1888 act was not well taken. Board of Comm'rs v. Rollins, 9 Wyo. 281, 62 P. 351, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1900).

Four percent debt limit. —

Where indebtedness had been lawfully contracted from time to time under the territorial regime, and on July 10, 1890, the date of adoption of state constitution, the indebtedness was within the 4 percent limit, county was authorized to issue funding bonds to an extent not exceeding 4 percent of its taxable property as shown by the general assessment for 1889. Board of County Comm'rs v. Rollins Inv. Co., 3 Wyo. 470, 27 P. 683, 1891 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (Wyo. 1891).

Two percent limit not applicable. —

The two percent limit prescribed in the constitution does not apply in the apportionment of part of the debt of the parent county to the new county created therefrom. In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (Wyo. 1898).

Stated in

Board of County Comm'rs v. White, 79 Wyo. 420, 335 P.2d 433, 1959 Wyo. LEXIS 14 (1959).

§ 18-4-502. Funding indebtedness.

Any county desiring to fund, refund, pay or redeem any of its outstanding indebtedness as provided by W.S. 18-4-501 may call its indebtedness to be redeemed by advertisement for two (2) weeks in the official newspaper of the county. The advertisement shall notify the holders that interest will cease twenty (20) days after the date of notice.

History.

Laws 1890, ch. 28, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 1210; C.S. 1910, § 1122; C.S. 1920, § 1356; R.S. 1931, § 29-712; C.S. 1945, § 28-302; W.S. 1957, § 18-264; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1980, ch. 49, § 2.

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Rollins Inv. Co., 3 Wyo. 470, 27 P. 683, 1891 Wyo. LEXIS 10 (1891).

§ 18-4-503. Form of bonds; coupons covering interest.

The bonds specified in W.S. 18-4-501 shall have attached when negotiated semiannual interest coupons covering interest on the bond from the date of issue until paid and shall be signed by the chairman of the board of county commissioners, attested by the county clerk, bear the seal of the board of county commissioners and be countersigned by the county treasurer. The coupons annexed to the bonds shall be signed by the county treasurer. Each coupon shall have a number corresponding with the number of the bond and each bond shall state upon its face the amount for which the same is issued, to whom issued and the date of issue and shall recite that it is issued in conformity with the provisions of W.S. 18-4-501 and 18-4-503 through 18-4-506, which sections shall be printed on the back of each bond.

History.

Laws 1888, ch. 27, § 2; R.S. 1899, § 1211; C.S. 1910, § 1123; C.S. 1920, § 1357; R.S. 1931, § 29-713; C.S. 1945, § 28-303; W.S. 1957, § 18-265; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cited in

In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (1898).

§ 18-4-504. Notice of intention to issue and sell; printing and engraving; execution and sale; disposition of proceeds; redemption; records to be kept.

  1. Each board of county commissioners shall give notice by publication in some newspaper published in the county if there be one otherwise by three (3) notices posted in the county, one (1) of which is at the courthouse door, of its intention to issue and negotiate the bonds and invite bidders therefor. The notice shall also be published in a newspaper of general circulation in Cheyenne.
  2. After ascertaining the best terms and the lowest interest at which the bonds can be negotiated the board of county commissioners shall secure the proper engraving and printing, have them consecutively numbered and otherwise properly prepared and executed.
  3. When the bonds are executed they shall be registered by the county clerk in a public record book kept for that purpose and therein shall be stated showing the number, date, amount of bond, time and place of payment, rate of interest, number of coupons attached and any other description for future identification. The board of county commissioners shall from time to time and in such amounts as it deems proper, deliver the bonds to the county treasurer and take and file his receipt therefor and charge him with all bonds so delivered.
  4. The duties of the board of county commissioners pursuant to the provisions of W.S. 18-4-501 and 18-4-503 through 18-4-506 may be performed at any meeting thereof.
  5. The treasurer under the general supervision of the board shall sell the bonds for cash or exchange them for any county indebtedness for the redemption of which they were issued, but shall not sell or exchange the bonds for less than their face or par value and the accrued interest at the time of their disposal. No county indebtedness shall be redeemed at more than its face value and any interest that may be due thereon. If any portion of the bonds are sold for money the proceeds shall be applied exclusively toward the redemption of the county indebtedness for which the bonds were issued.
  6. When the treasurer redeems any county indebtedness he shall endorse by writing or stamping in ink on the face of the paper evidencing the indebtedness redeemed, the time of redemption, the amount redeemed, whether by money or the exchange of bonds and the words “redeemed” and “cancelled”. He shall keep a record of all bonds redeemed showing their number, rate of interest, date and amount of sale, when, where and to whom payable, and if exchanged, for what. The record shall be open for inspection by the public during usual office hours. He shall make detailed statements as often as required by the board of county commissioners of all bond redemption transactions and return to the board all redeemed and cancelled evidences of indebtedness.

History.

Laws 1888, ch. 27, § 3; R.S. 1899, § 1212; C.S. 1910, § 1124; C.S. 1920, § 1358; Laws 1931, ch. 73, § 17; R.S. 1931, § 29-714; C.S. 1945, § 28-304; W.S. 1957, § 18-266; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Cross references. —

As to organization of new counties, see §§ 18-1-301 to 18-1-320.

§ 18-4-505. Annual tax for purpose of redemption; payment of bonds guaranteed; effect of county division; payment out of general fund when tax not levied; reimbursement.

  1. The board of county commissioners shall annually levy upon all taxable property in the county in addition to other authorized taxes a sufficient sum to pay the interest on all bonds issued and shall at least one (1) year before the bonds become due and in time to provide means for their payment, levy a sufficient additional sum to pay bonds as they become due. All such taxes shall be levied, assessed and collected as other county taxes until the bonds are fully paid, including interest.
  2. The faith, credit and all taxable property within the county as constituted at the time of issue are and shall continue pledged to the payment of the principal and interest of the bonds. In the event of the division of any county, the segregated territory is relieved from any obligation occasioned by the issuance of the bonds when the county acquiring such territory pays its proportionate share as provided by W.S. 18-1-316 through 18-1-320.
  3. Should the tax for payment of interest on bonds not be levied or collected in time for payment, the interest shall be paid out of monies in the general fund of the county and the money so used shall be repaid to the general fund out of the first monies collected from taxes.

History.

Laws 1888, ch. 27, § 4; R.S. 1899, § 1213; C.S. 1910, § 1125; C.S. 1920, § 1359; R.S. 1931, § 29-715; C.S. 1945, § 28-305; W.S. 1957, § 18-267; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Power to issue refunding bonds. —

A county had power to issue refunding bonds for the retirement of bonds issued under the 1888 act. Board of Comm'rs v. Rollins, 9 Wyo. 281, 62 P. 351, 1900 Wyo. LEXIS 19 (Wyo. 1900).

Time of levy. —

Time for making levy for redemption fund is within discretion of board of county commissioners, subject only to limitation that it must be at least a year before maturity of the bonds. Cottle v. Union P. R. Co., 201 F. 39, 1912 U.S. App. LEXIS 1990 (8th Cir. Wyo. 1912).

Cited in

In re Fremont County, 8 Wyo. 1, 54 P. 1073, 1898 Wyo. LEXIS 21 (1898).

Law reviews. —

See “Administration of the General Property Tax in Wyoming,” 4 Wyo. L.J. 227.

§ 18-4-506. Application of funds derived from sale of bonds; penalty for misappropriation.

The county treasurer shall apply all proceeds from the sale of the bonds to the payment of the county indebtedness. The proper county officials shall levy, collect and apply all applicable taxes for the payment of interest and redemption of the principal of the bonds. Any county officer who fails to comply with the provisions of this section or neglects or refuses to levy and collect any such tax is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined in an amount equal to the sum that should have been levied, or fined in the amount of any misappropriation and imprisoned in the county jail for a term of not less than three (3) months nor more than twelve (12) months.

History.

Laws 1888, ch. 27, § 5; R.S. 1899, § 1214; C.S. 1910, § 1126; C.S. 1920, § 1360; R.S. 1931, § 29-716; C.S. 1945, § 28-306; W.S. 1957, § 18-268; Laws 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Chapter 5 Planning and Zoning

  • Article 1. County Planning Commission
  • Article 2. Planning and Zoning Commission
  • Article 3. Real Estate Subdivisions
  • Article 4. Conservation Design Process
  • Article 5. Wind and Solar Energy Facilities

Cross references. —

As to county surveyors, see §§ 18-3-701 to 18-3-705.

As to eminent domain generally, see §§ 1-26-501 through 1-26-817 and Rule 71.1, W.R.C.P.

As to municipal and county airports generally, see § 10-5-101 et seq.

For the Wyoming Conservation Districts Law, see §§ 11-16-101 to 11-16-134.

As to municipal zoning generally, see §§ 15-1-601 to 15-1-611.

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

56 Am. Jur. 2d Municipal Corporations, Counties, etc. §§ 155 to 167, 189 to 198, 541 to 548; 82 Am. Jur. 2d Zoning and Planning § 1 et seq.

Protest or petition by property owners, validity and construction of provisions of zoning statute or ordinance respecting, 4 ALR2d 335.

Applicability of zoning regulations to governmental projects or activities, 61 ALR2d 970.

Judgment denying permit for use of premises under zoning regulations as bar to subsequent application, 71 ALR2d 1362.

Authority of zoning commission to impose, as condition of allowance of special zoning exception, permit, or variance, requirements as to highway and traffic changes, 49 ALR3d 492.

Standing of municipal corporation or other governmental body to attack zoning of land lying outside its borders, 49 ALR3d 1126.

Zoning board's grant of new application for zoning change, variance, or special exception after denial of previous application covering same property or part thereof, 52 ALR3d 494.

Regulations creating and placing “floating zones,” 80 ALR3d 95.

Validity and construction of state or local regulation prohibiting off-premises advertising structures, 81 ALR3d 486.

Validity and construction of state or local regulation prohibiting the erection or maintenance of advertising structures within a specified distance of street or highway, 81 ALR3d 564.

Application of zoning regulation to radio or television facilities, 81 ALR3d 1086.

Validity of zoning for senior citizen communities, 83 ALR3d 1084.

Zoning regulations as applied to homes or housing for the elderly, 83 ALR3d 1103.

Applicability of zoning regulation to nongovernmental lessee of government-owned property, 84 ALR3d 1187.

Applicability of zoning regulations to projects of nongovernmental public utility as affected by utility's having power of eminent domain, 87 ALR3d 1265.

What constitutes accessory or incidental use of religious or educational property within zoning ordinance, 11 ALR4th 1084.

Local use zoning of wetlands or flood plain as taking without compensation, 19 ALR4th 756.

Express or implied restriction on lessee's use of residential property for business purposes, 46 ALR4th 496.

Zoning: what constitutes “incidental” or “accessory” use of property zoned, and primarily used, for residential purposes, 54 ALR4th 1034.

Zoning: what constitutes “incidental” or “accessory” use of property zoned, and primarily used, for business or commercial purposes, 60 ALR4th 907.

Addition of another activity to existing nonconforming use as violation of zoning ordinance, 61 ALR4th 724.

Change in volume, intensity or means of performing nonconforming use as violation of zoning ordinance, 61 ALR4th 806.

Change in type of activity of nonconforming use as violation of zoning ordinance, 61 ALR4th 902.

Zoning regulation of intoxicating liquor as pre-empted by state law, 65 ALR4th 555.

Zoning: residential off-street parking requirements, 71 ALR4th 529.

Laches as defense in suit by governmental entity to enjoin zoning violation, 73 ALR4th 870.

Validity of zoning laws setting minimum lot size requirements, 1 ALR5th 622.

Construction and application of zoning laws setting minimum lot size requirements, 2 ALR5th 553.

Applicability of zoning regulations to governmental projects or activities, 53 ALR5th 1.

101A C.J.S. Zoning and Land Planning § 1 et seq.

Article 1. County Planning Commission

  • §§ 18-5-101 through 18-5-107.  [Repealed].

§§ 18-5-101 through 18-5-107. [Repealed].

History.

Repealed by 2013 ch. 192, § 2., effective March 13, 2013.

Article 2. Planning and Zoning Commission

  • § 18-5-201.  Authority vested in board of county commissioners; inapplicability of chapter to incorporated cities and towns; mineral resources; private schools.
  • § 18-5-202.  Planning and zoning commission; composition; residency requirements, terms and removal of members; vacancies; rules; record; meetings to be public; secretary; preparation and amendments; purpose; certifications and hearing; amendments.
  • § 18-5-203.  Certificate required to locate buildings or use land within zoning resolution; issuance and denial; appeal upon denial.
  • § 18-5-204.  Violation of W.S. 18-5-202(c); continuing violation.
  • § 18-5-205.  Enforcement of zoning resolution by injunction, mandamus or abatement; appeal.
  • § 18-5-206.  Penalty for violation of W.S. 18-5-201 through 18-5-204.
  • § 18-5-207.  Continuation of existing uses; effect of alteration or addition; future use after discontinuation of nonconforming use.
  • § 18-5-208.  Special expertise of board of county commissioners and coordination of planning efforts with federal agencies.

Applied in

Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Crow, 2003 WY 40, 65 P.3d 720, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 50 (Wyo. 2003).

Cited in

Ford v. Board of County Comm'rs, 924 P.2d 91, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (Wyo. 1996).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Wyoming's Local Governments and the Quality of Growth — A Preliminary Discussion,” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 491 (1979).

For comment, “State Participation in Federal Policy Making for the Yellowstone Ecosystem: A Meaningful Solution or Business as Usual?” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 397 (1986).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Construction and effect of statute requiring that zoning application be treated as approved if not acted on within specified period of time, 66 ALR4th 1012.

Validity and construction of zoning laws setting minimum requirements for floorspace or cubic footage inside residence, 87 ALR4th 294.

§ 18-5-201. Authority vested in board of county commissioners; inapplicability of chapter to incorporated cities and towns; mineral resources; private schools.

  1. To promote the public health, safety, morals and general welfare of the county, each board of county commissioners may regulate and restrict the location and use of buildings and structures and the use, condition of use or occupancy of lands for residence, recreation, agriculture, industry, commerce, public use and other purposes in the unincorporated area of the county. However, nothing in W.S. 18-5-201 through 18-5-208 shall be construed to contravene any zoning authority of any incorporated city or town. No zoning resolution or plan shall prevent any use or occupancy reasonably necessary to the extraction or production of the mineral resources in or under any lands subject thereto. No board of county commissioners shall require that a land use or physical development be consistent with a local land use plan unless the applicable provisions of the local land use plan have been incorporated into the local zoning regulations. Nothing in W.S. 18-5-201 through 18-5-208 shall be construed to allow any board of county commissioners, through the establishment of minimum lot size requirements or otherwise, to prevent residential or agricultural uses authorized for land divisions that are exempt from subdivision requirements pursuant to W.S. 18-5-303(a)(i). No zoning resolution or plan shall regulate and restrict the location and use of buildings and structures and the use, condition of use or occupancy of lands for the use of a private school as defined in W.S. 21-4-101(a)(iii) in any manner different from a public school, provided that the private school:
    1. Is certified by the professional engineer or architect of record for the private school as being substantially similar to school facility commission guidelines for education buildings and siting and is designed to be constructed with appropriate materials, means and methods;
    2. Has capacity for fifty (50) students or more; and
    3. Is owned and operated by a not for profit entity.

History.

Laws 1959, ch. 85, § 1; 1967, ch. 202, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2010, ch. 82, § 1; 2019 ch. 141, § 1, effective February 27, 2019; 2019 ch. 196, § 1, effective March 15, 2019; 2021 ch. 161, § 1, effective July 1, 2021.

The 2010 amendment, substituted “18-5-208” for “18-5-207.”

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2010.

The 2019 amendments. —

The first 2019 amendment, by ch. 141, § 1, added the last sentence.

Laws 2019, ch. 141, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved February 27, 2019.

The second 2019 amendment, by ch. 196, § 1, designated former undesignated paragraph as present introductory language in (a), substituted “city or town. No zoning” for “city or town and no zoning,” added the last sentence, and added (a)(i) through (a)(iii).

Laws 2019, ch. 196, § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Became law without signature March 15, 2019.

The 2021 amendment , effective July 1, 2021, added the second sentence in (a).

Section not unconstitutional as improper delegation. —

This section is not unconstitutional because it does not grant authority to the county planning and zoning commission to adopt a comprehensive zoning plan, and thus, it is not an improper delegation. Carter v. Board of County Comm'rs, 518 P.2d 142, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 1974).

Application of article. —

This article must be applied in such a way as to reasonably restrict the actions of boards of county commissioners. At the same time, however, to make the theories of planning meaningful, there must be a means to prevent changes in the conditions of a county pending the formulation of a comprehensive plan under § 18-5-202(b). The means necessary to maintain the status quo can be supplied by reference to the powers expressly and impliedly conferred by the County Zoning Act, taken in a light which is consistent with a reasonable exercise of police powers. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Legislature intended to differentiate this section from § 18-5-105. —

The statements of the respective purposes in this section and § 18-5-105 clearly indicate that the legislature intended to deal with separate subjects and provide authority to accomplish different objectives by the two pieces of legislation. Carter v. Board of County Comm'rs, 518 P.2d 142, 1974 Wyo. LEXIS 181 (Wyo. 1974).

Sand, gravel, rock and limestone are not “minerals.” —

Sand, gravel, rock, and limestone are not minerals for purposes of § 18-5-201.River Springs Ltd. Liability Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 899 P.2d 1329, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1995), reh'g denied, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 142 (Wyo. Aug. 15, 1995).

County commissioners may foreclose extraction of sand, gravel, rock and limestone. —

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-5-207 did not deny a county authority to regulate a landowner's nonconforming gravel business by omitting “land” when allowing regulation of changes to nonconforming uses because the statute said nothing about change in land use. Seherr-Thoss v. Teton County Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2014 WY 82, 329 P.3d 936, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2014).

Broad authority. —

The authority granted in this section gives counties broad power to regulate their lands, including broad authority to require compliance with zoning provisions in their efforts to promote orderly development of unincorporated areas. Ford v. Board of County Comm'rs, 924 P.2d 91, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (Wyo. 1996).

County commissioners empowered to zone to control land in unincorporated areas. —

All of the boards of county commissioners throughout the state are given the power to adopt and enforce zoning resolutions for their own counties in order to restrict and control the use of lands located in unincorporated areas. Croxton v. Board of County Comm'rs, 644 P.2d 780, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 337 (Wyo. 1982).

County commissioners have authority to impose limitations on habitable space. —

Under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-5-201, the Board of County Commissioners of Teton County, Wyoming had authority to promulgate Teton County, Wyo., Land Dev. Reg. § 2450, which limits the square footage of homes that can be built in the jurisdiction, because such land use regulation, with a purpose of preserving the area's beauty, past, microeconomics, and housing market, affect the welfare and character of the community. Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Crow, 2003 WY 40, 65 P.3d 720, 2003 Wyo. LEXIS 50 (Wyo. 2003).

County commissioners may foreclose extraction of sand, gravel, rock and limestone. —

There is no inhibition by this statute upon the authority of the board of county commissioners to limit land use by foreclosing the extraction of sand, gravel, rock, and limestone; the authority of the county to prohibit land use is not preempted but, if extraction is permitted by the board of county commissioners, the authority to regulate the mining process is assigned by statute to the Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ). River Springs Ltd. Liab. Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 899 P.2d 1329, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1995).

A county can prohibit the extraction or processing of sand, gravel, rock, and limestone pursuant to its zoning authority, but a “grandfathered” use cannot be prohibited. River Springs Ltd. Liability Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 899 P.2d 1329, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1995), reh'g denied, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 142 (Wyo. Aug. 15, 1995).

If the county permits the extraction, production, or processing of sand, gravel, rock, or limestone, or must do so because the use was a preexisting use, then regulation of those activities is accomplished under the EQA by the DEQ. If, however, the DEQ, pursuant to an exception in the statute, does not regulate those activities, they may be regulated by the county in a way that does not conflict with state regulation. River Springs Ltd. Liability Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 899 P.2d 1329, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1995), reh'g denied, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 142 (Wyo. Aug. 15, 1995).

Board can adopt recommendations freezing building and land uses in unincorporated areas. —

The express power of the board of county commissioners under this section to regulate and restrict the use of buildings and land in unincorporated areas of the county is sufficient in and of itself, or, in the alternative, necessarily implies the authority to adopt recommendations which would freeze such building and land uses. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Board can enact freeze resolution without notice and hearing. —

In order to make meaningful such a power as that to adopt recommendations which would freeze building and land uses, the board of county commissioners necessarily must have the appurtenant power to enact a freeze resolution without notice and hearing. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Power of board is subject to restrictions. —

See Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Length of time. —

This section gives counties either express or implied power to enact a freeze resolution, without notice and hearing, providing that such a freeze is only for a reasonable length of time. Snake River Venture v. Board of County Comm'rs, 616 P.2d 744, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 296 (Wyo. 1980).

Neighbors did not show a board of county commissioners erred in granting a Basic Use Permit to use property as a temporary construction storage/staging area, even though the property had been so used in the past and such a permit would likely be sought in the future, because the use was “temporary,” under the applicable land use regulation, as the permit duration was two years, and past or possible future uses of the property were irrelevant. Tayback v. Teton Cty. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2017 WY 114, 402 P.3d 984, 2017 Wyo. LEXIS 120 (Wyo. 2017).

Property owner lacks vested right in contemplated development. —

Property owner has no vested right, which will withstand a later zoning regulation, in a development which is merely contemplated. Snake River Venture v. Board of County Comm'rs, 616 P.2d 744, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 296 (Wyo. 1980).

A subdivision developer who alleged that he had an entitlement or right to obtain approval of his subdivision, as originally proposed and without restrictions from a board of county commissioners, failed to identify a clearly established statutory or constitutional right that had been violated. Marshall v. Board of County Comm'rs, 912 F. Supp. 1456, 1996 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 761 (D. Wyo. 1996).

Revocation of zoning variance for racetrack upheld where the evidence reasonably supporting a county's conclusion that permitting a race track on a predominantly agricultural location did not promote the public health, safety and general welfare and would have been injurious to the neighborhood. Sheridan Race Car Ass'n v. Rice Ranch, 864 P.2d 30, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 174 (Wyo. 1993).

Quoted in

Board of County Comm'rs v. Teton County Youth Servs., Inc., 652 P.2d 400, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 393 (Wyo. 1982); Pedro/Aspen, Ltd. v. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2004 WY 84, 94 P.3d 412, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (2004).

Cited in

Quinn Revocable Trust v. SRW, Inc., 2004 WY 65, 91 P.3d 146, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 80 (2004).

Law reviews. —

See article, “Implementation of Land Use Policy: Police Power vs. Eminent Domain,” III Land & Water L. Rev. 33 (1968).

See comment, “County and Municipal Flood Plain Zoning Under Existing Wyoming Legislation,” VII Land & Water L. Rev. 103 (1972).

As to the development of land use planning in Wyoming, see XII Land & Water L. Rev. 73 (1977).

For article, “Wyoming's Local Governments and the Quality of Growth — A Preliminary Discussion,” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 491 (1979).

For comment, “State Participation in Federal Policy Making for the Yellowstone Ecosystem: A Meaningful Solution or Business as Usual?” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 397 (1986).

For casenote, “Mining Law — Gravel Extraction — Is Control Over Small Gravel Mining the Best Road for Regulation? River Springs Limited Liability Company v. Board of County Commissioners of County of Teton, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 142 (Wyo. 1995),” see XXXII Land & Water L. Rev. 155 (1997).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity of zoning ordinances prohibiting or regulating outside storage of house trailers, motor homes, campers, vans and the like, in residential neighborhoods, 95 ALR3d 378.

Library References.

American Law of Mining, 2nd Edition §§ 174.03, 174.02 (Matthew Bender).

§ 18-5-202. Planning and zoning commission; composition; residency requirements, terms and removal of members; vacancies; rules; record; meetings to be public; secretary; preparation and amendments; purpose; certifications and hearing; amendments.

  1. Each board of county commissioners may by resolution create and establish a planning and zoning commission. The commission shall be composed of five (5) members appointed by the board at least three (3) of whom shall reside in the unincorporated area of the county, provided that this provision shall not affect the membership composition of any existing commission. The terms of the members appointed to the first planning and zoning commission shall be of such length and so arranged that the terms of one (1) member will expire each year, and thereafter each member shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. Any member of the commission may be removed for cause other than politics or religion and after public hearing by the board of county commissioners. If a vacancy occurs in the commission the board of county commissioners shall fill the vacancy by appointment for the unexpired term. The planning and zoning commission shall organize within thirty (30) days after its establishment, shall adopt rules for the transaction of its business and keep a record of its actions and determinations. Three (3) members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. All meetings, records and accounts of the commission shall be public. The board of county commissioners shall designate the county clerk, another county employee or a member of the planning and zoning commission to serve as secretary to the commission. The secretary shall keep the record of commission actions in accordance with statute.
  2. The planning and zoning commission may prepare and amend a comprehensive plan including zoning for promoting the public health, safety, morals and general welfare of the unincorporated areas of the county, and certify the plan to the board of county commissioners. Before certifying its plan or amendments thereto to the board the commission shall hold at least one (1) public hearing. Notice of the time and place of hearing shall be given by one (1) publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county at least thirty (30) days before the date of the hearing. Any person may petition the planning and zoning commission to amend any zoning plan adopted under the provisions of W.S. 18-5-201 through 18-5-208.
  3. The planning and zoning commission shall prepare recommendations to effectuate the planning and zoning purposes and certify its recommendations to the board of county commissioners. Before adopting the recommendations the board shall hold at least one (1) public hearing. Notice of the time and place of hearing shall be given by one (1) publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the county at least fourteen (14) days before the date of the hearing. After public hearing has been held, the board shall vote upon the adoption of the planning or zoning recommendation. No planning or zoning recommendation shall be adopted unless a majority of the board votes in favor thereof.

History.

Laws 1959, ch. 85, §§ 2 to 4; 1967, ch. 202, §§ 2 to 4; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1985, ch. 179, § 1; 2010, ch. 34, § 1; ch 82 § 1.

The 2010 amendments. —

The first 2010 amendment, by ch. 34, § 1, in (a), substituted the last two sentences for the former last sentence, which read: “The county clerk shall serve as secretary to the commission.”

Laws 2010, ch. 34 § 3, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 4, 2010.

The second 2010 amendment, by ch 82, § 1, substituted “18-5-208” for “18-5-207” in (b).

Laws 2010, ch. 82, § 6, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 9, 2010.

While neither amendment gave effect to the other, both have been given effect in this section as set out above.

Application of article. —

This article must be applied in such a way as to reasonably restrict the actions of boards of county commissioners. At the same time, however, to make the theories of planning meaningful, there must be a means to prevent changes in the conditions of a county pending the formulation of a comprehensive plan under subsection (b) of this section. The means necessary to maintain the status quo can be supplied by reference to the powers expressly and impliedly conferred by this article, taken in a light which is consistent with a reasonable exercise of police powers. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Resolution procedures. —

Before the county commissioners can adopt a resolution, the planning and zoning commission must recommend adoption of the resolution to the county board. Crouthamel v. Board of Albany County Comm'rs, 951 P.2d 835, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1998).

Procedures of board. —

Tie vote of board of county commissioners on planning recommendations is a rejection that the board can reconsider during the same session unless statute or the board's own regulations say otherwise. Hirschfield v. Board of County Comm'rs, 944 P.2d 1139, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 119 (Wyo. 1997).

The rule of strict construction must be adopted in determining whether the powers delegated to the zoning commission have been acceptably exercised. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Section 18-5-204 concerns only resolutions adopted under subsection (c) of this section. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

No other provisions contemplating adoption of emergency planfor unincorporated areas. —

There are no other provisions in this article which contemplate the adoption of any other type of zoning scheme than comprehensive. Specifically, there are no separate provisions which contemplate the adoption of an interim or emergency plan for the unincorporated areas of the counties. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Board can adopt recommendations freezing building and landuses in unincorporated areas. —

The express power of the board of county commissioners under § 18-5-201 to regulate and restrict the use of buildings and land in unincorporated areas of the county is sufficient in and of itself, or, in the alternative, necessarily implies the authority to adopt recommendations which would freeze such building and land uses. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Board can enact freeze resolution without notice and hearing.—

In order to make meaningful such a power as that to adopt recommendations which would freeze building and land uses, the board necessarily must have the appurtenant power to enact a freeze resolution without notice and hearing. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Freeze resolution may not be extended without notice and hearing.—

The exercise of the power to enact a freeze resolution without notice and hearing is subject to certain restrictions. Such a resolution may not be extended, as a matter of course, so that it essentially becomes a board's comprehensive plan, without notice and hearing. The restrictions which would bar such a result can be found in the plain language of subsection (c) of this section. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Freeze resolutions. —

Where county failed to follow the statutory requirements in adopting a freeze resolution, the ten month moratorium was void ab initio when the initial recommendation to the County Board came from the planning staff and not the planning and zoning commission. Crouthamel v. Board of Albany County Comm'rs, 951 P.2d 835, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1998).

Notice and hearing are mandated by section. —

This section mandates a notice and public hearing as conditions precedent to the adoption of any recommendations of the zoning commission, and no action on such recommendations by the board is authorized until the notice and hearing have been effected. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Notice and hearing. —

The ten month moratorium on commercial use of property within the county was an invalid exercise of the county's police power, where the County Board did not provide notice and hearing as required under this section and described in Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).Crouthamel v. Board of Albany County Comm'rs, 951 P.2d 835, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1998).

Notice requirements sufficient. —

Landowners' right to procedural due process was not violated by the adoption of a land use management plan because the notice required by this section was given; a published notice that identifies the particular issues discussed, even in general terms, is sufficient. Laughter v. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2005 WY 54, 110 P.3d 875, 2005 Wyo. LEXIS 60 (Wyo. 2005).

Length of time for which freeze resolution may initially continue.—

Under the supreme court's construction of subsection (c) of this section, a freeze resolution may initially continue only for a length of time which affords an opportunity to give notice and hold a hearing on the issue of whether or not such a resolution should be given more permanent status under that subsection. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

The board must be diligent in formulating a comprehensive plan, when there is an interim freeze resolution in effect, in order to minimize the possible deprivation of property rights. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

No authority exists in this article which permits county commissioners to freeze the land use of an entire county for 5 years under the guise that some kind of a continuing emergency exists — all without compliance with the notice and hearing provisions of the law. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Although the county commissioners' “emergency” resolution of August 24, 1971, freezing existing land use in Park County without previously publishing a notice and holding a public meeting as provided by law, was initially a valid exercise of its implied power to do those things which would make its express power to regulate and restrict the use of buildings and land in unincorporated areas of the county meaningful, this temporary land freeze became, by extension, by resolution, a permanent land plan, which, under the statutes of this state, cannot be implemented without complying with the provisions with respect to public notice and hearing. As a result, the various subsequent resolutions, passed without compliance with the statutes and which extended for some 5 years the original land freeze, were invalid. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Authorized continuum for freeze resolutions. —

This article authorizes the following continuum: (1) On recommendation of the county zoning commission, the board can adopt a freeze resolution in appropriate circumstances without prior notice and hearing; (2) pursuant to subsection (c) of this article, notice of such action shall be promptly given in a newspaper of general circulation in the county, which also shall notice a hearing to be held on the 30th day after the publication on the question of whether or not the freeze resolution should be extended pending the formulation of a comprehensive plan; and (3) within a reasonable time, if the freeze resolution is so extended, the board shall adopt a comprehensive plan under subsection (b) of this section. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Change in density requires notice and comment. —

The court properly concluded that a zoning board failed to abide by the statutory procedures of notice and comment prior to adopting a change in density for contested acreage. Hoke v. Moyer, 865 P.2d 624, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 193 (Wyo. 1993).

Stated in

Snake River Venture v. Board of County Comm'rs, 616 P.2d 744, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 296 (Wyo. 1980).

Law reviews. —

For article, “Wyoming's Local Governments and the Quality of Growth — A Preliminary Discussion,” see XIV Land & Water L. Rev. 491 (1979).

For comment, “State Participation in Federal Policy Making for the Yellowstone Ecosystem: A Meaningful Solution or Business as Usual?” see XXI Land & Water L. Rev. 397 (1986).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Validity and construction of statutory notice requirements prerequisite to adoption or amendment of zoning ordinance or regulation, 96 ALR2d 449.

Disqualification for bias or interest of administrative officer sitting in zoning proceeding, 10 ALR3d 694.

Right to cross-examination of witnesses in hearings before administrative zoning authorities, 27 ALR3d 1304.

Construction and application of statute or ordinance requiring notice as prerequisite to granting variance or exception to zoning requirement, 38 ALR3d 167.

Construction and application of zoning regulations in connection with funeral homes, 92 ALR3d 328.

Validity of zoning ordinances prohibiting or regulating outside storage of house trailers, motor homes, campers, vans and the like, in residential neighborhoods, 95 ALR3d 378.

§ 18-5-203. Certificate required to locate buildings or use land within zoning resolution; issuance and denial; appeal upon denial.

It is unlawful to locate, erect, construct, reconstruct, enlarge, change, maintain or use any building or use any land within any area included in a zoning resolution without first obtaining a zoning certificate from the board of county commissioners or its designee and no zoning certificate shall be issued unless the plans for the proposed building, structure or use fully comply with the zoning regulations then in effect. The board of county commissioners or its designee shall act promptly upon any application filed with it and shall grant certificates when the proposed construction or use complies with the requirements of the zoning resolution. If it denies the application, the board or its designee shall specify the reasons for the denial. Any applicant desiring to appeal shall appeal to the board of county commissioners. The decision of the board of county commissioners may be reviewed by the district court and by the supreme court upon appeal in the same manner as provided in W.S. 15-1-609, for review of decisions of boards of adjustment.

History.

Laws 1959, ch. 85, § 5; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2004, ch. 130, § 1; 2017 ch. 57, § 1, effective July 1, 2017.

The 2004 amendment substituted “W.S. 15-1-609” for “W.S. 15-626.”

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 4, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 19, 2004.

The 2017 amendment, effective July 1, 2017, inserted “or its designee” preceding “and no zoning”; inserted “or its designee” preceding “shall act promptly”; inserted “or its designee” preceding shall specify the”; inserted “Any applicant desiring to appeal shall appeal to the board of county commissioners”; and made a stylistic change

Conflicting legislation. —

Laws 2004, ch. 130, § 3, provides: “Any other act adopted by the Wyoming legislature during the same session in which this act is adopted shall be given precedence and shall prevail over the amendments in this act to the extent that such acts are in conflict with this act.”

Unlawful issuance of certificate where project failed to meetamended regulations. —

Board unlawfully issued planning certificate where a project did not meet amended zoning regulations, even though the project had received initial approval based on ordinances then in effect. Snake River Venture v. Board of County Comm'rs, 616 P.2d 744, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 296 (Wyo. 1980).

Injunction improperly granted. —

Where the county had not adopted a valid zoning resolution, the ten month moratorium on commercial use of property was void ab initio, and the preliminary injunctions which kept landowner from operating a commercial business should not have been granted. Crouthamel v. Board of Albany County Comm'rs, 951 P.2d 835, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1998).

“Open” districts are, in effect, outside any zoning restrictions. Croxton v. Board of County Comm'rs, 644 P.2d 780, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 337 (Wyo. 1982).

Property owner generally without vested right in contemplateddevelopment. —

A property owner generally has no vested right (which will withstand a later zoning regulation) in a development which is merely contemplated. That is not to say a zoning regulation or resolution should not be examined itself to determine whether it has altered the general rules and provided property owners with additional rights. Croxton v. Board of County Comm'rs, 644 P.2d 780, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 337 (Wyo. 1982).

Review of denial of zoning certificate or development permit.—

The decision of a board of county commissioners, in denying the issuance of a development permit, which may be equated with a zoning certificate under this section, is adjudicative in nature and is, therefore, subject to the provisions of the Wyoming Administrative Procedure Act (§§ 16-3-101 through 16-3-115) and reviewable under Rule 12, W.R.A.P., pursuant to § 16-3-114.Board of County Comm'rs v. Teton County Youth Servs., 652 P.2d 400, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 393 (Wyo. 1982).

Revocation of second zoning variance for racetrack upheld where the evidence reasonably supporting a county's conclusion that permitting a race track on a predominantly agricultural location would not promote the public health, safety and general welfare and would have been injurious to the neighborhood. Sheridan Race Car Ass'n v. Rice Ranch, 864 P.2d 30, 1993 Wyo. LEXIS 174 (Wyo. 1993).

Changes during pendency of appeal. —

Where the zoning scheme was changed to industrial during the pendency of the appeal, determining the validity of the old agricultural zoning certificates would have no practical effect on the existing controversy and the case was dismissed on mootness. Bard Ranch Co. v. Frederick, 950 P.2d 564, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 170 (Wyo. 1997).

Quoted in

Ford v. Board of County Comm'rs, 924 P.2d 91, 1996 Wyo. LEXIS 135 (Wyo. 1996); Pedro/Aspen, Ltd. v. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2004 WY 84, 94 P.3d 412, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (2004).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Construction and application of zoning regulations in connection with funeral homes, 92 ALR3d 328.

Standing of civic or property owners' association to challenge zoning board decision (as aggrieved party), 8 ALR4th 1087.

Standing of zoning board of appeals or similar body to appeal reversal of its decision, 13 ALR4th 1130.

§ 18-5-204. Violation of W.S. 18-5-202(c); continuing violation.

No person shall locate, erect, construct, reconstruct, enlarge, change, maintain or use any building or use any land in violation of a resolution or amendment adopted by any board of county commissioners under W.S. 18-5-202(c). Each day’s continuation of such violation is a separate offense.

History.

Laws 1959, ch. 85, § 6; 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

This section concerns only resolutions adopted under § 18-5-202(c). Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

No authority exists in this article which permits county commissioners to freeze land use of entire county for 5 years under the guise that some kind of a continuing emergency exists — all without compliance with the notice and hearing provisions of the law. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Although the county commissioners' “emergency” resolution of August 24, 1971, freezing existing land use in Park County without previously publishing a notice and holding a public meeting as provided by law, was initially a valid exercise of its implied power to do those things which would make its express power to regulate and restrict the use of buildings and land in unincorporated areas of the county meaningful, this temporary land freeze became, by extension, by resolution, a permanent land plan, which, under the statutes of this state, cannot be implemented without complying with the provisions with respect to public notice and hearing. As a result, the various subsequent resolutions, passed without compliance with the statutes and which extended for some 5 years the original land freeze, were invalid. Schoeller v. Board of County Comm'rs, 568 P.2d 869, 1977 Wyo. LEXIS 314 (Wyo. 1977).

Fines accrued daily for land use violations. —

Where the maximum square footage allowed by the Teton County, Wyoming, Land Development Regulations was 8,000 square feet of habitable space, the homeowners were required to pay fines for enlarging their home to 11,000 square feet. Pursuant to Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 18-5-204, 18-5-206, the homeowners were required to pay a fine for each day they were in violation of the habitable space regulation; the total fine to be paid by the homeowners was $ 714,000.00. Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Crow, 2007 WY 177, 170 P.3d 117, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 189 (Wyo. 2007).

Cited in

Board of County Comm'rs of Teton County v. Crow, 2006 WY 45, 131 P.3d 988, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 49 (Wyo. Apr. 13, 2006).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Enforcement of zoning regulation as affected by other violations, 4 ALR4th 462.

§ 18-5-205. Enforcement of zoning resolution by injunction, mandamus or abatement; appeal.

Any zoning resolution passed by the board pursuant to W.S. 18-5-202(b) and (c) is enforceable in addition to other remedies provided by law by injunction, mandamus or abatement.

History.

Laws 1959, ch. 85, § 7; 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

District court has jurisdiction to enforce zoning decision by injunction. Wardwell Dev. Corp. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 639 P.2d 888, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 286 (Wyo. 1982).

Abatement. —

In a case in which a county sought an abatement order under Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-5-205 after a property owner altered and enlarged his home in violation of the county's land development regulations, the county was not required to make a showing of irreparable injury in order for the district court to order abatement. The owner's violation of the regulations constituted a basis for the imposition of an abatement order. Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Crow, 2006 WY 45, 131 P.3d 988, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 49 (Wyo. 2006).

Applied in

Croxton v. Board of County Comm'rs, 644 P.2d 780, 1982 Wyo. LEXIS 337 (Wyo. 1982).

Cited in

Nickle v. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2007 WY 115, 162 P.3d 1208, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (July 24, 2007).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Remedies to compel municipal officials to enforce zoning regulations, 35 ALR2d 1135.

Mandamus to compel zoning officials to cancel permit granted in violation of zoning regulation, 68 ALR3d 166.

§ 18-5-206. Penalty for violation of W.S. 18-5-201 through 18-5-204.

Whoever violates any provision of W.S. 18-5-201 through 18-5-204 shall be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense.

History.

Laws 1959, ch. 85, § 8; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 1997, ch. 188, § 1.

Imposition of fine for each day's violation. —

District court imposed a fine on a property owner for 242 days in connection with the owner's violation of a county's habitable space regulation, even though it was evident that the owner's violation of the regulation continued for a considerably longer time than 242 days. The district court was required to impose a fine for each day the owner's violation continued, and the record did not reflect a stipulation by the county that the fine should be imposed for a lesser period of time. Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Crow, 2006 WY 45, 131 P.3d 988, 2006 Wyo. LEXIS 49 (Wyo. 2006).

Fines accrued daily for land use violations. —

Where the maximum square footage allowed by the Teton County, Wyoming, Land Development Regulations was 8,000 square feet of habitable space, the homeowners were required to pay fines for enlarging their home to 11,000 square feet. Pursuant to Wyo. Stat. Ann. §§ 18-5-204, 18-5-206, the homeowners were required to pay a fine for each day they were in violation of the habitable space regulation; the total fine to be paid by the homeowners was $ 714,000.00. Bd. of County Comm'rs v. Crow, 2007 WY 177, 170 P.3d 117, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 189 (Wyo. 2007).

Cited in

Nickle v. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2007 WY 115, 162 P.3d 1208, 2007 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (July 24, 2007).

§ 18-5-207. Continuation of existing uses; effect of alteration or addition; future use after discontinuation of nonconforming use.

  1. A zoning resolution enacted under the provisions of W.S. 18-5-201 through 18-5-206 shall not prohibit the continuance of the use of any land, building or structure for the purpose for which the land, building or structure is used at the time the resolution is adopted and it is not necessary to secure any certificate permitting such continuance. However, the alteration or addition to any existing building or structure for the purpose of effecting any change in use may be regulated or prohibited by zoning resolution. If a nonconforming use is discontinued any future use of such land, building or structure shall be in conformity with the provisions of the resolution regulating uses in the area in which the land, building or structure is located.
  2. A county shall not enact a zoning resolution or take any other action that eliminates livestock grazing on any private land or land owned by the county without first complying with the provisions of this article.

History.

Laws 1959, ch. 85, § 9; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2019 ch. 165, § 1, effective February 28, 2019.

The 2019 amendment, designated former undesignated paragraph as present (a); and added (b).

Laws 2019, ch. 165 § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8 of the Wyo. Const. Approved February 28, 2019.

Severability. —

Section 10, ch. 85, Laws 1959, reads: “If any provision in this act shall for any reason be invalid, it shall not affect the remainder of this act and this act shall remain in force and effect the same as if such part held invalid had not been included herein.”

Nonconforming gravel business. —

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-5-207 did not deny a county authority to regulate a landowner's nonconforming gravel business by omitting “land” when allowing regulation of changes to nonconforming uses because the statute said nothing about change in land use. Seherr-Thoss v. Teton County Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2014 WY 82, 329 P.3d 936, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2014).

Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-5-207 did not allow a county to reduce the size of a landowner's nonconforming gravel operation because the landowner satisfied the doctrine of diminishing assets by showing (1) the landowner actively ran the business when land use regulations were adopted and objectively showed an intent to expand the business then and (2) operating the business had no substantially different and adverse impact on the neighborhood. Seherr-Thoss v. Teton County Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2014 WY 82, 329 P.3d 936, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2014).

Doctrine of diminishing assets. —

Doctrine of diminishing assets was adopted to resolve an ambiguity in Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-5-207 on use of the word “land” because the doctrine provided an objective way to quantify “land.” Seherr-Thoss v. Teton County Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2014 WY 82, 329 P.3d 936, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2014).

To define the extent of a protected, nonconforming land use involving a diminishing asset, a land owner must prove each prong of the doctrine of diminishing assets, showing (1) excavation activities were actively pursued when a zoning ordinance became effective, (2) the area to be excavated was clearly intended to be excavated, as measured by objective manifestations, and (3) the continued operations have no substantially different and adverse impact on the neighborhood. Seherr-Thoss v. Teton County Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2014 WY 82, 329 P.3d 936, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2014).

Construction. —

Second sentence of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-5-207 creates a permissive exception to the grandfather exception in the first sentence, and this permissive exception is limited to certain uses of buildings and structures and not uses of land because the sentence has no applicability to a change in use of land. Seherr-Thoss v. Teton County Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2014 WY 82, 329 P.3d 936, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2014).

First sentence of Wyo. Stat. Ann. § 18-5-207 is ambiguous regarding the geographic extent of the word “land” because the statute is silent as to whether one may continue a pre-existing use of land throughout the whole parcel, only on the portions of the parcel affected at the time the zoning resolution was adopted, or to some area of land in between those alternatives. Seherr-Thoss v. Teton County Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2014 WY 82, 329 P.3d 936, 2014 Wyo. LEXIS 88 (Wyo. 2014).

Enactment of freeze resolution without notice or hearing, subject to condition. —

Section 18-5-201 gives counties either express or implied power to enact a freeze resolution, without notice and hearing, providing that such a freeze is only for a reasonable length of time. Snake River Venture v. Board of County Comm'rs, 616 P.2d 744, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 296 (Wyo. 1980).

Property owner lacks vested right in contemplated development. —

Property owner has no vested right, which will withstand a later zoning regulation, in a development which is merely contemplated. Snake River Venture v. Board of County Comm'rs, 616 P.2d 744, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 296 (Wyo. 1980).

Nonconforming certificate not required. —

Where landowner had established its intended commercial use in prior years, and where the ten month moratorium banning commercial use was invalid, corporation's commercial use was “grandfathered”, and commercial operations could continue without seeking a certificate permitting nonconforming use. Crouthamel v. Board of Albany County Comm'rs, 951 P.2d 835, 1998 Wyo. LEXIS 11 (Wyo. 1998).

Construction. —

This section forbids counties from enacting zoning regulations that prohibit existing uses. Snake River Brewing Co. v. Town of Jackson, 2002 WY 11, 39 P.3d 397, 2002 Wyo. LEXIS 12 (Wyo. 2002).

Cited in

River Springs Ltd. Liab. Co. v. Board of County Comm'rs, 899 P.2d 1329, 1995 Wyo. LEXIS 125 (Wyo. 1995).

Am. Jur. 2d, ALR and C.J.S. references. —

Classification and maintenance of advertising structure as nonconforming use, 80 ALR3d 630.

Building in course of construction as establishing valid nonconforming use or vested right to complete construction for intended use, 89 ALR3d 1051.

Construction and application of zoning regulations in connection with funeral homes, 92 ALR3d 328.

Validity of zoning ordinances prohibiting or regulating outside storage of house trailers, motor homes, campers, vans and the like, in residential neighborhoods, 95 ALR3d 378.

Enforcement of zoning regulation as affected by other violations, 4 ALR4th 462.

Zoning: occupation of less than all dwelling units as discontinuance or abandonment of multifamily dwelling nonconforming use, 40 ALR4th 1012.

Change in area or location of nonconforming use as violation of zoning ordinance, 56 ALR4th 769.

Alteration, extension, reconstruction or repair of nonconforming structure or structure devoted to nonconforming use as violation of zoning ordinance, 63 ALR4th 275.

Validity of provisions for amortization of nonconforming uses, 8 ALR5th 391.

Activities in preparation for building as establishing valid nonconforming use or vested right to engage in construction for intended use, 38 ALR5th 737.

§ 18-5-208. Special expertise of board of county commissioners and coordination of planning efforts with federal agencies.

  1. When representing a county as a cooperating agency in matters related to the National Environmental Policy Act and in federal land planning, implementation and management actions, a board of county commissioners shall be deemed to have special expertise on all subject matters for which it has statutory responsibility, including but not limited to, all subject matters directly or indirectly related to the health, safety, welfare, custom, culture and socio-economic viability of a county.
  2. The board of county commissioners of a county which has officially adopted a comprehensive plan pursuant to W.S. 18-5-202(b) may participate in efforts to coordinate the plan with federal agencies as provided in the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974, as amended by the National Forest Management Act of 1976 and any other federal statute which provides for coordination with local governments and federal regulations adopted pursuant to those acts.

History.

Laws 1993, ch. 104, § 1; 2012, ch. 13, § 1.

The 2012 amendment, added (a); added (b) designator; and in (b), substituted “agencies” for “regional forest or other resource management plans,” inserted “the Forest and Rangeland Renewable Resources Planning Act of 1974, as amended by the National Forest Management Act of 1976 and any other federal statute which provides for coordination with local governments,” and substituted “those acts” for “that act, including, but not limited to, Title 36, of the Code of Federal Regulations, part 219.7 and Title 43, of the Code of Federal Regulations, part 1610.3” at the end.

Laws 2012, ch. 13 § 2, makes the act effective immediately upon completion of all acts necessary for a bill to become law as provided by art. 4, § 8, Wyo. Const. Approved March 6, 2012.

Federal Land Policy and Management Act. —

The Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, referred to in this section, appears throughout titles 7, 16, 30, 40, and 43 of the United States Code.

Article 3. Real Estate Subdivisions

  • § 18-5-301.  Authority vested in board of county commissioners.
  • § 18-5-302.  Definitions.
  • § 18-5-303.  Exemptions from provisions.
  • § 18-5-304.  Subdivision permit required.
  • § 18-5-305.  Enforcement; rules and regulations.
  • § 18-5-306.  Minimum requirements for subdivision permits.
  • § 18-5-307.  Planning commission may receive applications and make recommendations.
  • § 18-5-308.  Approval by the board.
  • § 18-5-309.  Permit fee.
  • § 18-5-310.  [Repealed.]
  • § 18-5-311.  Investigatory powers.
  • § 18-5-312.  Enforcement.
  • § 18-5-313.  False statement or misrepresentation; penalty.
  • § 18-5-314.  Penalties.
  • § 18-5-315.  Provisions minimum.
  • § 18-5-316.  Requirements for large acreage subdivision permits.
  • § 18-5-317.  Subsequent sale of subdivided lots.
  • § 18-5-318.  Large parcels used for agricultural purposes.

Powers. —

A subdivision developer who alleged that he had an entitlement or right to obtain approval of his subdivision, as originally proposed and without restrictions from a board of county commissioners, failed to identify a clearly established statutory or constitutional right that had been violated. Marshall v. Board of County Comm'rs, 912 F. Supp. 1456, 1996 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 761 (D. Wyo. 1996).

Applied in

McClellan v. State, 933 P.2d 461, 1997 Wyo. LEXIS 31 (Wyo. 1997).

Cited in

Snake River Venture v. Board of County Comm'rs, 616 P.2d 744, 1980 Wyo. LEXIS 296 (Wyo. 1980).

§ 18-5-301. Authority vested in board of county commissioners.

The regulation and control of the subdivision of land in the unincorporated areas in each county is vested in the board of county commissioners of the county in which the land is located. Nothing in this article shall contravene or limit the authority of any county to regulate and control the subdivision of land pursuant to the provisions of W.S. 18-5-201 through 18-5-207.

History.

Laws 1975, ch. 176, § 1; 1977, ch. 124, § 1.

Applied in

Marshall v. Board of County Comm'rs, 912 F. Supp. 1456, 1996 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 761 (D. Wyo. 1996).

Quoted in

Pickle v. Board of County Comm'rs, 764 P.2d 262, 1988 Wyo. LEXIS 151 (Wyo. 1988).

Cited in

Pedro/Aspen, Ltd. v. Bd. of County Comm'rs, 2004 WY 84, 94 P.3d 412, 2004 Wyo. LEXIS 109 (2004).

§ 18-5-302. Definitions.

  1. As used in this article:
    1. Repealed by Laws 2019, ch. 186, §  2.
    2. “Board” means the board of county commissioners of the county in which the land sought to be subdivided is located;
    3. “Encumbrance” means a mortgage or other lien of record, securing or evidencing indebtedness and affecting land to be subdivided including liens for labor and materials. Taxes and assessments levied by public authority are not an encumbrance under this article except such taxes and assessments as may be delinquent;
    4. “Person” means a natural person, firm, corporation, partnership, or association, or any combination of the above, or any other legal or commercial entity;
    5. “Sell” or “sale” includes sale as evidenced by the delivery of a deed, contract for deed, lease, assignment, auction or award by lottery concerning a subdivision or any part of a subdivision. “Sell” or “sale” does not include a contract to sell which is expressly contingent upon the recording of the final plat by the county clerk, if all funds paid by the buyer under the contract are escrowed with a financial institution located in this state or a title company licensed to do business in this state until the final plat is recorded and the seller tenders the deed or the contract to sell is cancelled or the buyer and seller agree otherwise in writing;
    6. “Subdivider” means any person who lays out any subdivision or parts thereof either for the account of the subdivider or others;
    7. “Subdivision” means the creation or division of a lot, tract, parcel or other unit of land for the immediate or future purpose of sale, building development or redevelopment, for residential, recreational, industrial, commercial or public uses. The word “subdivide” or any derivative thereof shall have reference to the term subdivision, including mobile home courts, the creation of which constitutes a subdivision of land;
    8. “Sewage system” means all pipelines, conduits, pumping stations, force mains and other constructions used for collecting or conducting wastes to a treatment plant or disposal system; any plant or other works used for the purpose of treating, stabilizing or holding wastes; and any system used for disposing of wastes, either by surface or underground methods, including any treatment plant, disposal wells and absorption fields;
    9. “Water supply system” includes development of the source and all structures for conveyance of raw water to the treatment plant or delivery systems; all water treatment plants including disinfection facilities; water supply systems used for irrigation and stock water; and all finished water delivery systems including pipelines, pumping stations and finished water storage facilities;
    10. “Parcel” means a contiguous piece of property lawfully created or conveyed of record as a single piece of property.

History.

Laws 1975, ch. 176, § 11; 1977, ch. 124, § 1; 2000, ch. 95, § 1; 2001, ch. 208, § 1; 2008, ch. 88, § 2; 2009, ch. 59, § 2; 2010, ch. 101, § 1; 2019 ch. 186, § 2, effective July 1, 2019.

The 2008 amendment, effective July 1, 2008, substituted “18-5-317” for “18-5-315” in (a)(i); and inserted (a)(x).

The 2009 amendment, effective July 1, 2009, rewrote (a)(v) to expand what is and is not included under definitions of “sell” and “sale”; and in (a)(ix), added “water supply systems used for irrigation and stock water,” and deleted “Separate water supply systems used solely for irrigation or stock water are not included” at the end.

The 2010 amendment, effective July 1, 2010, in (a)(x), substituted “lawfully created or conveyed of record as a single piece of property” for “under common ownership.”

The 2019 amendment, effective July 1, 2019, repealed (a)(i), which read: “ ‘This article’ means W.S. 18-5-301 through 18-5-317.”

Editor's notes. —

There is no subsection (b) in this section as it appears in the printed acts.

Unlawful subdivision. —
